## 14.10  Resource Classification

The Mineral Resources are classified under the categories of Indicated and Inferred according to CIM guidelines. Due to a lack of dense (&lt;35 m x 35 m) drilling and pending further analysis of the Actlabs vs. SGS accuracy issues no Measured Mineral Resource has been assigned at this stage for the Project.

SRK's  classification  mainly  reflects  the  relative  confidence  of  the  geological  model  and  the associated grade estimates. This classification is also based on:

- · Sample  spacing  relative  to geological and  geo-statistical observations  regarding  the continuity of mineralization;
- · Data verification to original sources;
- · Specific gravity determinations;
- · Accuracy of drill collar locations;
- · Accuracy of topographic surface; and
- · Quality  of  the  assay  data  and  many  other  factors,  which  influence  the  confidence  of  the mineral estimation.

No single factor controls the resource classification; rather, each factor influences the result.

For the resource classification, a solid shape was constructed around the relatively well drilled core of the deposit resulting from the NioCorp Phase I to Phase III programs, where most drillholes are spaced approximately 60 to 70 m apart which allows typically three holes to be used for the first estimation search pass.

All blocks located within this area were classified as Indicated Mineral Resource (Figure 14-18). All blocks estimated outside of the perimeter of drillholes are classified as Inferred Mineral Resource, which typically extends 100 to 150 m beyond the drilling.

## 14.11   Mineral Resource Statement

The  following  section  defines  the  updated  Mineral  Resource  Statement  for  the  Project.  This statement  includes  the  estimated  Mineral  Resources  for  Nb2O5,  TiO2  and  Sc  for  the  deposit  the Effective  Date  of  Mineral  Resource  is  May  15,  2017,  which  is  the  date  the  final  metallurgical recoveries  were  determine  for  use  in  the  CoG  calculation.  This  represents  the  latest  Mineral Resource for the Project.

CIM Definition Standards for Mineral Resources and Mineral Reserves (May 2014) defines a Mineral Resource as:

'(A)  concentration  or  occurrence  of  diamonds,  natural  solid  inorganic  material,  or  natural  solid fossilized organic material including base and precious metals, coal, and industrial minerals in or on the  Earth's  crust  in  such  form  and  quantity  and  of  such  a  grade  or  quality  that  it  has  reasonable prospects  for  economic  extraction.  The  location,  quantity,  grade,  geological  characteristics  and continuity  of  a  Mineral  Resource  are  known,  estimated  or  interpreted  from  specific  geological evidence and knowledge'.

Portions of a deposit that do not have reasonable prospects for eventual economic extraction must not be included in a Mineral Resource.

The 'reasonable prospects for economic extraction' requirement generally implies that the quantity and grade estimates meet certain economic thresholds and that the Mineral Resources are reported at an appropriate CoG taking into account extraction scenarios and processing recoveries. Based on this  requirement, SRK considers that major portions of the Project are amenable for underground extraction with a processing method to recover FeNb (as the saleable product of Nb2O5), TiO2 and Sc2O3 products.

The result of positive indications from the company's metallurgical testing and development program, titanium (TiO2) and scandium (Sc) were added to the Mineral Resource Statement in February 2015. Both of these metals can be recovered with simple additions to the existing process flowsheet, and would  provide  additional  revenue  streams  that  would  complement  the  planned  production  of ferroniobium.

In the previous Mineral Resource Estimate SRK quoted the Mineral Resource using a CoG based on Nb2O5 only, but on-going work by the Company since the 2015 PEA has resulted in a change in approach to CoG, which is now based on a NSR basis. The economic parameters were selected based  on  experience  and  benchmarking  against  similar  projects  and  work  completed  by  the Company (Table 14-16).

SRK  based  price  and  cost  assumptions  on  the  pricing  of  products  at  the  'mine-gate',  with  no additional down-stream costs required. The assumed products are a ferroniobium product (in metal form, approximately 65% Nb and 35% Fe), a titanium dioxide product in powder form, and scandium trioxide in powder form. NioCorp completed market studies (with recognized independent companies)  to  obtain  pricing,  which  SRK  has  reviewed  and  completed  an  independent  review  of FeNb. Based on the review SRK is of the opinion that the prices are reasonable for the determination of potential for eventual economic extraction.

SRK has provided reasonable estimates of the expected costs based on the knowledge of the style of mining (underground) and potential processing methods. The selected metal recovery is based on the current metallurgical test work completed during the FS program.

The reader is cautioned that the results are used solely for the purpose of testing the 'reasonable prospects  for  economic  extraction'  by  underground  mining  methods,  and  do  not  represent  an attempt to estimate Mineral Reserves.

The estimated cost information presented here is used as a guide to assist in the preparation of a Mineral Resource Statement and to select an appropriate resource reporting CoG.

The detailed description of the NSR calculation is defined in Section 15.2.4, but in summary, NSR has therefore been calculated as follows:

NSR (US$) = Revenue per block from Nb2O5 + Revenue per block from TiO2 + Revenue per block from Sc

## Tonnes per Block

The  Mineral  Resource  has  been  filtered  to  show  all  blocks  above  the  mining  cut-off  to  ensure estimates form suitable mining targets. Any isolated blocks of material reporting above cut-off can be removed as they will unlikely warrant the cost of development. No such cases existed at the Project and  all  material  within  the  geological  wireframes  above  a  cut-off  of  US$180/t  NSR  has  been considered to have reasonable prospects of being mined via underground methods.

SRK defined a Mineral Resource on receipt of a validated database, to account for these additional revenue streams. No additional resource definition drilling has been completed since the October 2015 press release and therefore changes have been limited to additional information provided from the  2016  re-assay  program  of  historical  pulps.  The  updated  Mineral  Resource  is  based  on  an additional 203 pulp samples, 374 pulverized pulp, and 90 chip samples re-assayed from historical holes which had not previously been assayed for TiO2% or Sc (ppm). The Mineral Resource also accounted for an estimate of the density values, as a relationship has been identified by SRK for higher density values at higher Nb2O5, TiO2 and Fe2O3 grades.

The Mineral Resource Statement in Table 14-17 has been determined using a net smelter return cutoff  value  based  on  economic  parameters  as  defined  in  Table  14-16.  The  Mineral  Resource  was

disclosed on February 23, 2015. This should be considered the latest estimate for the Project and be used in any future studies.

## 15 Mineral Reserve Estimate

## 15.1  Introduction

The  Project  is  currently  in the  exploration  phase  and  has  not  been  developed.  Based  on geomechanical information and mineralization geometry an underground longhole stoping method (LHS) is suitable for the deposit. Paste backfill will be used to allow for a high recovery of material.

The stopes will be 15 m wide and stope length will vary based on mineralization grade. A spacing of 25 m between levels has been used. The deposit is mined in blocks where mining within a block occurs from bottom to top with the use of paste backfill. Sill pillars are left in situ between blocks. The backfill will have sufficient strength to allow for mining adjacent to filled stopes, thus eliminating the need for dip pillars.

The  mine  will be shaft access to minimize development  through water bearing horizons. Mineralization  will  be  transported  from  stopes  to  the  shaft/hoist  system  by  underground  trucks.  A single ventilation raise will serve as a dedicated exhaust raise and will be raisebored conventionally. Intake air will be down the shaft with fresh air entering a dedicated ventilation drift above the loading pocket. As levels are developed lower in the deposit short slot raises will be developed connecting levels for ventilation purposes.

Access and infrastructure  development  underground  was  designed  to  support  the  mining  method and sized based on mining equipment and production rate requirements. Surface infrastructure and tailings were designed on lands which NioCorp has an option to purchase. The general layout of the mine and surface infrastructure is shown in Figure 15-1.

<!-- image -->

Source: SRK, 2017

## 15.2  Conversion Assumptions, Parameters and Methods

Indicated  Mineral  Resources  were  converted  to  Probable  Mineral  Reserves  by  applying  the appropriate modifying factors, as described herein, to potential mining block shapes created during the  mine  design  process.  No  Measured  Resources  are  estimated  and,  as  a  result,  no  Proven Reserves are stated.

The undiluted tonnes and grade of each potential mining block is based on the resource block model estimated  by  SRK  as  described  in  Section  14  of  this  report.  All  Mineral  Reserve  tonnages  are expressed as "dry' tonnes (i.e., no moisture) and are based on the density values stored in the block model.

## 15.2.1 Dilution

The  mining  dilution  estimate  for  this  FS  is  based  on  the  equivalent  linear  overbreak/slough methodology (ELOS) (Clark, 1997). ELOS is an empirical design method that is used to estimate the amount of overbreak/slough that will occur in an underground opening based on rock quality and the

hydraulic radius of the opening. For the FS design, ELOS was applied to in situ rock exposed and to the paste backfill walls wherever mining will occur adjacent to a secondary stope. In additional to the ELOS allowances, a percent additional dilution allowance was used to account for other potential sources of dilution (e.g., dilution from the floor when mucking a stope).

ELOS assumptions are shown in Table 15-1.

Table 15-1: Dilution ELOS Assumptions

| Type                 |   ELOS Value (m) |
|----------------------|------------------|
| Sidewalls (rock)     |              0.3 |
| Sidewalls (backfill) |              0.3 |
| Bottom (backfill)    |              0.1 |

Source: SRK, 2017

The rock sidewall dilution material will be mineralized, as the deposit mineralization shows a gradual decrease in grade from the stopes in all directions. To determine the grade that should be used for dilution material 3-D triangulations were generated showing the dilution for a general representative area  of  the  deposit.  Figure  15-2  shows  the  bottom  and  sidewall  dilution  shapes  in  blue  with  the planned stope design shapes in green.

<!-- image -->

Figure 15-2: Bottom and sidewall dilution shapes

<!-- image -->

Grade for the dilution in rock was calculated and compared to the average grade of the stopes and is summarized as follows:

- · Nb2O5 grade of dilution is 83% of the average stope grade
- · TiO2 grade of dilution is 94% of the average stope grade
- · Sc grade of dilution is 89% of the average stope grade

These percentages of average stope grade are applied to each individual stope for the portion of ELOS which would be rock. Stopes are typically above other stopes 75% of the time. 20% of the time the stopes are not adjacent to other stopes. A zero grade is used for backfill dilution.

The ELOS and additional dilution factor gives a total dilution of 6%, with 3% of the dilution having grade from rock adjacent to stopes.

For horizontal development in ore (other than drill drives inside a stope), dilution of 5% was applied at zero grade.

## 15.2.2 Recovery

A stope recovery factor of 94% was used. The following items were used to calculate this factor:

- · Material loss into backfill (floor) or 0.4 m;
- · Material loss to side and endwalls (underblast) of 0.2 m;
- · Material loss to mucking along sides and in blind corners; and
- · Additional loss factor due to rockfalls, misdirected loads, and other geotechnical reasons.

A development recovery factor of 95% was used for all horizontal development.

## 15.2.4 Cut-off Grade Calculation

Net Smelter Return (NSR) is a commonly accepted method of evaluating a mineral deposit where revenue  is  generated  from  multiple  elements.  NSR  is  defined  as  the  proceeds  from  the  sale  of

mineral  products  after deducting  off-site processing  and  distribution  costs. NSR  is  typically expressed  on  a  dollar  per  tonne  basis.  For  this  Project,  the  NSR  calculation  takes  into  account revenue for three products, FeNb, TiO2, and Sc2O3. A factor of 0.699 was used to convert Nb2O5 in the block model to Nb contained in the FeNb product. Similarly, a factor of 1.534 (1/0.652) was used to convert Sc to Sc2O3.

Recoveries  used  are  based  on  metallurgical  test  work  discussed  in  Section  13.  The  NSR  was evaluated  for  each  block  in  the  3-D  geologic  resource  block  model.  Table  15-4  shows  NSR parameters and an example NSR calculation for an individual block.

## 15.3  Reserves

Mineral  Reserves  were  classified  using  the  2014  CIM  Definition  Standards.  Indicated  Mineral Resources  were  converted  to  Probable  Mineral  Reserves  by  applying  the  appropriate  modifying factors,  as  described  herein,  to  potential  mining  block  shapes  created  during  the  mine  design process.

The underground mine design process results in mine plan resources of 31.7Mt (diluted) with an average grade of 0.79% Nb2O5, 2.81% TiO2, and 72 ppm Sc.

This estimate is based on a mine design using elevated CoGs and applying the US$180/t NSR CoG to material within the design. These numbers include a 94% to 100% mining recovery based on type of  opening  (stope,  development,  etc.)  to  the  designed  wireframes  in  addition  to  a  0%  to  6% unplanned dilution. A portion of the dilution does include grade as described in Section 15.2.1. An additional development allowance of 14% was applied to main ramps and 12% to level accesses to account for detail currently not in the design.

## 16 Mining Methods

## 16.1  Geology Overview

The mine planning work is based on the resource geology and block model, described in chapter 14 of this report. The deposit is hosted within the Elk Creek Carbonatite. Carbonatites commonly occur as intrusive bodies, such as isolated sills, dikes, or plugs, although rarely occur as extrusive rocks. The Carbonatite is covered by approximately 190 to 200 m of Pennsylvanian sedimentary rock and till. niobium (Nb2O5), titanium (TiO2), and scandium (Sc) mineralization are hosted in the carbonatite. The current known extents of the Carbonatite unit are approximately 950 m along strike, 300 m wide, and 750 m in dip extent.

Two dominant trend surfaces have been used in the block model creation process. The southwest contact has been modelled using a strong sub-vertical trend (shown in blue), while the northeast of the deposit has followed moderate dipping trends (shown in black) parallel to the low-grade mafic units (shown in green) as shown Figure 16-1.

<!-- image -->

Source: SRK, 2015

In addition  to  the  mineralization,  various  other  elements  were  estimated  into  the  model  for metallurgical purposes.

## 16.2  Mining and Project History

The majority of exploration over the Project area was completed by Molycorp prior to 1984. Starting in 2009, the title of the Project was held by Elk Creek Resources Corp. (ECRC). On May 4, 2010 Quantum announced the acquisition  of  ECRC  and  acquired  the  mineral  rights  to  the  Project.  On March  3, 2013  Quantum  announced  an  official name  change  from  Quantum  Rare  Earth

Developments  Corp.  to  NioCorp  Developments  Ltd.  (NioCorp).  NioCorp's  focus  is  to  develop  the Project.

SRK  completed  a  PEA  for  the  Project  originally  published  on  May  15,  2015  and  Amended  on October 16, 2015.

## 16.3  Geotechnical Design Parameters

From May 21, 2014 to July 30, 2015 SRK completed a geotechnical investigation program on site for the Project. The program was designed to characterize subsurface geotechnical conditions to assist in  the  development  of  a  FS  design  capable  of  meeting  the  requirements  for  basic  engineering design.

The  geotechnical  database  used  for  analyses  includes  data  from  two  geotechnical  borehole databases:  the  2014  program  and  a  previous  2011  program.  A  geotechnical  model  was  created using the characterization information in the databases to estimate rock mass quality, rock strength, and  major  discontinuities  in  the  carbonatite  hangingwall  and  footwall  and  the  Pennsylvanian Formation. The 3-D geotechnical model was built using the Vulcan software, wherein representative volumes of rock mass quality domains were created. The following is a summary of the geotechnical parameters used to assess the mine design.

## Data Collection

The geotechnical field investigation consisted of 23 drillholes, totaling 20,379 m. The program was designed to examine rock mass fabric and structural features in and around the mineralized zone at different depths and orientations. The drilling was conducted  in  three  phases  with  incremental  data  collection  designed  to  fill  knowledge  gaps  on  geotechnical  conditions. Drillholes were drilled at varying orientations into the hangingwall, footwall, and mineralized rock to capture data on rock mass discontinuity variations. The drillholes are shown in Source: SRK, 2017

Figure 16-2 in plan view and the location data are summarized in Table 16-1. The field investigation included  drilling  of  core,  geophysical  borehole  logging  of  structural  features,  geotechnical  core logging, core sample collection for laboratory strength testing, and in situ stress measurements.

<!-- image -->

The 2015 PEA mining geometry is represented in this figure. Minor changes to the layout and stopes have been made since for FS design. Source: SRK, 2017

Structural  features  (discontinuities)  encountered  during  this  field  investigation  consisted  of  joints, lithological contacts, veins, dikes, foliation, faults, shear zones and fractures. Orientation data was collected using acoustic televiewer (ATV) down-hole equipment. Typical alteration on discontinuity surfaces  was  recorded  in  the  logs  and  included  mineralized  coatings  or  infillings  with  occasional hematite staining. Faulting was interpreted using evidence of slickensided surfaces and the presence of gouge infilling and orientations verified using the ATV orientation data.

## Geotechnical Domains

Four  spatial geotechnical  domains  were  identified  based  on  lithology,  weathering,  structural conditions and rock mass strength similarities. These geotechnical domains include:

- · Pennsylvania Formation in the upper 200 m;
- · Hangingwall material to southwest of the orebody;
- · Mineralized carbonatite orebody; and
- · Footwall material to northeast of the orebody.

## Rock Mass Quality

The laboratory testing program included 71 Unconfined Compressive Strength (UCS) tests of intact samples,  17  Triaxial  Compressive  Strength  (TCS)  tests  of  intact  samples,  and  38  Direct  Shear Strength (DSS) tests of jointed rock samples. Triaxial tests were conducted at different confinement levels  (80  tests)  to  account  for  anticipated  variations  in  stress  conditions.  A  set  of  29  static  and dynamic elastic constant measurements were collected to characterize the elastic properties of the rock.  A  total  of  12  Brazilian  Tensile  Strength  (BTS)  tests  were  conducted  to  characterize  tensile strength  of  the  rock  mass.  The  UCS  results  were  used  to  calibrate  the  spatial  variation  of  UCS values interpreted from 2,180 Point Load Tests (PLT) conducted in the field during the core logging program.  The  laboratory  tests  were  sufficient  to  develop  shear  strength  parameters  (intact  and discontinuity) and provide estimates of the statics and dynamics elastic constants.

The majority of the Rock Quality Designation (RQD) values indicate fair to good rock quality (RQD = 80  to  100)  throughout  the  drillholes.  Regions  with  lower  RQD  (RQD  =  10  to  60)  were  generally associated  with  weathered  or  altered  rock  zones  and/or  minor  geological  intrusions.  Fracture frequencies ranged from 0.1 to 9 fractures per meter with an average of 3 fractures per meter.

The core was generally  fresh  to  slightly  weathered  with  weathering  limited  to  the  surfaces  of  the discontinuities  of  slight  rock  mass  alteration.  Field  index  strength  tests  indicate  that  the  core  was

strong on average (R4). The core tended to break along pre-existing planes of weakness such as veins, foliation and healed structural features.

Laboratory  UCS  tests  results  indicate  that  the  carbonatite  and  lamprophyre  strength  ranges  from strong to very strong (UCS = 50 to 250 MPa), whereas the mafic dikes and mudstone and limestone of the Pennsylvania Formation are moderately strong to strong (UCS = 25 to 100 MPa). ## Pre-Mining Stress Regime

Since no information on in situ stresses was available in the region and this underground mine would be the first in the district, a stress measurement program was undertaken.

In  September  2014,  Agapito  Associates,  Inc.  (AAI,  2014)  performed  downhole  in  situ  horizontal stress testing at the site using the Sigra IST tool. The purpose of the testing program was to estimate the in situ horizontal stress field in the two basic rock types present at the site: the un-mineralized Pennsylvania rock (above 200 m depth) and the mineralized carbonatite ore zone (below 200 m). A total of thirteen tests were conducted; eight of which were successful. The results of the study were as follows:

- · There  is  an  apparent  increase  of  stress  with  depth  of  about  36  kPa/m  for  the  major horizontal stress ( σ H) and 21 kPa/m for the minor horizontal stress( σ h);
- · The major horizontal stress is about 20% greater than the vertical stress ( σ  /σ H V=1.2) and the minor horizontal stress is 71% of the vertical stress ( σ  /σ h V=0.7);
- · The average orientation of the major stress is N 66° E, however, a calculation using ATV borehole breakout data provides a better estimate of N 72° E;
- · The orientation of the principal stresses is well correlated with the orientation of the major fault structures, validating the major fault model; and

- · Figure  16-5  shows  a  summary  of  the  major  and  minor  stress  orientation  relative  to  the fracture set orientations and fault structure orientations.

<!-- image -->

Source: SRK, 2017

## Seismicity

A  high-level  assessment  of  the  local  seismic  earthquake  potential  from  the  International  Building Code suggests a local Peak Ground Acceleration (PGA) of 0.02g for a 50-year return earthquake event. The source of the peak ground acceleration is the 2002 USGS Interactive National Seismic Hazard  Map  (Frankel  et  al,  2003).  It  shows  the  Maximum  Design  Earthquake  (MDE)  with  an expected 1% probability of having an earthquake of magnitude greater than 5.0 in 100 years.

No additional studies of seismicity were conducted since the region is not particularly known for large earthquake activity.

## Mine Layout Parameters

SRK  evaluated  different  mining  methods.  Given  constraints  on  limiting  the  extent  of  surface disturbance, long-hole open stoping with backfilling was selected as the optimal mining method for the orebody. To maximize ore extraction, SRK has selected a primary/secondary stope extraction sequence,  whereby  primary  stopes  are  mined  first  on  first  pass  and  backfilled  prior  to  mining secondary stopes.

The orebody shape is longest in the northwest-to-southeast direction, which is nearly perpendicular to  the  major principal stress ( σ 1).  Considering the principal stress orientations, the major geologic structures, and the local discontinuity orientations, SRK has chosen the stopes orientation to be N 60°E creating the most favorable ground conditions during mining. In this way, the major principal stress  is  redistributed  around  the  smallest  dimension  of  the  primary  stopes.  Figure  16-6  shows  a plan  view  of  stope  orientations  with  the  hangingwall  toward  the  southwest  and  footwall  (with infrastructure) towards the northeast.

<!-- image -->

Source: SRK, 2015

To minimize long-term, mining-induced damage to access drifts, the setback distances used in the design of the mine is 25 m for haulage drives and 75 m for the main ramps. These values represent the minimum distance between the drifts and induced stresses from stope mining. These setback distances were verified from the results of 3-D numerical modeling of the mining sequence.

## Stope Dimensions

A stope stability assessment was completed using the stability graph method (Mathews et al., 1981; Potvin, 1988; Potvin and Milne, 1992 and Nickson, 1992) with stope dimensions of:

- · Width: 15 m
- · Height: 30 m
- · Length: 50 m

The method compares the hydraulic radius (area divided by perimeter) of a stope face to a stability index number. The stability index number accounts for the rock mass quality (primarily Q values) with  adjustments  for  local  fracture  orientations,  potential  block  failure  mode  into  the  stope,  and induced  mining  stresses.  The  results  from  the  stability  assessment  indicated  that  the  initial dimensions for stopes are stable. Figure 16-7 and Figure 16-8 show the stability chart of each stope face under slightly weathered and moderately weathered carbonatite conditions, respectively.

<!-- image -->

Source: SRK, 2017

<!-- image -->

Source: SRK, 2017

A  second  stability  assessment  was  completed  by  using  larger  stope  dimensions  assuming  15% dilution along the walls. Results of this analysis indicate that these diluted stopes should be stable but  may  require  some  support  depending  on  rock  mass  quality.  The  actual  in  situ  rock  mass conditions need to be incorporated in the final stope designs.

Stope stability was verified using 3-D numerical model which simulated the stoping sequence.

## Backfill Strength

An  initial  backfill  strength  assessment  was  completed  for  the  primary/secondary  stopes.  This assessment identified  the  minimum  strength  required  for  the  primary  panels  to  be  self-supporting when  they  are  exposed  on  the  east  and  west  walls.  Two  methods  were  used  to  determine  the minimum  backfill  strengths:  2-D  analytic  vertical  stope  method  and  numerical  modeling  using FLAC3D stope-scale model.

The  analytical  methods  included  Li  and  Aubertin  (2014)  and  Belem  and  Benzaazoua  (2004)  for single  stope  face  of  backfill  exposed  during  secondary  stope  mining  (exposing  two  backfill  faces simultaneously is not planned). Using a factor of safety of 2.0, a 14-day UCS strength of 1.0 MPa was considered the minimum strength for the primary stope panels. The numerical modeling results confirmed  these  values.  The  model  was  also  used  to  verify  that  secondary  stopes  would  remain stable  in  that  no  'sit-down'  failure  mechanism  would  occur  against  two  adjacent  backfilled  stopes during the progressive mining of the secondary stope.

## Dilution

Dilution  was  estimated  using  the  method  developed  by  Clark  and  Pakalnis  (1997)  based  on  an empirical model calibrated to case histories for dilution into open stopes. The method predicts the quantity of unstable wall rock for a given rock mass quality from a given stope size. The parameters plotted on the dilution chart are the stability number, N', and hydraulic radius.

The thickness of external dilution is estimated as an ELOS. Figure 16-9 shows the range of predicted equivalent linear overbreak/slough (ELOS) for moderately weathered carbonatite, and Figure 16-10 shows ELOS for fresh to slightly weathered carbonatite. Sidewall and back dilution is not expected to be  a  problem  because  in  primary  stopes  dilution  (from  secondary  stopes)  will  be  at  grade  and dilution  from  secondary  stopes  is  managed  by  controlling  backfill  strength.  Given  the  low  fracture frequencies (about 3 m / fracture) dilution is anticipated to be variable.

For design purposed, an average of 0.2 m of ELOS dilution has been assumed for endwalls and 0.3 m for sidewalls. In backfilled sidewalls an average of 0.3 m has been assumed.

Source: SRK, 2017

## Ground Support

Ground  support  requirements  have  been  estimated  using  empirical  support  charts  developed  by Barton  (1974).  The  method  relates  the  rock  mass  quality  (Q)  to  the  equivalent  dimension  of  the excavation (De). De is the ratio of the excavation width (D) to the excavation support ratio (ESR) index.  The  ESR  value  accounts  for  a  degree  of  safety  required  depending  on  the  use  of  the excavation.  Values  ranges  from  ESR=1.6  for  long-term  critical  access  drifts  to  2.5  for  short-term temporary  accesses  into  stopes.  The  recommended  ground  support  consists  of  three  general classes of support levels based on rock mass quality, drift usage and drift dimensions. The threeclass system includes:

- · Support Type 1 - spot bolting for Q&gt;4 (~69% of drifts);
- · Support Type 2 - systematic bolting and 4 to 10 cm of fiber reinforced shotcrete for Q&lt;4 and Q&gt;1 (~24% of drifts); and
- · Support Type 3 - systematic bolting, steel mesh, and 4 to 10 cm of plain shotcrete for Q&lt;1 (~7% of drifts).

Table  16-4  summarizes  the  drift  dimensions  used  to  estimate  ground  support  requirements.  The Support specifications are summarized in Table 16-5.

## Crown Pillar Stability

Crown pillar stability assessment was conducted using the empirical Scaled Span Method (Carter, 1992) and a limit equilibrium analysis in the CPillar software. The results of the empirical analysis indicate that if  the  rock  mass  quality  in  the  crown  has  a  Q  value  greater  than  37,  then  all  stopes could be mined in Level 1 with a Factor of Safety (FOS) of more than 2.0. No additional analyses are required  at  this  time  because  the  stopes  are  planned  to  be  tightly  backfilled  and  the  FOS  will  be much higher.

The results of the 3D numerical model confirm that the crown pillar will remain stable during and after mining. The total predicted surface displacement is anticipated to be less than about 1 cm at the end of mining.

## 16.4  Hydrogeology Design Parameters

The hydrogeology of the deposit is characterized based on three phases of work:

- 1. The first phase of hydrogeological characterization was conducted during phases 1 and 2 of the  core  drilling  program  and  consisted  of  packer  testing,  installation  of  piezometers,  and measurement of water levels. Specifically, the program included:
- o 42 downhole packer-isolated injection and airlift tests in coreholes;
- o Installation of six 2 inch PVC standpipe piezometers isolated in the carbonatite and open to large intervals of the deposit;
- o Installation of two nominal 2 inch PVC standpipe piezometers isolated in the 180 m thick Pennsylvanian aquitard above the carbonatite; and
- o Frequent measurement of water levels in open coreholes and piezometers over a period of six months.
- 2. Following the second phase of resource-related core drilling, a 10-day airlift pumping test was completed using a deep, open, vertical PQ corehole as a pumping well. Water levels from the surrounding piezometers were recorded over the duration of the test and for several weeks following the test.
- 3. The third phase of hydrogeological characterization involved installation of two multi-level, distally-located piezometers and a deep 6 inch diameter injection well completed to depths of 850 m, followed by completion of a nominal 30-day injection test. The piezometers were completed within the carbonatite at distances of 0.6 km and 1.2 km from the center of the injection well at the center of the deposit. The injection test was chosen as a test method over a standard pumping test due to the salinity of the groundwater and the expense of handling the discharge water. During the injection test, surface water from Todd Creek was injected at rates of between 22 and 30 L/sec (350 to 480 gpm) over a period of 33 days, including downtime. Response to the injection test was monitored over the duration of the test and for more than eight weeks following the test.

## Conceptual Hydrogeology

Significant components of the pre-mining conceptual hydrogeology at Elk Creek are:

- · The local geology consists of a thin layer of glacial till overlying 180 m of low-permeability Pennsylvanian-aged shale and limestone resting on top of the carbonatite host rock.
- · The  horizontal  hydraulic  conductivity  (K)  of  the  Pennsylvanian  strata  is  on  the  order  of 10 -4 m/d; the vertical K of the limestone is likely 100 times lower. The Pennsylvanian strata essentially  isolates  the  glacial  till  groundwater  system  from  the  deeper  carbonatite,  and functions as an aquitard.
- · The carbonatite  is  faulted  by  regional  and  local  structures,  and  exhibits  elevated  K  along faults to the full depth of the mapped resource, from 200 m at the limestone contact to at least 850 m  below  ground  surface  (bgs).  The  total  vertical  depth  of  the  permeable carbonatite is unknown. The carbonatite may be micro-karstic in places. Measured K values in  the  carbonatite  range  from  10 -2 m/d  in  undisturbed  rock  to  2  m/d  along  faults.  The distribution of hydraulic conductivity is shown on Figure 16-11.

- · The carbonatite appears to be quasi-isotropic and relatively homogenous, despite being a fractured  rock  unit,  as  illustrated  by  the  inferred  drawdown  observed  at  the  end  of  the injection test shown on Figure 16-12.
- · The carbonatite is surrounded by granite, which is believed to be relatively non-permeable (assumed  K=  10 -2 m/d), and  may  be  regionally faulted, providing limited hydraulic communication laterally into the carbonatite.
- · Water  levels  in  the  Pennsylvanian  strata  are  nominally  50  to  80  meters  below  ground surface (mbgs), while depths to groundwater in the carbonatite are approximately 100 mbgs. There is a downward hydraulic gradient from the limestone to the carbonatite.
- · The heads in the carbonatite require that groundwater flows from the carbonatite to a lowerpressure  'sink',  or  distant  groundwater  or  surface  water  body.  The  Central  Missouri  fault (Central  Plains  Shear  Zone)  may  hydraulically  connect  the  deep  carbonatite  to  a  distant boundary such as the Missouri River in the southeast or a distant oil and gas basin to the east (Forest City Basin).

The  conceptual  model  for  the  Project  is  based  primarily  on  testing  and  water  level  information acquired within the boundaries of the deposit, with the exception of two piezometers located 0.6 and 1.2 km to the south and southeast. The structural features, the granite, and the distal carbonatite surrounding the deposit have not been well characterized, and these hydrogeological units will play a large  role  in  controlling  inflow  to  an  underground  mine.  There  is  a  lack  of  information  on  the carbonatite to the west and north outside of the deposit, and an absence of test data or water levels in the granite. There are also uncertainties with the permeable thickness of carbonatite, as well as with the distribution of K with depth. The presence of a distant, external water source(s) through a geologic structure (Central Plains Megashear) hydraulically connected to the carbonatite groundwater system is not confirmed. A conceptual hydrogeological snap shot of the Project toward the end of the mine life is provided Figure 16-13.

The  conceptual  model  was  refined  and  evaluated  using  a  numerical  groundwater  flow  model (described  below)  of  the  Project,  and  various  alternatives  were  calibrated  adequately  to  data measured in the field.

## Predicted Dewatering Requirements

A fully three-dimensional groundwater-flow model was constructed using the finite difference code -MODFLOW-SURFACT. The Elk Creek numerical model defines dewatering requirements for four years  of  pre-production  and  32  years  of  productive  underground  mining.  Model  predictions  were completed for both passive inflow and active dewatering scenarios.

The model predicts for the Base Case a maximum passive inflow in Year 0 of about 580 L/sec for ungrouted conditions and 385 L/sec in year 14, if grouting of the developments is implemented. The amount of predicted passive inflow to the underground could not be handled effectively with an inmine  sump  system,  and  therefore  active  dewatering  with  wells  will  be  required. ## Active dewatering predictions include:

- · A maximum dewatering rate of 757 L/sec from 12 wells reached in pre-mining Year -1, and maintained through Year 4, as shown on Figure 16-14.
- · Dewatering rates begin to decline in Year 5, and decrease to 230 L/sec by the end of mine life;
- · Initially, approximately 97% of inflow to the wells would come from groundwater storage and 3% from the distal water source. By end of mining, 79% of the total inflow to dewatering wells will originate from the distal water source; and
- · A  maximum  drawdown  of  652  m  will  occur  within  the  mineralized  carbonatite  zone. Drawdown at the carbonatite-granite contact is estimated to range from 445 to 485 m.

<!-- image -->

Source: SRK, 2017

The largest uncertainties associated with dewatering requirement predictions are associated with the following factors:

- · The thickness of the permeable carbonatite;
- · The K of the granite;
- · The specific yield of the carbonatite; and
- · The  existence  or  absence  of  a  distal,  external  water  source  through  a  geologic  structure (e.g., Central  Plains  Megashear  or  other)  hydraulically  connected  to  the  carbonatite groundwater system.

These uncertainties could be addressed either through a large-scale, long duration pumping test or through the installation and operating of the active dewatering system over an extended period of time. ## 16.5  Mine Design

## 16.5.1 Selection of Mining Method

Based on geomechanical information and mineralization geometry an underground longhole stoping method (LHS) is suitable for the deposit. Paste backfill will be used to allow for a high recovery of material.

The stopes will be 15 m wide and stope length will vary based on mineralization grade. A spacing of 25 m between levels has been used. The deposit is mined in blocks where mining within a block occurs from bottom to top with the use of paste backfill. Sill pillars are left in situ between blocks. The backfill will have sufficient strength to allow for mining adjacent to filled stopes, thus eliminating the need for dip pillars.

The  mine  will be shaft access to minimize development  through water bearing horizons. Mineralization  will  be  transported  from  stopes  to  the  shaft/hoist  system  by  underground  trucks.  A single ventilation raise will serve as a dedicated exhaust raise and will be raisebored conventionally. Intake  air  will  move  down  the  shaft  with  fresh  air  entering  a  dedicated  ventilation  drift  above  the loading  pocket.  As  levels  are  developed  lower  in  the  deposit  short  slot  raises  will  be  developed connecting levels for ventilation purposes.

The mine design process involved using stope optimization within Vulcan™ software to determine potentially mineable areas based on a CoG and minimum mining dimensions. Dilution and recovery were  added  to  the  designed  tonnage  to  account  for  unplanned  stope  dilution  and  unrecoverable material within the stope.

The mining design was based on a marketing constraint provided by NioCorp to produce no more than 7,500 t/y of ferroniobium and a mine life of at least 30 years. Optimization work indicated that a grade  of  0.8%  Nb2O5  was  the  highest  possible  that  would  sustain  a  consistent  ferroniobium production over the LoM. The final mill production rate was established at 2,760 t/d. Once the final

FS level metallurgical recoveries were applied, an annualized production of approximately 7,055 t of ferroniobium  could  be  produced  per  year.  Scandium  trioxide  and  titanium  dioxide  follows  the ferroniobium  production  in  the  mine  plan.  SRK  used  an  NSR  based  approach  on  production scheduling targeting the annual ferroniobium requirement.

Access and infrastructure  development  underground  was  designed  to  support  the  mining  method and sized based on mining equipment and production rate requirements. Surface infrastructure and tailings were designed on lands which NioCorp has an option to purchase. The general layout of the mine and mill is shown in Figure 15-1.

## 16.5.2 Stope Optimization

Figure  16-15  shows  cross  sections  of  the  resource  block  model  blocks  above  a  NSR  CoG  of US$180/t which have been classified as Measured and Indicated. There is a higher-grade portion of mineralization at depth and the mineralization at those depths is approximately 300 m along strike. Higher in the deposit the mineralization is approximately 600 m in length along strike. This model formed the basis of the stope design.

Source: SRK, 2017

<!-- image -->

Stope optimization was completed in Vulcan™ using a minimum mining stope width of 15 m, a stope height of 25 m, variable length along strike, and an NSR CoG of US$180/t. The stopes and block model  are  oriented  to  match  the  direction  of  in  situ  stresses,  which  are  elevated  (~1.2H:1V).  As

discussed in Section 16.3 this stope orientation optimizes stress distribution and allows for mining of larger openings.

To  produce  approximately  7,000  t  FeNb  annually  with  a  process  facility  capacity  of  2,760 t/d  a minimum average grade  of  approximately  0.8%  Nb2O5  must  be  mined.  This  can  be  achieved  by varying  the  mine  design  CoG  somewhat  by  level  to  maintain  the  approximate  average  grade required (and can be further optimized through short term planning). All CoGs used are above the marginal  calculated  CoG  discussed  in  Section  15.2.4.  Using  elevated  CoGs  to  maximize  NPV  or achieve other company goals has the effect of leaving lower grade resource material in situ. SRK notes that using a cut-off of US$180/t would give an average Nb2O5 grade of approximately 0.64%. To achieve an average Nb2O5 grade of 0.8%, the NSR cut-off is raised to approximately US$500/t, which is a significant increase.

Several  stope  optimization  runs  were  generated  using  various  recoveries,  pricing,  and  cut-offs  to determine  sensitivity  of  the  deposit  to  both  recovery  and  prices.  As  an  elevated  Nb2O5  cut-off  is being targeted the purpose of the stope optimization was to determine at what point the deposit no longer holds together well for mining, and to track average Nb2O5 grades to determine the optimal optimization run to generate the desired quantity of FeNb. Figure 16-16 and Table 16-9 shows stope optimization  results  given  fixed  pricing  and  recovery  as  outlined  in  Section  15.2.4.  Note  that dilution/recovery has not been applied to the optimization results.

## 16.5.3 Stope Design

Stope optimizer shapes were used as a basis for the design work. Stopes are 15 m wide and 25 m high with varying length. Each stope has a 4.5 m x 4.5 m access located at the bottom of the stope as shown in Figure 16-17. Top accesses are designed to give access to stopes on the next level and to allow for backfilling. The stopes are drilled from the top and rings are blasted from the end of a stope toward the footwall access. The blasted material is remotely mucked from the stope access.

<!-- image -->

Source: SRK, 2015

Figure  16-18  shows  a  rotated  view  of  a  typical  level  layout  with  stopes  shown  in  blue  and development  accesses  shown  in  green.  A  level  is  made  up  of  approximately  20  to  30  footwall accesses  and  the  stopes  are  cut  along  strike  to  follow  maximum  geotechnical  lengths.  As  the mineralization is fairly continuous along the length of the stope, there are many instances where 3-4 stopes  are  mined  from  the  same  footwall  access.  Due  to  this,  a  higher  strength  backfill  will  be necessary for a high percentage of stopes.

<!-- image -->

Source: SRK, 2017

A primary/secondary stoping sequence will be used, where on any given level primary stopes must be separated by a secondary stope. Extraction of the secondary stope can only occur after the two immediately  adjacent  primary  stopes  have  been  mined,  backfilled,  and  have  had  time  to  cure. Backfilling will be an integral part of the (LHS) mining cycle, however with the quantity of stopes on a level and flexibility in sequencing mining should not be limited by backfilling operations. If a shorter level is encountered with fewer stopes then backfilling may be a limiting factor which could reduce mining rates on that level.

## 16.5.4 Development Design

The stope accesses are connected to a level access located in waste or low grade material. The level accesses are offset approximately 25 m from the end of stopes. Each stope access typically connects  to  the  level  access  except  in  cases  where  stopes  are  small  and  long  development  is required to reach the stope. In those instances, a connection from an adjacent stope is included in the design. This minimizes the amount of development, however it limits the sequencing order.

The level  accesses  connect  to  the  main  ramp  which  is  offset  at  least  75 m  from  stoping  into  the footwall. On the southeast side of each level the level access connects to an exhaust air ventilation raise  and  on  the  northwest  side  connects  to  a  fresh  air  raise.  The  fresh  air  raise  serves  as  a secondary means of egress. As the main ramp connection is typically near the middle of a level, a manway raise has been designed at the southeast side of the levels to provide another mean of egress for personnel. Figure 16-19 shows a typical level section.

There  is  additional  mineralization  below  block  3,  however  as  these  blocks  provide  an approximate 32 year mine life, additional design was not completed at this time.

## 16.5.5 Mine Access

The underground mine will be accessed through a shaft system that will be sunk conventionally. The surface  facilities  include  a  hoist  house,  headframe  structure,  hoisting  system,  compressor  room, Motor  Control  Center  (MCC)  room,  headframe  structure  with  collar  house,  a  mine  electrical substation,  and  a  development  ventilation  system  that  will  be  converted  to  a  ventilation  booster system during production. Shaft heating will also be provided.

The underground system includes the shaft, two cage-over-skips, an auxiliary cage, loading pocket and  skip  loader,  and  a  muck  handling  system  at  the  bottom  of  the  shaft.  An  emergency  escape system is included in the return air raise.

The hoist house contains a two-hoist system, a main production hoist and an auxiliary hoist. The production hoisting system is a 1,415 kW (1,900 HP), double drum system, 5 m in diameter, in a double-clutch  configuration  for  maximum  efficiency.  The  system  allows  for  up  to  5,000  t  of  muck

hoisting  within  a  ten  hour  shift,  in  addition  to  the  use  of  the  light  duty  service  hoist.  The  second hoisting plant will utilize a 447 kW (600 HP), 2.44 m single drum hoisting plant that will serve as light duty service hoist and secondary means of egress during shaft construction. The auxiliary hoist will be connected to the emergency generator included in the plant electrical system, as it serves as an emergency  egress  from  the  shaft.  The  collar  house  provides  a  staging  area  for  personnel  and materials going down the shaft or returning to the surface and for maintenance.

## Main Ramp Development (long-term development openings)

The main ramp is 5.5 m wide by 5.5 m high with an arched back. It will be developed with a twinboom jumbo drilling 41 mm diameter blast holes and 102 mm relief holes. All jumbo holes will be drilled 4.24 m in length, which allows for an effective advance rate of 3.81 m per round (90% pull). The drill pattern provides for 66 charged blast holes and five uncharged relief holes. Drilling times were calculated based on average penetration rates of 1.8 m/min for loaded holes and 1.0 m/min for reamed holes. A 10% redrill factor was assumed.

Use of a bulk emulsion explosive was assumed at a powder factor of 1.03 kg/t. The blasting cycle time considered mobilization, charging and tying in of holes, clean-up, and demobilization.

Loading will be performed with a 6.2 m 3  (14 t) LHD that will transport blasted rock to remuck bays that are spaced 250 m apart. Load, maneuver and dump times were considered and a 95% bucket fill  factor  was  assumed.  The  time  associated  with  loading  haul  trucks  at  the  remuck  bays  was accounted for as an activity that is separate from the main ramp development.

During  the  pre-production  period,  development  waste  rock  that  is  placed  in  a  remuck  bay  will  be loaded into trucks, hauled to the shaft, and skipped to the surface. During the pre-production period, the  temporary skipping system will be able to handle rock that has not been crushed. During the production period, development waste will be placed in empty secondary stopes.

Ground support will be installed as specified in Table 16-14. Time allowances have been included for mobilization and setup, scaling, bolting/meshing/shotcreting as required, and demobilization.

Utility installation includes piping lines, ventilation tube, electrical cable, messenger cable, and leaky feeder. Piping, ventilation and electrical utilities will be installed at the end of every other round.

## Slots- Stope Development

After top and bottom stope development drifts are established a slot will be developed at the far end of the stope. The slot consists of a conventionally blasted drop raise and 28 fan-drilled holes that will be slashed into the void that is created by the drop raise. Including the fan-drilled holes, the overall dimensions of the slot will be 15 m wide by 6 m long by 25 m high.

All blasthole drilling for the slot will be at a diameter of 114 mm (4.5 inches) using a down-the-hole (DTH) drill. A total of 50 holes will be required for the slot (22 holes for the drop raise and 28 holes for  slashing).  The  estimated  penetration  rate  for  the  DTH  drill  is  0.75  m/min  and  the  total  drilling requirement is 1,105 m (including 10% redrill).

The slot will be removed in a series of four blasts using a bulk emulsion product. The first two blasts will remove the bottom 14 m of the drop raise. The third blast will remove the remaining 6 m at the top of the drop raise along with 14 of the fan-drilled slash holes on one side of the drop raise. The fourth and final blast will remove the remaining fan-drilled slash holes on the opposite side of the drop raise. The overall powder factor for the slot will be 1.39 kg/t based on a slot tonnage of 4,162 t. The blasting cycle  time  includes  travel/set  up  time,  charging  and  tying  in  of  holes,  clean  up,  and demobilization.

Slot ore will be mucked with a 6.2 m 3  LHD that will transport blasted ore to remuck bays that will be located, on average, 150 m from the stope. Load, maneuver and dump times were considered and a 95% bucket fill factor was assumed. The time associated with loading haul trucks at the remuck bays was accounted for as an activity that is separate from slot development.

Ore that is placed in a remuck bay will be loaded into trucks and hauled to the grizzlies feeding the underground material handling system.

## Stoping

Stopes will be 25 m in height x 15 m in width and will have varying lengths. A tophammer longhole production drill will be used to fan drill the stope from the upper access drift. Blast holes will be 114 mm (4.5 inches) in diameter and the estimated drill penetration rate is 1.2 m/min. The total drilling requirement is 192.8 m per ring (including 10% redrill) and the ore blasted per ring is 3,246 t.

Stope blasting will be performed in a series of three-ring blasts, the number of which will be dictated by the length of the stope. Each three-ring blast will have a total of 39 charged holes (13 holes per ring). A bulk emulsion product will be used and the powder factor will be 0.55 kg/t. The estimated blasting cycle time includes travel/set up, charging and  tying in of holes, clean up, and demobilization.

Stope ore will be mucked with a 6.2 m 3  LHD that will transport blasted ore to remuck bays that will be located, on average, 135 m from the stope. Load, maneuver and dump times were considered and a 95% bucket fill factor was assumed. Ore that is placed in a remuck bay will be loaded into trucks and hauled  to  the  grizzlies  feeding  the  underground  material  handling  system;  however,  the  time associated with loading haul trucks is accounted for as a separate activity.

As shown in Table 16-20, the stope production rate is 2,352 t/d.

## Shaft Sinking

The 7.5 m shaft will be sunk conventionally, to a depth of 440 m, at an average rate of 2.23 m/d. This rate was developed in conjunction with contractors for the material expected to be encountered. The rate includes sinking, lining, and adjustments in rate due to rock types. Material will be removed by the temporary hoisting system and placed in the lined temporary stockpile location adjacent to the shaft.

## Raisebored Raises

The 5.5 m diameter lined ventilation exhaust raise will be raisebored. The raise will be approximately 390 m in depth. The raisebore average advance rate is 2.75 m/d. The rate includes drilling the pilot hole, and reaming the vent raise. Loading will be performed with a 6.2 m 3  LHD that will transport cuttings to a remuck bay that will be located 75 m from the bottom of the raise. Load, maneuver and dump times were considered and a 95% bucket fill factor was assumed. Raisebore cuttings that are placed  in  a  remuck  bay  will  be  loaded  into  trucks  and  hauled  and  skipped  to  the  surface  during preproduction.

The 2.0 m internal raise where the emergency escape hoist will be located will be raisebored by a contractor at an estimated advance rate of 5 m/d.

## Ventilation Connections between Levels with Escapeways - Drop Raises

The  raises  will  be  developed  using  conventional  drop  raising  to  establish  ventilation  connections between the levels. The ventilation raise dimension varies with required ventilation volume for that section of the mine.

Waste from the drop raises will be mucked with a 6.2 m 3 (14 t) LHD that will transport the blasted rock to remuck bays that will be located, on average, 100 m from the bottom of each raise. Load, maneuver and dump times were considered and a 95% bucket fill factor was assumed. The time associated  with  loading  haul  trucks  at  the  remuck  bays  was  accounted  for  as  an  activity  that  is separate from ventilation connection development.

During  the  pre-production  period,  development  waste  rock  that  is  placed  in  a  remuck  bay  will  be loaded into  trucks,  hauled  to  the  shaft,  and  skipped  to  the  surface.  During  the  production  period, development waste will be placed in empty secondary stopes.

In ventilation raises where a ladder escapeway is used, the installation time estimate is 45 days in addition to the time noted in the productivity tables for the ventilation raises. In this document, if the heading notes an escapeway is included the additional time and cost of the manway was included in the feasibility estimate and production schedule.

## 16.6.2 Development and Production Schedule

The  production  and  development  schedule  was  completed  using  iGantt  software.  The  production schedule is based on the rate assumptions shown Table 16-11.

A delay of 28 days was used prior to driving on paste fill or mining adjacent to a paste filled stope. These delays account for curing time as well as multiple pours. A 45 day delay to install manways in ventilation raises was also assumed.

The mining operation schedule is based on 365 days/year, 7 days/week, with two 12 hour shifts each day.  A  production  rate  of  2,760 t/d  was  targeted  with  ramp-up  to  full  production  as  quickly  as possible.  The  schedule  timeframe  is  monthly  for  the  pre-production  period  and  for  two  years  or production, then quarterly for three years, and annually for the remainder of the mine life.

Shaft sinking activities begin in May, 2019 with mine development occurring from the end of 2019 through 2020. Stoping begins late in 2020, with a ramp up period through Q1 - 2021, after which the mine and plant are operating at full capacity.

## 16.7  Mining Operations

## 16.7.1 Stoping

Stopes will be mined using the longhole open stoping method. Individual stope blocks are designed to be 15 m wide, up to 30 m long, and will have a transverse orientation. Levels are spaced 25 m apart and each stope block will have a top and bottom access (4.5 m x 4.5 m flat back drifts).

Stopes will be drilled downward from the top access using 114 mm diameter holes (stope slots will be drilled with a DTH drill and stope production rings will be drilled with a tophammer drill). A bottom up,  primary/secondary extraction sequence will be followed. Primary stopes will be backfilled with

high  strength  paste  backfill  and  secondary  stopes  will  be  backfilled  with  RoM  waste  from  the underground operation and low strength paste backfill as needed when waste rock is not available.

Stope extraction will occur in two steps. During the first step, a slot will be mined at the far end the stope using a drop raise and 28 fan-drilled slash holes. The slot is required to create sufficient void space for the remainder of the stope to be blasted. During the second step, production rings will be blasted  three  rows  at  a  time  (13  blastholes  per  ring)  until  the  stope  is  completely  extracted.  The number of three-row blasts in a given stope will depend on the length of the stope. All blasting will be performed with bulk emulsion.

Ore will be remotely mucked from the bottom stope access using a 6.2 m 3  (14 t) LHD. The LHD will transport  the  ore  to  a  remuck  bay  to  maximize  the  efficiency  of  the  stope  mucking  operations.  A second LHD and a fleet of 40 t haul trucks will be used to transport ore from the remuck bays to the grizzly feeding the underground material handling system. Multiple remuck bays will be used on each level to avoid interference between the stope loader and the haul trucks.

## 16.7.2 Material Handling System

The underground material handling system is designed to size the rock, provide surge and storage capacity, and be an efficient, automated system for moving the rock from bin to loading pocket to surface via the hoisting plant.

During operations, ore will be brought to the dump point and fed via a rock-breaker protected grizzly into an infeed orepass that loads into the crusher station. A hydrostroke feeder will load a vibratory grizzly which will separate fine and coarse sections and feed the coarse (oversize) material into a jaw crusher. Undersize will be fed via chute to the main transfer conveyor and on to the ore bin.

The  jaw  crusher  will  feed  the  sized  material  via  the  same  conveyor  to  the  ore  bin  which  has  a capacity of 2,500 t, representing approximately one day's production through the mill.

Waste is fed directly, during the pre-production period only, from the dump point into the waste bin, which  also  has  a  2,500 t  capacity,  or  approximately  two  days  waste  requirement  at  maximum development needs. During production, ore will also be fed into the second 2,500 t bin as all waste will be disposed of underground. The two bins will provide slightly less than 2 days processing plant production.

The  bins  are  designed  at  10  m  diameter  from  top  to  bottom,  for  both  ease  of  construction  and maintenance. The bin bottom will be a structural steel platform that can be removed for maintenance in major outages.

The  rock  from  the  loading  pocket  (LP)  conveyor  loads  a  two-flask  loading  pocket,  which  is weightometer measured and controlled via a PLC/PC interface. Control monitoring around the facility will use CCTV cameras located at strategic points, with load sensors, bearing and motor monitors, etc.  Rock breakers will be remotely operated by the hoist operators via joystick and camera. The entire system will be monitored by the hoisting personnel.

Loaded skips will be hoisted to the surface and dumped into a chute with a flop gate that will direct the rock to either a rock bunker (to be placed on the temporary rock storage area) or to a surge bin. The surge bin  has  an  apron  feeder  that  feeds  a  conveyor  to  the  crushed  ore  storage  bin,  which subsequently moves via another feeder onto the conveyor to the mill.

Material in the rock bunker will be transported by loader (or loader and truck) to the temporary lined rock storage area.

## 16.7.3 Development

Lateral development includes interlevel ramps, level accesses, stope accesses, and short connecting drifts for ventilation. The interlevel ramp system will be a (5.5 m wide by 5.5 m high with an arched back) at a maximum 14% gradient. Level accesses will be 5.0 m wide by 5.5 m high with an arched back and will be mined higher at the remuck bays to allow the haul trucks to be loaded by the LHD. Stope access drifts will be flat back 4.5 m wide by 4.5 m high. The short connecting drifts for escapeways will be 3.5 m wide by 3.5 m high with a flat back.

Interlevel ramps and levels accesses will be located in the footwall and have been designed to avoid crossing fault zones to the maximum extent possible. Stope accesses are oriented perpendicular to the strike of the orebody.

The  lateral  development  is  sized  for  the  operation  of  the  mining  equipment  fleet  that  has  been selected for the operation. The development profiles include allowances for ventilation ducting and services.

Conventional  drop  raising  will  be  used  to  establish  ventilation  connections  between  level  access drifts.

## 16.7.4 Backfilling

The mine production sequence includes the use of cemented paste backfill to fill the voids left by the stopes to maintain the mine structural integrity. As discussed in Section 16.3.2, the mine utilizes a high strength backfill paste that has a 5% cement content in the primary stopes. A lower strength paste with 2% cement is used to supplement waste rock, whenever waste rock is not available, to backfill  the  secondary  stopes.  Section 18.12 discusses the surface plant and system to move the pastefill underground to the stopes. A backfill operations crew installs barricades in the lower access drift  to  the  stopes, extends the pipe delivery system in the upper access drift into the stopes, and monitors the backfill as the stope fills. Once the stope is filled the backfill is allowed to cure (28 days) to design strength of over 1 MPa prior to blasting on the adjoining stope.

## 16.7.5 Ground Support

The  current  knowledge  of  the  geotechnical  characteristics  indicate  that  ground  support  will  be required  in  the  ramps  and  primary  access  drifts  as  well  as  the  shaft  and  shop  areas.  The  stope access drifts will require minimum ground support except at brows of the stopes. The ground support plan  includes  use  of  grouted  rebar  and  split  set  style  bolts  as  a  standard.  The  bolting  will  be supplemented with wire mesh, shotcrete, and additional support where required. The plan includes allowances for areas of full shotcrete, but it is not expected to be required in normal operations, just in  areas  encountering faulted or challenging ground conditions. A bolter will be utilized as normal practice and shotcrete equipment are included in the estimate. Additionally, a cable bolter has been included in the equipment fleet to allow for cable bolting if necessary in intersections and at the stope brows. The geotechnical information currently does not indicate this is required, however the cable bolter can also be used to provide additional ground support capacity if needed.

Table 16-14 in Section 16.6.1 shows a simplified operational ground support plan.

## 16.7.6 Grade Control

As part of the routine mining sequence, NioCorp will be infill drilling and will execute a grade control program to monitor the mining production. The infill drilling will be conducted from established drilling stations on each level, with underground diamond drilling using NQ core diameter drilled across the width of the known mineralization. Drilling will be logged for basic parameters and sampled using the current established protocols by NioCorp. SRK envisions up to three holes in a fan pattern can be drilled from each station to gain knowledge for levels above and below as required.

The aim of the grade control program is to deliver the most economic tonnes to the mill via accurate definition of 'ore' and waste. The basis of a successful program in an underground environment will be  completed  via  detailed  geological  mapping  and  grade  sampling  ahead  of  the  mining.  Grade control strategy is related to mining method and orebody type. For underground operations sampling methods include chip, channel and panel samples, grab/muck pile samples, and drill-based samples.

The aim of the program will be to identify variations in dip, strike and width, impact on local scale from  faulting  effects,  and  grade  continuity/  type.  Variations  in  geometry  at  the  edge  of  the mineralization will require geological understanding to ensure optimum grade, minimal dilution and maximum mining recovery.

The current proposed mining methods involve development cross-cuts at regular intervals across the width of the mineralization at the top and bottom of a stope prior to mining. Samples should be taken across the full width of the exposed mineralization with sufficient volume to ensure accurate assay.

The aim of the sampling should be to achieve a sample weight the equivalent of at minimum half NQ core for the sampling interval. The samples should be logged geologically marking the width of the mineralization and any hanging wall or footwall mineralization. The samples should be processed at an onsite facility to enable quick turnaround.

Additionally, blasted material will be available for grab sampling to test grades, which should then be input to a production database and be used to confirm head-grades and for reconciliation purposes. Note  that  grab  sampling  can  result  in  selection  bias  if  not  conducted  following  a  routine  defined protocol.

The mine geologist will perform daily mapping, as well as define the ore/waste contact for the mining teams. The mapping should be incorporated into a digital format to further improve the geological model and enable the development of short term estimation.

SRK recommends that NioCorp create a series of protocols to cover all grade control tasks from mapping to sampling and integration with the database. On-going quality assurance/quality control monitoring and review will allow protocols and staff to be updated as required.

## 16.8  Ventilation

Ventilation modeling work was completed based on the mine design/production schedule described in Sections 16.3 and 16.6. The intake shaft is 7.5 m diameter finished and the exhaust raise (return shaft) is 5.5 m diameter.

## 16.8.1 Airflow Requirements

The  airflow  requirements  were  based  on  vehicle  motor  power  (kW).  A  factor  of  0.08 m /s/kW  of 3 engine  power  was  used  to  ensure  safe  working  conditions  in  areas  with  diesel  equipment.  An additional  65 m 3 /s  of  airflow  is  required  to  provide  shops,  crusher,  and  shaft  bottom  areas  with perceptible movement of air. Minimum airflow requirements were estimated by block based on the equipment list. The minimum airflow required is 420 m 3 /s for block 3, at full production. Additional airflow will be needed to account for leakage and maintain perceptible movement of air in working areas.

Air  velocity  limitations  vary  according  to  airway  type.  In  areas  such  as  return  airways  and  shafts where personnel are not expected to work, higher velocities are acceptable. Typical airflow velocities for various airway types are shown in Table 16-29. The minimum recommended air velocity for an area with workers in a drift is 0.3 m/s, to provide perceptible movement.

## 16.8.2 Ventilation Controls

## Fixed Facilities Controls

The  suggested  controls  for  the  shaft  bottom  area  are  shown  in  Figure  16-28.  Air  from  the  fixed facilities flows directly to the return (so that in the event of a fire fumes can be exhausted from the mine and not contaminate the mine workings). Potentially contaminated air from vehicles, shops and fuel  bays also exhausts directly from the mine Fire doors are included in any fuel bay or shop to prevent the spread of fumes in the event of a fire. Interlocked equipment doors are used to isolate the shaft to prevent dusty air from the shaft area to enter the mine. The connection from the shaft area to the ramp system will need air locking vehicle doors to regulate the airflow allowed into the ramp system.

<!-- image -->

Source: SRK, 2017

## Level Ventilation Controls

Air enters the level from the intake raise system and is regulated onto the level. Airflows across the level and portions of the air are picked up and used in each production stope via auxiliary ventilation. The air from the stope exhausts back to the main level. A small portion of air also flows in from the ramp. This system allows mining on other levels in the mine while blast fumes may still be present on the most recently blasted level. The air is then regulated into the return raise system. Air into the escape raises may need to be regulated to prevent excessive air velocities.

Temporary  bulkheads  need  to  be  constructed  when  stopes  are  open  between  levels  to  maintain control of the ventilation system. These temporary bulkheads can be a simple curtain type bulkhead made from brattice material.

When mining of the level is completed the regulators will be bulkheaded off, removing the level from the ventilation circuit.

<!-- image -->

Source: SRK, 2017

## 16.8.3 Ventilation Model

Ventsim  Visual  was  used  to  generate  the  ventilation  model  using  resistance  factors  from  similar operations. Air from the surface is forced into the intake plenum at the top of the service shaft. When temperatures are below 4°C the intake air will be heated. The LoM ventilation plan is to supply all of the mine air through the production shaft. A portion of this air is used to supply air to the shaft bottom area to the shops, crusher dumps, crusher, and belt transfers. This air is then transferred directly to the exhaust shaft. Air is also supplied to the ramp to control the direction of airflow on the levels. The majority of air exits the shaft via a ventilation transfer drift and into the intake raise system. Fresh air is then fed to the working levels. Additional air is supplied to each level from the ramp. On the level, the air is distributed to the production faces using auxiliary fans. At the end of each level, the air is exhausted via the return raise system. This return raise system is driven by main return fans on the ventilation  transfer  level  where  the  air  is  exhausted  out  of  the  mine  via  the  return  shaft.  Staged ventilation models were generated for each block of mining.

## 16.8.4 Climatic Modeling

A  climatic  study  was  completed  to  estimate  temperatures  throughout  the  mine  to  ensure  safe working conditions. A wet bulb temperature of 28.0°C was used as the design limit for acclimated workers in areas where personnel will be active. Using the provided weather data from the Project site,  the  barometric  pressure,  relative  humidity,  and  wet  bulb  temperature  at  the  75 th percentile highest dry bulb temperature was determined from weather data. This information was used as the surface  psychrometric  data  for  climatic  modeling.  The  weather  conditions  used  in  the  study  are displayed in Table 16-32.

Table 16-32: Data Determined at the 75 th  Percentile Highest Dry Bulb Temperature

|   Dry Bulb Temperature  (°C) |   Wet Bulb Temperature  (°C) |   Relative Humidity  (%) |   Barometric Pressure  (kPa) |
|------------------------------|------------------------------|--------------------------|------------------------------|
|                           28 |                         23.7 |                       70 |                       102.07 |

Source: SRK, 2017

The  CLIMSIM  program  requires  certain  thermal  properties  for  the  surrounding  rock  mass  to  be established.  A  value  of  32.3  ºC  was  used  as  a  basic  rock  temperature  based  on  drillhole measurements.

The results show that the while temperatures are anticipated to be warm in the mine, the wet bulb temperature is not expected to exceed the practical design limit of 28ºC in the main ventilation areas, however in lower velocity areas ventilated using auxiliary ventilation more airflow may be needed. A single loader in a heading has a minimum airflow requirement of 19.4 m 3 /s of airflow resulting in a velocity too low in the drift to carry heat away fast enough to meet the design limit. Approximately 20% more air  is  necessary  for  head  dissipation  beyond  that  required  for  diesel  exhaust  dilution. Therefore, the minimum airflow in an auxiliary ventilated drift is 23.3 m /s. 3

## 16.8.6 Recommended Ventilation Infrastructure

## Sensors

Several different types of sensors are recommended to be installed at the mine. These sensors can help predict wear on the fans, alarm in the event of a fire and can tie into the ventilation modeling software.  Listed  in  this  section  are  some  of  the  recommended  sensors  for  the  mine.  Bundled  air quality and quantity sensors are recommended for each fan installation, intake shaft, fixed facilities and each working level. These include fan monitoring, air  quality,  air  quantity,  and  psychrometric sensors.

## Regulators

Drop board regulators consist of large wooden or steel boards which are slotted from the ground up. More boards in place result in a smaller air opening and consequent generation of a higher airway resistance.  This  can  also  form  the  frame  for  a  bulkhead.  Drop  board  type  of  regulators  are recommended to be placed at the intake and exhaust of each level.

Slide  regulators  are  typically  a  piece  of  steel  on  a  slider  that  can  be  adjusted  manually  to increase/decrease the area of an opening in a door or a regulator. These types of regulators are recommended for use where equipment doors require a regulator.

## Bulkheads

For  the  purposes  of  this  study  shotcrete  bulkheads  were  assumed  to  be  constructed.  These bulkheads should have steel man doors placed in them for the purposes of escape and inspection of the raises.

Upper sill levels of a stope may require temporary bulkheads in relatively low pressure situations. These bulkheads can be constructed with fabric or flexible material.

## Equipment Doors

Equipment doors allow passage of personnel, vehicles and materials and prevent air pulsing and short circuiting of air. Air locking doors will be near the main fan installations and shaft bottom area.

## Equipment Doors

Equipment doors allow passage of personnel, vehicles and materials and prevent air pulsing and short circuiting of air. Air locking doors will be near the main fan installations and in to the ventilation drive.

## Air Heaters

Bulk air heaters are required at the surface intake shaft. Low pressure high-quantity fans will also be needed for the air heaters. These fans produce just enough pressure to overcome the losses from the heater, fan, and plenum so that there is a slight positive pressure on the headframe.

## 16.8.8 Air Heating

If the outside air temperature drops below 0°C ice can build up along the walls intake airways and shafts and on the fittings of utilities, causing increased resistance to airflow and posing a hazard to personnel and equipment working in or around the intake. Repetitive freeze-thaw cycles can result in severe damage to the integrity of the ground support in airways and shafts.

Based on the weather data shown in Table 16-36, heating is required for five months out of the year.

Table 16-36: Surface Temperatures near the Elk Creek Mine

|                       |   Jan |    Feb |   Mar |   Nov |   Dec |
|-----------------------|-------|--------|-------|-------|-------|
| Temperature (Celsius) | -8.3  | -11    | -5.6  | -4.4  | -3.8  |
| RH (%)                | 91    |  88    | 71    | 89    | 75    |
| Density (kg/m 3 )     |  1.23 |   1.27 |  1.22 |  1.23 |  1.25 |

Source: SRK, 2017

A heater size of 17.2 MW is required assuming a maximum ventilation scenario with 483 m 3 /s of air to be heated from -23°C to +4°C. Natural gas will be the fuel for the heaters. The combustion of the gas  produces  small  amounts  of  carbon  dioxide,  water  vapor,  and,  in  poorly  maintained  heaters, carbon monoxide. The possibility of creating carbon monoxide means that a gas monitor should be installed downstream of the heater with an alarm and automatic fuel cut-off. A temperature sensor should  also  be  placed  at  an  appropriate  distance  downstream  of  the  heater  to  obtain  accurate readings in fully mixed air.
