## 18.5.3 Fire Water

The fire  water  system will  consist  of  two  redundant  fire  water  tanks,  fire  water  pumps  capable  of delivering 2,000 gpm for a period of 4-hrs with emergency power back-up, the fire water distribution system, as well as on-site hydrants.

All  infrastructure  facilities,  except  for  the  Gate  House,  will  include  wet  sprinkler  systems.  Process buildings  will  include  wet  sprinkler  systems  in  all  office  spaces  and  control  rooms.  Dry  sprinkler systems  are  required  in  Hydrometallurgical  buildings  within  specified  high  hazard  areas.  The remaining open process/factory areas of these two process facilities, as well as the open areas of the  Mineral  Processing  building  will  utilize  fire  hose  protection  from  outside  hydrants,  as  well  as interior located fire hose reels.

## 18.5.4 Potable Water

Potable water will be supplied from the Water Treatment plant at an operational flow rate of 300 gpm to  dedicated  potable  water  tankage.  Potable  water  will  be  distributed  to  all  site  facilities  via  a dedicated pumping system at 50 psig pressure. The nominal flow rate will be 100 gpm for the entire facility, with a peak flow rate of 750 gpm during shower usage.

## 18.6  Auxiliary Buildings and Facilities

## Administration &amp; Service Building

The Administration Building will consist of modular units or a long term leased building that will house offices for support staff and site management.

## Maintenance Shop

The  Maintenance  Shop  and  the  Warehouse  will  both  be  located  in  a  single-story,  steel-framed structure, 301 ft x 61 ft located centrally within the site. The Maintenance shop will include a wash bay and a Maintenance Shop area.

The Warehouse section will be 140 ft x 61 ft. The Warehouse will be the primary hub for receiving all parts and materials for the mine and processing facilities, and shipping of all products.

## Process Plant and Maintenance Modular Offices

Additional office space for processing area and maintenance personnel will be provided in modular units located in the vicinity of the Hydrometallurgical Building.

## Mine Change House

A single-story Mine Change House Building will be built near the Mine access. The Change House will  include  locker  room  and  shower  facilities  for  personnel  working  in  the  Mine  and  in  the  ore processing areas and other surface facilities. Building dimensions will be 200 ft x 81 ft.

## Assay Laboratory

The Process Analysis Laboratory will be housed in a single story, steel-framed building located near the main processing facilities with dimensions of 81 ft x 49 ft.

## Gate House

A Gate House, a lease portable building of 30 ft x 16 ft will be located at the main site access point. The Gate House will host the security personnel controlling access into the site.

## Site Drainage

Storm  water  will  be  collected  on  site  by  a  storm  water  collection  system  that  will  consist  of  a combination  of  buried  HDPE  pipe  and  surface  swales  and  ditches.  Surface  water  from  disturbed areas will be collected in a storm water retention basin prior to its release into the local stream.

Storm water that is  collected  from  areas  of  potential  contamination  from  hazardous  material  from process areas will be collected separately from other surface water sources and analyzed prior to discharge to the storm water collection system. The fuel island, as well as the retention pond pipe inlet  will  include  oily  water  separators  to  ensure  any  petroleum  that  is  in  surface  water  is  not discharged to local waters and is collected for off-site disposal.

## Sanitary Waste Water System

Sanitary waste water will be transported from the on-site holding tanks to the municipal waste water treatment plant located in Tecumseh.

Waste water from all site facilities will be collected in the on-site sanitary waste water system through an underground PVC SR35 sewer piping network combining manholes and sewage lift stations. The system is designed for a peak flow rate of 750 gpm during peak shower usage and 27,300 gpd daily nominal volume.

## First Aid Facilities

The Administration building, as well as the Mine Change building, will each have a first aid station for treatable  on-site  injuries.  There  will  be  an  on-site  emergency  mine  rescue  vehicle  and  a  rescue trailer. A helicopter pad will be located within the site property for evacuation of personnel.

## Laydown Area / Cold Storage

During normal operation of the mine and processing facilities there will be minimal need for laydown areas or additional, covered or enclosed storage. The spacing between buildings has been chosen to provide adequate clearances for construction, and space for staging equipment and replacement parts for maintenance and plant turnarounds.

## Reagent Storage

Reagents will be used in the Hydromet, Pyromet, Acid Plant, HCl Regeneration Plant and the Paste Backfill Plant. Liquid reagents will be stored in the reagent or raw material tank farm located west of the  Hydromet  Plant.  The  tank  farm  will  include  truck  unloading  stations  and  transfer  pumps  to transfer reagent to their required process. All tanks of specific reagents will be isolated from other reagents and located within their own diked containment areas.

Process facilities will also store reagent tanks, bunkers, bins and silos. Additional plant reagents will be stored in the process buildings.

## Products Storage, Packaging, Shipping

Packaging of the three main products will take place at the outlet of the respective final processing equipment, as a continuation of the process flow.

The anticipated production rates of ferroniobium and titanium dioxide will warrant multiple shipments per week of each product if shipped via over-the-road vehicles. The anticipated production rate of scandium  will  yield  much  smaller  volumes.  Frequency  of  shipments  of  scandium  will  be  less

frequent, justifying transfer of the containers to a designated storage area inside the Maintenance / Warehouse Building until shipment.

The types and locations of loading and unloading facilities will be specific to the material or products being received and shipped.

## RCRA Waste Storage

This storage area will include a concrete diked containment area for the storage of wastes, including any hazardous wastes generated at the facility prior to offsite disposal.

## Truck Scale

A truck scale will be located near the primary site access.

## Fuel Storage - Surface Fuel Station

Fueling facility for surface vehicles will be provided.

## 18.7  Roads

## 18.7.1 Main Access Road to Site

The primary access to the site will be from County Road 721. Access into the site will be controlled by security personnel. The site access road will be leading to the main access points to the mine, the Administration Building and the primary traffic destinations on the site.

## 18.7.2 Secondary Site Access Roads

A  second,  emergency  access  to  the  site  will  be  connecting  to  Nebraska  State  Route  50.  The entrance to the emergency access road will be secured with a locked gate.

## 18.7.3 Secondary Site Roads (to tailings, etc.)

Secondary roads on site include haul roads connecting the Plant Site to TSF cells and light vehicle access roads connecting infrastructure throughout the site. Haul traffic is expected to include 40 t haul trucks delivering tailings to the active TSF cells and support equipment for the haul fleet. Light vehicles include light duty pickups and service vehicles supporting infrastructure.

## Haul Roads

Haul roads are required to provide access between the Plant Site and TSF Cells. A haul road will provide  access  to  Plant  Site  Cells  2  and  3,  as  well  as  Area  7.  Area  7  haul  road  will  require  a connection between a public road and the TSF area. Improvements to the public roadway may be required pending haul fleet size delivering tailings to Area 7. Highway compliant tractor-trailer trucks may be used instead of off-road trucks.

Haul roads are designed to allow trucks to pass safely. The haul trucks assumed for this study are 40 t  articulated  off-road  trucks.  The  width  of  a  truck  is  approximately  4  m  wide.  To  provide  safe passage for two-way traffic, the suggested width of the travel way (driving surface) is 3.5 times the width of the truck, or 14 m. Haul roads are shown with a width of 20 m, allowing for up to 6 m for safety berms. The road widths and berm placement will be determined during the final engineering design. Much of the roadway may not require a safety berm due to height, but a running width of 20 m is used for estimating and preliminary design purposes.

Haul  traffic  speed  is  generally  slow,  (30  to  40  km/h);  the  design  shown  does  not  incorporate engineering  controls  for  a  design  speed,  and  are  shown  for  estimating  and  preliminary  design purposes only.

## Light Vehicle Access Roads

Light vehicle access roads are located throughout the site. They provide access to dewatering well pads, and infrastructure such as ponds, embankment crest and toe fills.

Expected traffic on light duty roads includes light duty pickup trucks, maintenance equipment, and the occasional haul truck. Light vehicle roads assume occasional use, single lane traffic with areas to safely pull out of the traffic lane should vehicles meet. A typical light duty vehicle is approximately 3 m wide. Road widths are designed at 6 m in width.

Speeds are expected to be slow (20 to 30 km/h); the design shown does not incorporate engineering controls for a design speed, and are shown for estimating and preliminary design purposes only.

## Construction

Geotechnical  information  for  soils  underlying  road  alignments  is  not  available  at  this  time.  The construction  of  the  roadways  assumes  similar  construction  practices  as  defined  for  the  TSF embankment construction. Remove 1 m (+/-) of topsoil, replace with suitable compacted sub-grade fill, and  provide  structural  support  for  traffic  with  a  durable  gravel  surface.  Geotextile  fabric  is installed at the base of the gravel layer to provide stability. A minimum of 0.5 m of compacted gravel should be provided for the driving surface.

All roadways will be designed to promote drainage off of the driving surface. This requires that the roadways  be  elevated  slightly  above  the  surrounding  ground  elevations  and  crowned,  and/or  a drainage ditch be provided as needed in areas of elevation transition from cut to fill. In areas where berms are required, notches in the berms should be provided to allow stormwater to discharge off of the roadways. In areas where safety berms are not required, shoulder slopes should not exceed 3:1 (horizontal to vertical), and 4:1 desired to reduce the chance of a vehicle rollover should they divert from the roadway.

## 18.8  Temporary Waste Rock Stockpile

The temporary waste rock stockpile will be used during the sinking of the shaft for storage of topsoil, waste rock and ore. The feasibility design incorporates the following parameters and details:

- a. The facility has been divided into three cells (Figure 18-3) to enable waste materials to be stockpiled separately.
- b. A minimum of 1 m of subbase soils will be removed prior to construction of the TSF and stockpiled at the location shown on Figure 18-3.
- c. Based on the current geochemical analysis of the waste rock and ore the temporary waste rock stockpile will be lined. The liner systems for the facility is shown on Figure 18-10 and will incorporate:
- o A  minimum  of  2  ft  of  glacial  till,  amended  as  necessary  with  bentonite,  and compacted  in  layers  to  result  in  a  hydraulic  conductivity  of  less  than  or  equal  to 1x10-7cm/s;
- o An 80-mil high-density polyethylene (HDPE) geosynthetic liner placed over the low permeability basin and inside embankment sideslopes; and

- d. Runoff  from  the  stockpile  will  gravity  drain  into  a  water  management  pond  located  to  the south of the facility (Figure 18-3). The water management pond liner system will incorporate:
- o A  minimum  of  2 ft  of  glacial  till,  amended  as  necessary  with  bentonite,  and compacted  in  layers  to  result  in  a  hydraulic  conductivity  of  less  than  or  equal  to 1x10-7cm/s;
- o A 60-mil HDPE secondary liner incorporating a DrainLiner system or Geonet layer above the geosynthetic liner;
- o An 80-mil high-density polyethylene (HDPE) primary liner;

The DrainLiner or Geonet layers will gravitate into a leak collection and recovery system (LCRS) that facilitates pumping of collected seepage water back into the water management pond via a submersible pump and riser pipeline arrangement. As shown on Figure 18-13, the riser pipeline will be contained in a 'port' pipeline installed between the two liners. The LCRS sumps are gravel-filled facilities between the primary and secondary liners,  with  the  horizontal  base  of  the  riser  pipe  perforated  within  the  gravel  for  leakage collection and recovery.

- e. Once the plant is operational the ore will  be  removed  and  processed.  Waste rock will  be used as overliner during TSF construction and any additional will be placed in Plant Site Cell 1 for final disposal.
- f. It  is  currently anticipated that all waste material will be removed from the temporary waste rock stockpile by Year 2.

<!-- image -->

Source: SRK, 2017

## 18.9  Water Management

## 18.9.1 Surface Water Management for TSF and Temporary Stockpile Areas

The Project is located primarily in the Elk Creek Watershed, near its confluence with Todd Creek. Todd  Creek  is  a  tributary  of  North  Fork  Big  Nemaha  River  which  becomes  Big  Nemaha  River approximately 30 miles downstream  and  joins the Missouri River approximately 45 miles downstream.

The  TSF  and  associated  ponds  will  all  be  located  outside  and  above  the  limits  of  the  FEMA approximate Zone A flood zone (Figure 18-4).

Figure 18-4: TSF and Stockpile Area Stormwater Controls

<!-- image -->

Hydrologic and hydraulic analyses were performed to evaluate stormwater control requirements for the  Elk  Creek  TSF  and  supporting  facilities.  In  general,  the  TSF  facilities  are  located  in  the uppermost  reaches  of  small  catchments  in  the  Elk  Creek  watershed  and  therefore  only  local diversion of small upstream flows (run-on) around facilities is required.

Stormwater  control  designs  include  spillways  on  the  TSF  cell  and  water  management  pond embankments, and channels on the embankment crests for management of storm runoff from the closed and re-graded surfaces. External stormwater controls include triangular channels (v-ditches) and sediment traps located at the toe of embankments for sediment and erosion control, and culverts to pass flows in drainages through access road crossings (Figure 18-4).

All  TSF cell and pond spillways are configured as a 0.5 m deep by 3 m wide trapezoidal channel (notch) with 10:1 sideslopes, oriented perpendicular to the embankment crest and can pass the PMF storm  event;  a  channel  (down-chute)  lined  with  riprap  (or  HydroTurf)  will  convey  flows  down embankments and into stilling basins. All other stormwater controls are design to withstand the peak flow rate from the 100-year, 24-hour storm event.

Peak flow rates for spillway, culvert and closure channel sizing were determined utilizing HEC-HMS version  4.2  (HEC-HMS),  released  by  the  US  Army  Corps  of  Engineers,  Hydrologic  Engineering Center (USACE 2016). The Rational Method was used to evaluate peak flow rates and channel (vditch)  sizing  for  the  embankment  toe  channels.  Hydraulic  calculations  were  performed  in  Bentley FlowMaster version 8i (Bentley 2009), and HY-8 version 7.5 (HY-8) released by the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA 2016).

Rainfall  data  used  in  the  hydrologic  analyses  was  obtained  from  the  National  Oceanic  and Atmospheric  Administration  (NOAA),  Precipitation  Frequency  Data  Server  (PFDS)  which  for  the State  of  Nebraska  utilizes  NOAA  Atlas  14,  Volume  8  Version  2  (NOAA  2013)  (Table  18-4).  The probable maximum precipitation (PMP) storm depth of 21 inches (533 mm) was obtained from the document  Nebraska  Statewide  Probable  Maximum  Precipitation  Study  (Tomlinson  et.  al,  2008), recommended for use in Nebraska by Nebraska Department of Natural Resources.

Table 18-4: 24-Hour Precipitation Depth-Frequency Data for Elk Creek Project

| 24-Hour Storm Event                         | 24-Hour Storm Event                         | 24-Hour Storm Event                         |
|---------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------|
| Frequency                                   | Depth (inches)                              | Depth (mm)                                  |

## 18.9.2 Active Dewatering System

Active dewatering from the surface will be utilized in advance of development of the mine and will continue  to  be  utilized  throughout  the  mine  life.  The  active  dewatering  system  will  consist  of  a network of approximately 12 perimeter wells, equally spaced around the deposit. The wells will be drilled  to  a  depth  of  850  mbgs.  The  wells  will  be  16  inches  in  diameter  and  will  be  capable  of pumping approximately 65 L/sec (1,000 gpm) each. The wells must be installed and operational one year in advance of the shaft completion date, so that the shaft can be suitably dewatered. Three additional  wells  will  be  drilled  to  provide  dewatering  capacity  when  primary  wells  and  pumps  are being  serviced.  The  three  additional  wells  will  also  allow  a  higher  maximum  flow  rate  for  short periods of time when needed.

Wells will require a nominal 16 inch outside diameter casing and screen to accommodate a 16-stage, nominal 9.5 inch diameter, 670 kW (900 HP), submersible pump with a shroud. The final design of the wells will depend on the prototype wells and how they function,

Water from each well will be piped to a collection pond. The water will then be pumped via a mine dewatering  discharge  waterline  to  the  Missouri  River.  The  total  average  anticipated  input  to  the collection pond during the first 5 years will be 757 L/sec, after which time flow rates are expected to gradually decline through the LoM.

## 18.9.3 Active Dewatering Pond

The active dewatering pond has been designed as a collection and transfer pond for all mine water and any suitable process water prior to discharge to the Missouri River (Figure 18-5). In addition, water from the active dewatering pond will be used as a source of make-up water for the plant. The feasibility design incorporates the following parameters and details:

- a. Feasibility design has been performed using 1 m contoured topography.
- b. The active dewatering pond embankment sections will incorporate a 20 m crest width and 3 (horizontal) to 1  (vertical) side  slopes.  Revegetation  of  the  embankment  crests  and downstream sideslopes will be provided for erosion protection, immediately after construction completion of each embankment.
- c. The active dewatering pond will cover approximately 5.4 ha with a crest elevation of 372.5 masl  and  a  base  elevation  of  362.5  masl.  The  maximum  embankment  height  will  be approximately 11 m.
- d. Assuming 1 m of dry freeboard, the pond has a total capacity of approximately 430,000 m 3 . The pond will provide 4.5 days of emergency storage assuming a maximum dewatering rate of 950 L/sec (15,000 gpm) rate plus the 100-year, 24-hour storm.
- e. The  active  dewatering  pond  has  been  designed  with  two  cells  for  operational  water management, thus allowing water management in one cell while solids are removed from the other cells. Each cell has a capacity of approximately 50,000 m 3  or approximately 0.5 days of storage. These cells are included in the total capacity described in c, above.
- f. Foundation preparation for the embankments will incorporate removal of a minimum of 0.5 m of  native  soils,  and  re-compaction  in  layers.  The  embankments  will  then  be  constructed using  soil  borrowed  from  within  the  active  dewatering  pond  footprint,  and  compacted  in layers to form a non-settling structure.
- g. The active dewatering pond, as well as the Leak Collection and Recovery System (LCRS) sumps within the cells, will incorporate:

- · A  minimum  of  2 ft  of  glacial  till,  amended  as  necessary  with  bentonite,  and compacted  in  layers  to  result  in  a  hydraulic  conductivity  of  less  than  or  equal  to 1x10 -7 cm/s;
- · A 60-mil HDPE secondary liner incorporating a DrainLiner system or Geonet layer above the geosynthetic liner;
- · An 80-mil high-density polyethylene (HDPE) primary liner;

The DrainLiner or Geonet layers will gravitate into a LCRS sump that facilitates pumping of collected  seepage  water  back  into  the  LCPs  via  a  submersible  pump  and  riser  pipeline arrangement.

- h. In order to maintain a constant water level within the pond water will need to be pumped to the Missouri River at a rate of approximately 790 l/s (12,500gpm) assuming average monthly precipitation, an average dewatering rate of 950 l/s, and an average make-up water rate of 190 l/s.

Source: SRK, 2017

## 18.9.4 Waterline to Missouri

The  purpose  of  the  waterline  to  the  Missouri  is  to  convey  water  from  a  holding  pond  (active dewatering pond) that is filled by the mine's dewatering wells to a discharge point at the Missouri River. The dewatering system will consist of a 53 km waterline as well as booster pump stations, control valves, surge protection and a mixing diffuser structure at the Missouri River.

## Waterline to Missouri Dewatering System

## Design Criteria

- · The design criteria includes:
- o Sustained Pumping Capacity: 45.4 m³/min (12,000 gpm); and
- o Peak Pumping Capacity: 56.8 m³/min (15,000 gpm).

## Waterline Alignment

The 53 km waterline  generally  follows  County  Road  720  from  the  mine  site  continuing  east  until County Road 634 Ave where it jogs to the north 1.6 kilometers (1 mile), and then continues along County Road 721 until the Missouri River where it meanders northerly to the proposed outlet (Figure 18-6).

<!-- image -->

Source: Olsson, 2017

## Waterline

The waterline has been sized to minimize friction head loss while maintaining high enough velocities to  keep  the  pipe  clean.  The  sizing  is  based  on  a  maximum  velocity  of  2.1  m/sec  (7  ft/sec])  at 56.8 m³/min  (15,000  gpm),  and  the  velocity  in  the  waterline  will  be  approximately  1.7 m/sec  (5.5 ft/sec) at 45.4 m³/min (12,000 gpm). Due to the elevated level of chlorides in the water, high-density polyethylene  (HDPE)  pipe  was  selected  as  the  pipe  material.  The  proposed  waterline  includes 762 cm (30 inch) internal diameter (ID) HDPE standard dimension ratio (SDR) 11 pipe.

The waterline installation will include open-cut trenching as well as trenchless installation. A majority of the waterline will be installed via open-cut trenching. Waterlines installed at the river and water way crossings will be installed using horizontal directional drilling (HDD) to avoid impacts to waters of the  U.S.,  which  would  require  additional  U.S.  Army  Corps  of  Engineers  (USACE)  permitting. Waterlines installed under highways and railroads will be installed using auger boring or pipe jacking and include steel casings.

It  is  anticipated  that  construction  operations  will  have  a  major  impact  on  the  existing  gravel  road along the waterline alignment, that the road will need to be completely rebuilt, and that the vegetation along the sides of the road will  need  to  be  re-established.  This  work  will  be  coordinated  with  the Counties through which the waterline will occupy right-of-way.

NioCorp has obtained a perpetual easement for the east end of the waterline at the Missouri River and  may  need  to  acquire  additional  lands  along  the  waterline  route  for  pumping  stations  located along the route and to avoid impacting the Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) dam near U.S. Highway 75. It is assumed that the remaining portion of the waterline will primarily occupy county right-of-way.

## Automatic Air Relief Valves

To evacuate air that may accumulate in the waterline, automatic air relief valves are anticipated at high points along the waterline alignment. It has been assumed that one automatic air relief valve station (including the valve and below grade vault) will be installed at every mile along the waterline. The number of automatic air relief valves will be further evaluated once final design is authorized to proceed.

## Surge Protection within Waterline

Surge  protection  along  the  waterline  will  be  provided  and  includes  an  assumption  that  surge protection  devices  will  include  a  combination  of  pressure/surge  relief  valves,  pressurized  surge tanks, pump station bypasses, and/or surge towers. It is anticipated that one surge control device will be required between each of the booster stations for a total of four surge protection devices. The exact  number  and  type  of  surge  protection  devices  will  be  further  evaluated  through  additional hydraulic modeling once the final design is authorized to proceed.

## Booster Pump Stations

The pump station design includes a pre-packaged building with four vertical turbine pumps piped in parallel with variable frequency drives (VFD), controls, electrical panels, and support equipment. One of the pumps is designated as a back-up and the others will be utilized based upon flow conditions. The station will be pre-wired and tested prior to installation.

A  total  of  five  booster  pump  stations  are  currently  anticipated.  Two  stations  will  have  four  600 horsepower (hp) pumps at 106.68 m (350 ft) total dynamic head (TDH), two stations will have four 350 hp pumps at 61 m (200 ft) TDH, and one station will have six 200 hp pumps at 61 m (200 ft) TDH, for a total of five stations.

At 56.8 m³/min (15,000 gpm) the four pump booster stations will have three pumps operating with one  standby  pump,  and  the  six  pump  booster  station  will  have  five  pumps  operating  with  one standby pump. At 45.4 m³/min (12,000 gpm), the four pump booster stations will have a maximum of three  pumps operating at a reduced speed with one pump as standby and the six pump booster station  will  have  a  maximum  of  four  pumps  operating  with  two  pumps  as  standby.  The  pump operational plan and total number of pumps running versus number of available standby pumps will be evaluated and modified as design progresses.

The pre-packaged station, concrete footings, pump station installation, site clearing and grading, and site fencing are included in the cost for the pump stations. Additional modeling will be performed and the number of pump stations and sizing will be refined once final design is authorized to proceed with the goal of reducing the total number of pump stations required.

Permanent  electrical  service  will  be  required  at  each  of  the  four  pump  stations  along  the  pipe alignment. Generally, existing overhead power is available along the waterline route. The supply of this power will be coordinated with Omaha Public Power District (OPPD), the local power supplier, during detailed Project design.

It is anticipated that each of the pump stations will require the purchase of 0.2 hectare (0.5 acre) for locating the pump station building, backup generator, and general circulation to operate and maintain each facility. Figure 18-7 shows a typical booster station layout.

<!-- image -->

Source: Olsson, 2017

## Control Valves

It is anticipated that one control valve will be provided at each pump station. The control valve will be utilized  to  sustain  pressure,  reduce  pressure,  or  recirculate  flow.  Additional  modeling  will  further define the function of the control valve at each location.

## Backup Emergency Power

Backup emergency power will be provided at each booster pump station. It is anticipated that each generator  will  be  an  1,800  kW  diesel  generator  set,  480  volt,  3-phase  with  a  sound  attenuated weatherproof steel enclosure and a 7,570-liter (2,000-gallon) sub-base fuel tank rated for 24 hours at 100%  load.  Controls,  automatic  transfer  switch,  charging  system,  and  concrete  footings  will  be provided at each pump station. One generator set is anticipated at each station, except for the mine site pump station that will be powered by the mine site emergency power.

## Mixing Diffuser at River Discharge

A  study  has  been  performed  by  MixZon  Inc.  to  size  the  mixing  diffuser  structure  at  the  Missouri River. The diffuser structure includes a pre-fabricated diffuser assembly that will be installed within the  Missouri  River.  The  diffuser  assembly  is  to  be  of  the  submerged  multiport  configuration.  The general arrangement of the assembly is a 10 m (32.8 ft) long staged multiport diffuser. A total of six risers  are  to  be  equally  spaced  along  the  10  m  (32.8  ft)  length  with  duckbill  style  check  valves mounted on the risers and pointing offshore in a fanned design. A detailed design of the diffuser assembly  including  river  installation  design  will  be  performed  once  final  design  of  this  item  is authorized. Figure 18-1 shows the mixing diffuser. A lower cost diffuser mechanism may ultimately be utilized as detailed engineering and permitting progress.

Source: Olsson, 2017

## Design and Construction Period

## Design Period

The overall design period is anticipated to take 34 weeks or 238 days from Notice to Proceed (NTP) and is summarized as follows:

- · Preliminary Design:
- o Hydraulic  modeling  can  begin  within  1  to  2  weeks  of  NTP  and  is  expected  to  be completed within 8 weeks of initiation.
- o Remainder of preliminary design can begin in 1 week +/- of NTP and is expected to be completed within 9 weeks of initiation.
- · Survey:
- o Survey can begin in 3 weeks of NTP and is expected to be completed within 8 weeks of initiation.
- o Booster station locations need to be finalized before survey can be completed, which is tied to the hydraulic modeling.
- · Geotechnical:
- · Geotechnical soil borings can begin in 3 weeks of NTP and is expected to be completed within  4  to  5  weeks.  Laboratory  testing  is  expected  to  be  completed  within  3  weeks  of completion  of  drilling.  The  report  is  expected  to  be  completed  within  3  to  4  weeks  of completion of laboratory testing.
- o Booster  station  locations  need  to  be  finalized  before  geotechnical  borings  can  be completed, which is tied to the hydraulic modeling.
- · Final Design:
- o Final design can begin as soon as preliminary design is completed and is expected to be completed within 21 weeks.

## Procurement

Since  the  Project  will  discharge  into  the  Missouri  River  and  will  require  a  National  Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit through the Nebraska Department of Environmental Quality (NDEQ), it is anticipated that 100% designs will need to be developed and submitted to the NDEQ for approval and issuance of a construction permit. It is anticipated the Project will be bid concurrent  to  the  NDEQ  review.  Once  bids  are  received  and  the  construction  permit  is  issued, Project construction can commence.

## Construction Period

The overall construction period is anticipated to take 12 to 18 months after awarding the Project and is summarized as follows:

- · Current conversations with pump station vendors indicate that pump station fabrication and delivery could take up to 8 months. In addition, we have confirmed that we can match pumps if two vendors are considered. It is estimated that utilization of multiple vendors may result in a month of schedule reduction. However, at this time it is anticipated that construction of the pump station component of this Project will require a year including fabrication, delivery, and installation. A goal of the final design task will be to refine hydraulic analysis in an attempt to reduce the number pump stations required, which could reduce the construction schedule.

- · Pipe installation has been estimated at one year based upon multiple crews installing the trenchless portions of the Project and multiple crews installing the open cut portions of the Project. It is not advisable to consider anything less than 1 year and it is recommended to consider 15 to 18 months to account for conditions such as a harsh winter or wet spring conditions.
- · The  mixing  structure/diffuser  is  anticipated  to  require  5  months  to  fabricate  and  install. Timing of installation will need to account for lower flow conditions in the Missouri River.

## 18.10  Tailings Surface Logistics

The tailings will be transported by conveyor from the Hydromet Building to a temporary staging area, which will have concrete containment and will be sheltered by a tensioned-fabric over steel framing structure.  Slag  will  be  transported  from  the  Pyromet  Building  by  truck  or  skid  loader  to  the  same temporary staging area. The material will be transported by truck to the tailings storage facility or utilized  for  paste  backfill  by  the  surface  paste  backfill  plant,  once  the  slag  has  been  properly characterized for use in the backfill application.

## 18.11  Tailing Storage and Associated Facilities

Preliminary investigations performed by SRK included a comparison of potential TSF sites for both slurry  and  filtered  (dewatered)  tailings  disposal  options.  This  comparison  considered  potential engineering, strategic, permitting and closure issues, including:

- · Engineering:  Containment  area,  required  reclaim  for  negative  water  balance  on  tailings impoundment,  relative  embankment  heights,  distance  to  plant,  pumping  head  for  slurry (plant  to  impoundment)  and  reclaim  water  (impoundment  to  plant),  upstream  stormwater management,  major  road  crossings,  potential  residential  relocations,  and  potential  road relocations;
- · Strategic:  Proximity  to  major  roadways,  churches  and  cemeteries,  visual  embankment heights, and property ownership;
- · Permitting: Major drainage crossings and major road encroachment; and
- · Closure: Closure cover areas and volumes, seepage potential, and mass stability.

Of  eight  potential  sites,  Area  7  and  Area  1  ranked  first  and  second  for  both  slurried  and  filtered tailings.  This  evaluation  included  development  and  implementation  of  a  preliminary  foundation characterization  plan  for  both  Area  1  and  Area  7,  and  development  of  preliminary  water  balance spreadsheets for both slurried and filtered tailings options for both sites.

Following development of the 2015 PEA, the decision was made to only generate dry tailings, by calcining and filtration processes, and a more detailed foundation characterization investigation was performed for Area 7. Additional data revealed that the full stream of filtered tailings would be used for underground backfill operations, limiting the total tailings tonnage to be disposed of in the TSF to around 1,070 dry t/d for a life of 32 years (as opposed to 4,930 t/d for 30 years).

This significant decrease in deposition rate, as well as the finding that the predominantly calcined tailings  material  will  be  a  dry  'clinker',  with  a  sandy  gravel  or  gravelly  sand  gradation  (i.e.,  well drained) resulted in NioCorp's direction to SRK to evaluate the Plant Site (refer Cells 1, 2 and 3 in Figure  18-11)  as  feasible  tailings  storage  and  stormwater  management  locations  for  the  first  19 years of operations, with the following significant advantages:

- · No Elk Creek access road and conveyor crossings;
- · Shorter distance from Plant Area for tailings transport and reclaim water management;
- · Reduction in storm water management; and
- · Consolidation of disturbance into a much smaller area (than Area 7).

The Plant Area was therefore considered the best option for the first 19 years of management and storage of tailings dry  tailings  (in  three  State-approved  solid  waste  facilities),  and  management  of precipitation  contacting  the  tailings  via  runoff  and  infiltration  in  separate  double-lined  'leachate collection ponds'. Once the Plant Site cells are full, a new facility will be constructed at Area 7.

The feasibility design incorporates the following parameters and details:

- a. Topography: Feasibility design has been performed using 1 m contoured topography.
- b. Feasibility Design: Feasibility design of the TSFs is based on dam safety regulations, solid waste regulations (including tailings placement/compaction/interim covering), leachate water management regulations, and radioactive licensing regulations, all discussed in Section 20. The  design  is  intended  to  demonstrate  compliance  with  Nebraska  industrial  solid  waste Regulations  for  Design,  Operation  and  Closure  and  is  based  on  a  meeting  held  between NioCorp, SRK and Nebraska Department of Environmental Quality Solid (NDEQ).
- c. Embankment Cross-Section: All TSF and LCP embankment sections will incorporate a 20 m crest width and 3 (horizontal) to 1 (vertical) side slopes as shown in Figure 18-10 and Figure 18-12. Vegetation of the embankment crests and downstream sideslopes will be provided for erosion protection, immediately after construction completion of each embankment.
- d. Leachate Collection Ponds: Each of the three leachate collection ponds will be utilized for management of precipitation runoff and drainage from the tailings solids, and will be lined with  two  layers  of  geosynthetic  liner  (primary  and  secondary),  sandwiching  a  permeable spacer that allows evacuation of all leakage through the primary liner to be collected in a lined 'sump' area and pumped back into the Leachate Collection Pond, thereby providing a means of long-term leakage control as shown on Figure 18-13. This approach is known as a Leakage Collection and Recovery System (LCRS).
- e. Tailings  Production  Rate:  The  tailings  production  rate  is  an  average  of  2,460  dry  t/d consisting  of  825  dry  t/d  of  water  leach  residue  tailings,  1,588  dry  t/d  of  calcined  excess oxide tailings, and 46 t/d of slag. Of this, an average of 1,390 dry t/d will be placed into the mine  back  fill  (Section  18.12)  and  1,070  dry  t/d  will  be  deposited  in  the  TSF.  Testing performed  on  the  excess  and  insoluble  oxides  indicate  that  a  loose  (non-compacted)  dry density of 1.6 t/m 3 will occur, and placement and spreading of the dry tailings will increase the density to between 1.7 and 1.8 t/m 3 .
- f. Growth  Media  Salvage:  A  minimum  of  1  m  of  subbase  soils  will  be  removed  prior  to construction of the TSF and stockpiled at the locations shown on Figure 18-9, as follows:
- o For Plant Site Cell 1 the topsoil will be stockpile in the Plant Site Cell 3 footprint;
- o For  Plant  Site  Cell  2  and  Cell  3  topsoil  will  be  stockpiled  in  the  footprint  of  the Temporary Waste Rock Stockpile (which will have ended its design life and been removed to Plant Site Cell 1 as described in Section 18.8; and
- o For Area 7 Cell 1 topsoil will be stockpiled in the specified location in Area 7.
- g. TSF Area, Storage and Time Characteristics: The TSF system includes four TSF cells, Plant Site Cell 1, Cell 2 and Cell 3 and Area 7 Cell 1. Table 18-5 provides a summary of TSF cell footprint areas, storage characteristics and time periods.

The LCP system includes three ponds; one for Plant Site Cell 1 (LCP-1), one for Plant Site Cells  2  and  3  (LCP-2)  and  one  for  Area  7  Cell  1  (Area  7-LCP).  Table  18-6  provides  a summary of LCP footprint areas, and leachate and stormwater storage characteristics.

- i. Structural  Embankment  Foundation  Preparation:  Foundation  preparation  for  all  TSF  and LCP embankments will incorporate removal of a minimum of 0.5 m of native soils, and recompaction in layers to form a non-settling structure as shown on Figure 18-10 and Figure 18-12.
- j. Embankment Compaction:  All  TSF  and  LCP  embankments  will  be  constructed  using  soil borrowed from within the respective TSF basins, and compacted in layers to form a nonsettling structure as shown on Figure 18-10 and Figure 18-12.
- k. Embankment  Raises:  All  tailings  embankments  will  be  constructed  to  completion  before each cell is commissioned as shown in Table 18-7, thereby eliminating the need for raising, extension of the TSF liner and embankment drainage elements at any stage. This assists in preventing the facility from being affected by potential liquefaction of the tailings solids under seismic loads.
- l. TSF Liner and Above-Liner Drainage System: The components of the facility liner/drainage systems are described below and shown in Figure 18-10 through Figure 18-13
- i. The TSF basins and inside embankment sideslopes will incorporate:
- (1)  A minimum of 2 ft of glacial till, amended as necessary with bentonite, and compacted in layers to result in a hydraulic conductivity of less than or equal to 1x10 -7 cm/s;
- (2)  An 80-mil high-density polyethylene (HDPE) geosynthetic liner placed over the low-permeability basin and inside embankment sideslopes; and
- (3)  For  Plant  Site  Cell  1,  an  above-liner  centralized  drain  (i.e.,  from  north  to south) directing drain flows into an above-liner, double-lined, leak-detected sump that facilitates pumping into LCP 1.

- (4)  For Plant Site Cells 2 and 3 and Area 7 Cell 1, above-liner embankment toe drains  (along  entire  inside  perimeter),  as  well  as  respective  centralized drains, that gravitate drain flows into above-liner, double-lined, leak-detected sumps that facilitates pumping into LCP 2 and Area 7 LCP, respectively.
- (5)  Typical drain sections are provided on Figure 18-11 for the centralized drain (Plant Site Cells 1, 2 and 3), and the perimeter inside toe drains (Plant Site Cells 2 and 3 and Area 7 Cell 1).
- ii. Lining for LCP Basins and Inside Sideslopes: LCP basins and inside embankment sideslopes, as well as the leak collection and recovery system (LCRS) sumps within the TSF cells, will incorporate:
-  A minimum of 2 ft of glacial till, amended as necessary with bentonite, and compacted in layers to result in a hydraulic conductivity of less than or equal to 1x10 -7 cm/s;
-  A 60-mil HDPE secondary liner incorporating a DrainLiner system or Geonet layer above the geosynthetic liner;
-  An 80-mil high-density polyethylene (HDPE) primary liner;
- The DrainLiner or Geonet layers will gravitate into a LCRS sump that facilitates pumping of  collected  seepage  water  back  into  the  LCPs  via  a  submersible  pump  and  riser pipeline arrangement. As shown on Figure 18-13, the riser pipeline will be contained in a 'port'  pipeline  installed  between  the  two  liners.  The  LCRS  sumps  are  gravel-filled facilities between the primary and secondary liners, with the horizontal base of the riser pipe perforated within the gravel for leakage collection and recovery.
- m.  Tailings  Solids  Transportation  and  Deposition:  A  cost  tradeoff  study  was  performed  to compare trucking to conveying costs, and trucking is the preferred option. Tailings' solids will be trucked from the process plant directly to each planned deposition location at the TSFs, dumped, spread and compacted using a bulldozer, and graded to slope in a predetermined direction to facilitate control of surface water. Tailings will be placed in sections in the cells starting at the high point in the base grading and working toward the sumps. Each cell will be closed in phases every 3 to 4 years, once the full depth of tailings has been achieved in each section, as described in Section 20.5.
- i. For Plant Site Cell 1 and Area 7 Cell 1, tailings placement will be performed from south to north.

## 18.12 Paste Backfill Plant and Underground Reticulation

## 18.12.1 Surface Plant

The backfill system at the Elk Creek Mine was designed to make paste from leach residue and oxide material  produced  by  the  Hydromet  plant.  The  paste  formulation  tests  were  carried  out  in  SGS Lakefield, Ontario between March and July 2017. The test mixes met or exceeded the 1 MPa at 28day mining requirement using 5% binder.

A  calcination  pilot  program  carried  out  at  Hazen  Lab  in  Golden,  Colorado  suggested  that  the formation  of  Srebrodolskite  (Ca2Fe2O5)  significantly  reduces  the  CaO  content  in  the  oxide  solids. This allowed the backfill system to utilize the oxide as a source of solids without having a self-heating issue due to the exothermic reaction from hydrating CaO.

The paste plant receives 28.1 t/h of the leach residue filter cake, and up to 70 t/h of the oxide solids for making paste backfill. The leach residue filter cake is expected to have 20% to 25% moisture and the oxide solids are completely dry (due to the high temperature calcination process). If required, the oxide solids will be crushed to minus 2 mm, with a suitable particle size distribution, before they are used. The crushing process needs to be a dry process to avoid introducing excessive water content into the paste mix. The filter cake is fed to a conveyor belt with a live bottom feeder, while the dry oxide  solids  are  stored  in  a  silo  before  they  are  fed  to  the  mixer.  The  system  has  a  nominal production of 37.8 m 3 /h or 81.9 wet t/h. This is the rate required to keep up with the voids created underground. The design production rate is 62.4 m 3 /h or 137.8 wet t/h. This design rate allows the paste plant to catch up (at a throughput of 65% over the nominal rate). At the design rate, the backfill system can complete filling the daily void created underground in 14.5 hours. However, the system is expected  to  run  continuously  once  the  stopes  become  available  for  backfill,  except  for  planned maintenance.

## 18.12.2 Underground Reticulation

The  paste  is  pumped  underground  with  a  positive  displacement  pump.  The  pipeline  enters  the underground just outside of the backfill plant to avoid interfering with surface operations. This also eliminates any interactions with the waterway.

A 6 inch borehole connects the backfill plant and the underground backfill station at about 65 degree inclination from horizontal. From the underground backfill station, the paste goes to the stope in 6' Schedule 80 carbon steel pipe. Sill plugs will be required at the base of each paste pour in order to protect the paste barricades from overloading. The sill plugs typically extend from the bottom of the stope to roughly 2 m above the drawpoint brow. This ensures the maximum loading on the barricade is kept under 200 kPa.

Rupture  spools  are  used  to  manage  any  unexpected  high  pressure  in  the  pipeline.  The  paste  is directed from the rupture point to a sump for safety and easy clean-up. A spill detector senses the paste in the sump and transmits the information to the control room in the backfill plant. Water proof cameras with night vision are used to monitor the underground backfill operation.

## 18.12.3 Capital and Operating Cost

The pre-production capital for the paste plant and infrastructure is estimated at US$12.58 million. A 15%  contingency  (US$1.88  million)  is  included  in  Feasibility  Technical  Economic  Model.  The operating costs are estimated at US$8.29/t ore mined (average over LoM).

## 18.12.4 Opportunities

Binder costs are typically the single largest component of the operating cost in a backfill system. At Elk Creek the unique combination of leach residues and oxide wastes results in exceptional backfill strengths  at  very  low  binder  contents.  However,  all  backfill  systems  provide  opportunities  for optimization  of  mix  designs  to  lower  operating  costs.  The  slag  produced  from  the  mill  can  also potentially be analyzed and used as a binder or for sale.

## 19 Market Studies and Contracts

## 19.1  Market Studies

Market  studies  for  niobium,  titanium  dioxide  and  scandium  trioxide  are  an  important  part  of  the proposed  Elk  Creek  operation.  These  commodities,  especially  niobium  and  scandium  trioxide (scandium), are thinly traded without an established publically available price discovery mechanism. Hence, detailed third party market studies provide the basis for assumptions used in the economic analysis.

## 19.1.1 Niobium

As part of its scope for the Project, SRK carried out a Niobium Marketing Study in Q2 2017 at the request of NioCorp (SRK, 2017a) from which the following information in this section is taken.

Commercial  trade  of  niobium  occurs  in  a  number  of  forms,  the  most  common  of  which  is ferroniobium. Ferroniobium is sold most commonly as steel grade (65% Nb content) as well as a higher purity technical grade.

## Supply

The niobium market is generally described as an oligopoly with three major producers dominating supply.  These  three  producers  are  Companhia  Brasileira  de  Metalurgia  e  Mineração  (CBMM), Niobec and China Molybdenum Co. Ltd (CMOC). However, in practical terms, the market operates like a monopoly with a single company (CBMM) setting the price and the other operations acting as price takers. In addition, CBMM performs its own research and development activities to evaluate additional  /  increasing  usage  of  niobium  which  provides  a  significant  benefit  for  other  market participants.  In  terms  of  ferroniobium  production,  Table  19-1  shows  reported  annual  production capacity from the three largest mine operations along with the Project's estimates.

## Demand

Niobium demand showed a strong profile of growth over almost 20 years from the early 1990's to late 2000's, greatly exceeding growth rates in steel demand (Figure 19-1: ).

<!-- image -->

Source: CBMM, 2013

However, the overall trend in demand since that time has been flat overall. SRK is of the opinion that the drivers behind the flattening of demand growth in niobium are due to three primary factors:

- · CBMM rebasing the niobium price significantly higher in the late 2000's;
- · The global financial crisis of 2008 damaging global demand for all products; and
- · Decreasing rate of taking market share from some industry sectors such as automotive and pipeline.

SRK is of the opinion that demand growth for niobium usage will again outperform overall growth in demand  for  steel  (which  is  more  closely  tied  to  GDP  growth).  This  is  due  to  the  following assumptions:

- · Increased use in structural applications;
- · Continued  increases  in  market  share  in  automotive  applications,  albeit  at  a  reduced  rate from that seen in the 2000's;
- · Continued development of advanced new alloys and microalloys utilizing niobium; and
- · Continued development of new pipelines as oil and gas are produced from regions distant from  traditional  production  areas  (and  associated  refining  capacity).  This  includes  areas such as the Bakken shale gas field of North Dakota and oil shale regions of northern Alberta.

At  the  same  time,  other  primary  demand  sectors  for  niobium  will  be  maintained  such  as  on  the superalloy  side  where  the  718  superalloy  continues  to  be  utilized  in  the  newest  jet  engines  and global growth of the aeronautical industry remains robust. Some demand in sectors such as power

generation may fall off as typical steam or gas fired turbines from nuclear, natural gas or coal fired power may decrease, but this demand can be offset as niobium is also utilized in some renewable energy sources such as towers for wind turbines.

SRK therefore is of the opinion that it  is  reasonable  to  utilize  an  average  of  a  5%  growth  rate  in niobium demand going forward.

## Pricing

Recent price trends for 65% ferroniobium (pricing basis anticipated for NioCorp) are shown in Figure 19-2. Notably, there has been a slight downward trend in the US Dollar price since 2011. However, in terms of Brazilian Real, CBMM's base currency, the price actually increased over this time period. This indicates that although there may have been a slight decrease on a US Dollar basis, CBMM was potentially more profitable and could therefore allow the price to slip slightly.

<!-- image -->

Source: Metal Pages

Future prices of niobium are highly dependent upon the intention of CBMM. The company has the ability to flood the market with low cost production, dropping the price and driving out its competitors. This will  be  especially  true  once  it  finalizes  its  expansion  that  is  currently  underway.  However,  to date,  CBMM has shown a tolerance for other producers and has dropped its production levels to maintain a stable price. SRK is of the opinion that it has adopted this strategy as it allows for higher profitability and also provides additional comfort to downstream consumers that there is more than one supplier, encouraging additional demand.

The  economic  analysis  in  this  report  used  the  recommended  real  2017  US  dollar  base  price  of US$40/kg Nb as the forward looking price for steel grade (65%) ferroniobium. This price is slightly higher  than  spot,  but  SRK  is  of  the  opinion  that  the  recovering  Brazilian  Real,  combined  with increasing steel demand, will push the price back to the US$40/kg Nb level.

The key risk to achieving this price is the intent of the Brazilian producers as they have the potential to flood the market to depress the price and stop development of new Nb projects like Elk Creek. It is noted that the Brazilian producers have not taken such drastic actions during the decades that they have held a preeminent market position. SRK is of the opinion that this is not likely though given the limited production volumes (10% of global market of less) proposed by NioCorp.

## 19.1.2 Titanium Dioxide

No  formal  market  study  was  done  for  titanium  dioxide  (TiO2)  during  the  report  period  as  it  only represents 2% of overall revenue in the economic analysis. All market information for titanium and titanium  dioxide  is  derived  from  USGS  Commodity  Market  Summaries  (Bedinger,  2016)  and  the internal SRK price database.

TiO2  is  used  extensively  as  paint  pigment  with  some  minor,  though  increasing,  demand  from  the aerospace  industry  as  an  alloy  in  next  generation  aircraft.  Average  domestic  US  consumption  in 2015  was  747,000 t  of  which  242,000 t  was  imported.  With  the  Project  producing  approximately 11,500 t TiO2 per year during LoM, it is assumed that this annual production volume can easily be absorbed into the domestic market.

The  economic  analysis  assumes  a  constant  long-term  price  of  US$0.88/kg  based  on  rutile concentrate FOB Australia benchmark with no discounts. This is supported by SRK's subscription Consensus  Market  Forecast  (CMF),  produced  quarterly  by  Consensus  Economics,  which  shows long  term  pricing  trends  in  the  mid  to  high  eighties  range  as  shown  in  Table  19-2.  Although  the market  is  well-established  and  mature,  the  key  risk  to  maintaining  this  price  is  domestic  US  and global economic growth.
