The comminution test results indicate that the Ai for all of the samples tested ranges from 0.026 to 0.126, which corresponds to the mildly to slightly abrasive range.

The JKDW and SMC test results indicate that all of the individual samples fall in the moderately soft to moderately hard (A x b = 58.4 to 41.3) range of hardness with respect to resistance to impact (A x b).  The resistance to impact (A x b) for the composites ranges from medium to hard (A X b = 49.4 to 34.9).

The CWi results indicate that the samples tested are in the range of medium to moderately hard (10.7 kWh/t to 12.0 kWh/t) for crusher design purposes.

The RWi results indicate that the ore falls in the soft to hard (11.9 kWh/t to 18.0 kWh/t) range of hardness for the purpose of rod mill design purposes.

The BWi results indicate that two of the samples fall in the soft range (Sample #4 [11.6 kWh/t] and Sample #7 [11.7 kWh/t]).  The results also indicate that Comp1-VM10 falls in the moderately hard range (BWi = 15.7 kWh/t); all other samples fall in the moderately soft to medium range.

In summary, Comp1-VM10 shows hard indices in all tests, while all other samples range from soft to moderately hard.  This clearly indicates that the sample used in Comp1VM10 (drill hole NEC 14-010) is hard, while the rest of the ore zones are moderately hard.

The key parameters from the locked-cycle test work (the specific throughput, specific grinding force, net specific energy requirements, and flake thickness) are discussed in the following sub-sections.

## SPECIFIC ENERGY REQUIREMENT

The test work results indicate that the net specific energy requirement of the locked-cycle test is 3.65 kWh/t.  SGS reported that this is amongst the highest value in the SGS database and could possibly be owing to the relatively fine closing screen size (1.70 mm) used in the locked-cycle test (most of their HPGR tests are conducted with a coarser

<!-- image -->

screen size of 3.35 mm).  Tetra Tech notes that the reported net specific energy requirement is comparable to the HPGR specific power requirement (4.18 kWh/t) calculated, based on the SMC test on a different composite from the same orebody.

## SPECIFIC GRINDING FORCE

The results indicate that the specific grinding force of the locked-cycle test is 3.14 N/mm 2 .  SGS reported that this specific grinding force value corresponds to the 60 th percentile of the SGS database (meaning that 60% of all the locked-cycle tests used a lower pressure).

## SPECIFIC THROUGHPUT

Higher specific throughput was reported (311 ts/hm 3 ) from the locked-cycle test work. SGS reported that the sample falls in the soft range of the SGS database in terms of the specific throughput, at approximately the 15 th  percentile.

## FLAKE THICKNESS

The flake thickness was reported at approximately 7 mm for all tests.  This flake thickness indicates that a suitable de-agglomeration step ahead of the HPGR product screen needs to be considered in the process design.

## 3.0 RECOVERY METHODS

## 3.1 COMMINUTION FLOWSHEET OPTIONS TRADE-OFF STUDY

Tetra Tech completed a desktop-level, trade-off study in order to identify the optimal comminution flowsheet for the Project.  The trade-off study compared three comminution flowsheet options on a differential (or relative) cost basis:

-  conventional wet SAG milling (base case)
-  dry SAG milling
-  HPGR.

The battery limits for this trade-off study included all equipment from the primary crusher discharge bin to the final comminution product discharge bin at the end of the comminution circuit.

Tetra Tech assumed a comminution circuit product particle size at a characteristic size of P80 = 1.1 mm.

The accuracy of the capital cost estimate was assessed at ±25% and the operating cost estimate was assessed at ±10%.

## 3.1.3 DRY SAG MILL

## PROCESS DESCRIPTION

The primary crusher product will be dried in a rotary drier and fed to a dry SAG (Aerofall type) mill, operating with an air classifier.  The ore fraction of the air classifier will be fed to a screen and the oversize will be subsequently fed to an in-circuit pebble crusher for recycling to the mill.  The screen undersize is the comminution circuit product that will report to the hydrometallurgical process.  The air fraction will be fed to an air cyclone and passed through a dust collector bag house before returning to the mill. ## 3.1.5 BASIS OF COST ESTIMATES

## CAPITAL COST

The capital costs for each flowsheet option were established in the trade-off study, in order to comprehensively compare the flowsheet options.  The costs are based on a standalone plant construction, ring-fenced from all other site areas.

For the standalone plant, the primary equipment list of each flowsheet was developed from the following:

-  process design basis
-  conceptual block flow diagram
-  high-level equipment sizing
-  process design criteria.

Once the primary equipment list was developed, the cost of each capital item was established based on the following resources:

-  equipment vendor's budget price estimates
-  mine and mill equipment cost guide (Infomine USA 2014)
-  Tetra Tech's in-house database.

Installation costs were then estimated and the following engineering factors were applied:

-  civil
-  structural steel
-  piping and valves
-  electrical and instrumentation
-  transport
-  erection of items
-  vendor services.

Indirect engineering factors (site preparation and construction management) were then applied to the installed plant capital cost to establish the total capital cost.

It is important to note that the total plant capital costs used in the trade-off study form the base capital cost estimate of the selected plant, but cannot be compared directly to the final plant capital cost.

<!-- image -->

## OPERATING COST

Operating costs for each option were established by estimating the required labor, consumables, moisture removal or drying, and adsorbed power requirements.

The labor cost for the comminution circuit was assumed at a constant rate of US$0.50/t of ore for all options.

Consumable usage was estimated based on the test work results, vendor's recommendations, and from Tetra Tech's experience in similar projects, or using industry standard assumptions.

Maintenance spares were calculated assuming 5% of the cost of the primary mechanical equipment.

Power costs were calculated based on an estimate of absorbed power requirements and an assumed power cost of US$0.06/kWh.

## 3.1.8 ECONOMIC EVALUATION

The trade-off study capital and operating cost estimates clearly demonstrate that the HPGR option is the least expensive in terms of capital and operating costs.  In this context, a discounted cash flow analysis is not required in order to identify the most economical solution; HPGR can be selected for the Project as the most cost-effective solution for comminution.

## 3.4 PROCESS DESCRIPTION

The run-of-mine (ROM) ore will be crushed underground in a primary crusher, and the crushed product with a top size of 203 mm and characteristic size (P80) of 115 mm, will be delivered to the crushed ore bin located at the surface.  The ore from the bin will be reclaimed by three vibrating feeders with a total capacity of 136 t/h and passed on to the secondary crusher circuit via the secondary crusher screen feed conveyor.

At the secondary crushing stage, the ore will be sized on a dry, double deck screen with a top deck aperture size of 50 mm and bottom deck aperture size of 25 mm.  The screen oversize from both decks will report to the secondary crushing stage.  The screen undersize will be conveyed to the HPGR circuit.

<!-- image -->

The screen oversize fractions will be crushed in a single secondary cone crusher operating with a closed side setting of 25 mm.  The secondary crushed product will be sized by the same double deck screen with the primary crusher discharge ore.

The screen undersize, at an approximate characteristic particle size (P80) of 22 mm, will be further crushed in the HPGR circuit.  The HPGR circuit will consist a single HPGR crusher and a dual stage de-lumper-type de-agglomeration unit operating in closed circuit, with a separate double-deck vibrating screen with top and bottom deck aperture sizes of 6 mm and 3 mm, respectively.  The recirculating load of the HPGR circuit is expected to be in the range of 30 to 40% of the circuit new feed.

The HPGR screen undersize will be the final comminution product and is expected to have a characteristic particle size (P80) of 1.1 mm.  The ore will be stored in a fine ore bin, then reclaimed by three vibrating feeders with a total design capacity of 132 t/h, and then passed on to the acid leach circuit via the acid leach feed conveyor for further processing.

A conceptual block flow diagram of the HPGR circuit is shown in Figure 3.4.

## 3.5 CONTROL PHILOSOPHY

An appropriate control philosophy for the comminution circuit will be developed during the next stage of project development, in order to maximize throughput and stabilize the control of the product particle size.  Information about control philosophy is provided in this report as general guidance for the control system design engineer.

<!-- image -->

It is important to note that accurate and robust control instrumentation is critical to the long-term sustainability and success of a comminution operation.  The following conditions normally upset the steady state operation of comminution circuits:

-  variability in feed (size distribution, ore hardness, feed rate)
-  abrasive nature of the feed material
-  unmeasured disturbances (tramp metal, chute plugging).

Therefore, the control instrumentation should be carefully selected with the objective of preventing these conditions.

Typical equipment normally used in a comminution circuit includes:

-  conveyor belt weightometers (measure the mass of ore entering and leaving)
-  metal detectors (remove tramp steel from crusher feed conveyor)
-  level transmitters (measure the level of material in crushing cavity/surge bins)
-  tilt switches (in feed chutes to detect plugging events).

<!-- image -->

## 4.0 CONCLUSIONS

SGS completed historical test work in 2015 (SGS 2015) and it is included in this report for completeness.

The Feasibility-level comminution test work was completed in two stages at SGS.  The primary stage was conducted on six composite samples and 13 variability samples, and included the determination of standard comminution parameters (SGS 2016a).  The second stage of comminution test work was conducted on a single composite sample, using a LABWAL HPGR semi-pilot scale test work program (SGS 2016b).  The test work results indicate that the Project ore is categorized as soft to moderately hard in terms of ore hardness, and amenable to standard grinding as well as an HPGR operation.

The comminution flowsheet for the Project was selected by conducting an economic trade-off study (Tetra Tech 2016).  As part of the trade-off study, Tetra Tech compared three comminution flowsheet options on a differential (or relative) cost basis and identified the HPGR flowsheet as the most cost effective option for the Project.

The HPGR option for the comminution flowsheet has been designed to process 1,007,400 t/a of primary crushed niobium ore hoisted from the underground mine, with a characteristic particle size of (P80) 115 mm. The comminution circuit product is expected to have a characteristic particle size of (P80) 1.1 mm.

<!-- image -->

## 5.0 RISKS AND OPPORTUNITIES

Based on the metallurgical test work and the process design completed for the Feasibility Study, Tetra Tech has identified the following potential risks and opportunities for the Project.

## 5.1 RISKS

-  The ore moisture content was assumed as 5%.  This is a reasonable assumption for design purposes, but it is anticipated that the ore moisture content may exceed the 5% limit during certain periods of operation.  It is also observed that some lithology types consisted of an increased amount of clay particles.  It is important to note the presence of higher moisture and clay together in the feed would be detrimental for the effective operation of the HPGR.
-  The entire comminution circuit is designed as a single stream.  This means the breakdown of any equipment in the flowsheet will stop the production of the plant.  This risk could be mitigated by running a preventive maintenance program, as well as employing a good maintenance crew on site.
-  The comminution test work indicates that the ore from one particular area of the mine is much harder than the rest of the ore.  However, Niocorp interpreted that the harder ore represents a minor proportion of the entire ore body.  The comminution circuit design is based on a blended feed that includes the hard ore.  The comminution circuit will be become a bottleneck if this hard ore has to be treated in its own without appropriate blending in place.
-  The consumable consumption rates of the HPGR were not tested; thus the wear and tear of the HPGR unit cannot be estimated.  Higher than normal wear and tear of HPGR is a potential risk.
-  The design comminution circuit product has a characteristic particle size of P80 = 1.1 mm.  This target product size is achievable subject to effective operation of the secondary screen along with the DE agglomeration drums.  Any fluctuations in the HPGR feed size as a result of screen inefficiency will have a negative effect on HPGR performance and final product size.
-  The risk of airborne and respirable dust exposure to the comminution plant operational team has not been quantified yet.  This could be possibly mitigated by employing covered conveyors and an effective dust control system.

<!-- image -->

## 5.2 OPPORTUNITIES

-  Waste heat generated from other areas of the process plant could possibly be used to dry the ore during periods of higher moisture content of feed ore.

<!-- image -->

## 6.0 RECOMMENDATIONS

Based on the metallurgical test work and the process design completed for the Feasibility Study, Tetra Tech recommends further pilot testing of the HPGR option.  The pilot HPGR test work program should be conducted prior to the detailed engineering stage in order to confirm and determine:

-  the main operating variables of the HPGR
-  flake strength
-  wear rate
-  Abrasion Index

The results from the pilot testing will be used to confirm the unit energy consumption, optimize the HPGR operating variables, and confirm the size of the HPGR unit for industrial operation.

The sample requirement for the pilot testing is estimated to be approximately 1.5 t.

Tetra Tech recommends that NioCorp select a vendor and complete the pilot testing prior to placing the order for the HPGR.  The cost of pilot testing will be in the range of US$8,500 to US$30,000, depending on the vendor.

## Executive Summary

The objective of this project was to characterize the hardness of samples in order to design a single-stage SAG mill grinding circuit.

The grindability tests conducted on 19 samples from the Elk Creek project indicated that:

-  The samples typically varied from the moderately soft to moderately hard range of hardness with respect to SAG milling and in terms of the Bond rod mill work index (RWI);
-  The ore is relatively  softer  for  ball  milling  relative  to  the  SAG  mill  grindability  and  the  samples typically ranged from the soft to medium range of hardness with respect to ball milling;
-  The ore is only slightly abrasive;
-  The hardness variability among the samples was relatively low likely due to the compositing of the samples.  Individual samples may show a greater range of hardness.

The grindability test results were used to design a grinding circuit capable of treating 2,700 tpd (122.3 t/h at 92% availability), from a feed F80 of 115 mm to a P80 of 1.4 mm using the JKSimMet software.  Two single-stage SAG mill configurations were investigated: with and without pebble crushing.

-  For the single-stage SAG mill without pebble crushing, it was found that one 20.0' x 9.0' SAG mill, with internal dimensions (nominal diameter x EGL) of 5.89 x 2.74 m, fitted with a 1.72 MW motor (2,300 HP), would be adequate to reach the design targets;
-  For the single-stage SAG mill with pebble crushing (SAC), it was found that one 20.0' x 7.5' SAG mill, with internal dimensions (nominal diameter x EGL) of 5.89 x 2.29 m, fitted with a 1.42 MW motor (1,900 HP), would be adequate to reach the design targets;
-  The motors were designed to allow an increase in ball charge up to 15% and in mill speed up to 80% of the critical speed (13.9 RPM).

-  Mill  design  should  be  reviewed  with  supplier  as  power  draw  may  vary  with  mill  geometry  and design, like the cone angles.

These recommendations do not allow for any safety factors that should be applied for errors in the model and design assumptions or the uncertainty in the representation of the ore body by the selected samples.

It is  recommended  to  complete  additional  variability  testing  using  continuous  intervals  representing individual blocks rather than large composites, in order to measure the true variability in hardness indices and to reduce the risk in the equipment selection.

Note that the product size P80 from the AG mill operation is highly ore-dependent, although also clearly affected by the classification system.  The P80 figures simulated in JKSimMet should be used as indicative only,  and  fine  tuning  of  the  AG  mill  discharge  system  and  classification  screen  aperture  may  be necessary once in operation.

## Introduction

Mr.  Alain  Dorval  of  Roche  Ltd,  on  behalf  of  NioCorp  Developments  Ltd,  requested  that  SGS  Minerals Services (SGS) perform grindability testing on nineteen samples from the Elk Creek deposit, located in Nebraska, USA.  The objective of this project was to characterize the hardness of the samples in order to design a single-stage SAG mill grinding circuit.

The  sample  preparation  and  grindability  program  was  performed  at  the  SGS  Lakefield  facility.    The characterization included the following tests: JK drop weight test, SMC test, Bond low-energy impact test, Bond rod mill grindability test, Bond ball mill grindability test, and Bond abrasion index test.

The bench-scale test results were used to design a grinding circuit capable of milling 2,700 metric tonnes per day (tpd) from a SAG feed F80 of 115 mm to a final grind P80 of about 1.4 mm.

This report summarizes the sample preparation and presents the grindability test results, as well as the grinding circuit design.

## 2.1. JK Drop-weight and SMC Tests

The JK drop-weight test was performed on four individual samples (Samples #1 to #3 and Sample #12) and on two composites (Comp4-VM12-13, Comp5-LPM11-13).  The results were interpreted by Contact Support Services (CSS), the North American agent for JKTech.  The test results are presented in Table 3 while the test procedures and details are presented in the CSS report (Appendix B).

In  addition  to  the  JK  drop-weight  test,  SMC  tests  were  performed  on  nine  individual  samples  and  six composites,  namely  Comp1-VM10,  Comp2-PM10,  Comp3-P10,  Comp4-VM12-13,  Comp5-LPM11-13, and Comp6-PM13.  The SMC tests on the individual samples were performed on Samples #4 to 11 as well  as  on  Sample  #13.    The  SMC  test  is  an  abbreviated  version  of  the  standard  JK  drop-weight  test performed on rocks from a single size fraction (-22.4/+19.0 mm in this case).  The SMC test results were calibrated  against  reference  samples  submitted  for  the  standard  DWT  in  order  to  consider  the  natural 'gradient of hardness' by size, which can widely vary from one ore to another.  The SMC test results were calibrated against the average DWT results.  The test results are presented in Table 3 and the SMC test results are detailed in the JKTech report, which is appended (Appendix C) along with the test procedure, calibration, and test details.  The cumulative distribution of the A x b values from the Elk Creek samples is compared to other large comminution projects in Figure 2.

The Elk Creek samples typically fell in the moderately soft to  moderately  hard  range of hardness with respect  to  resistance  to  impact  (A x b)  and  abrasion  (t )  breakages.    Only  sample  Comp1-VM10  was a categorized as hard in terms of A x b.  The A x b average, including all the DWT and SMC results, was 47.5.  The two samples on which a DWT and an SMC tests were performed were in good agreement. Four of the DWT samples have shown a slight evidence of bimodality in the rock relative density.  The average rock relative density among the 19 samples varied from 2.84 to 3.32.

As shown in Figure 2, the variability of the A x b from the Elk Creek samples was much lower than what is typically observed.  The Elk Creek A x b distribution is very sharp compared to other projects which all have a reversed 'S' shape, which is more typical.  The low variability in the test results may be due to the fact  that  composites,  made  of  intervals  from  different  depth  and  locations,  were  tested  rather  than discrete samples representing a specific block or location in the deposit.  Testing on large composites tends to reduce the variability observed in the results.

## 2.2. Bond Low-energy Impact Test

The Bond low-energy impact test determines the Bond Crusher Work Index (CWI), which can be used with Bond's third theory of comminution to calculate power requirements for crusher sizing.  The test was performed  on  Samples  #12  and  #13  only.    A  total  of  20  rock  specimens  for  each  sample,  in  the -75/+50 mm size fraction  were shipped to the SGS Burnaby laboratory for the completion of the Bond low-energy impact test.    The  results  are  presented  in  Table  4  and  compared  to  the  SGS  database  in Figure 3.  The test details are appended (Appendix D).  With CWI values of 10.7 kWh/t (Sample #12) and 12.0 kWh/t (Sample #13), the samples fell in the medium to moderately hard range of hardness of the SGS database.

## 3. Grinding Circuit Design

After completion of the grindability test program, the design was put on hold for about 18 months until the metallurgical  flowsheet  and  liberation  size  requirement  were  defined.    Since  the  liberation  size  is  now coarse enough, the need of a secondary milling step was eliminated.

A grinding circuit design was performed based on the bench-scale grindability test results presented in Section 2 using the JKSimMet software.

## 3.1. Design Criteria

The grinding circuit was designed to handle a throughput rate of 2,700 tpd (122.3 t/h at 92% availability) from a feed F80 of 115 mm to a final grind P80 of 1.4 mm.  The design criteria are summarized below:

## Design Criteria:

Daily Tonnage:

2,700 tpd (metric)

Utilization Rate:

92.0%

Throughput Rates:

122.3 t/h

F80:

115 mm

Final P80:

1,400 microns

Two flowsheet configurations, which are represented in their simplified form in Figure 10 and Figure 11, were investigated in the design.  The first option is a single-stage SAG circuit, which consists of a semiautogenous grinding mill (SAG) closed with a screen.  The addition of a pebble crusher to the previous

configuration, which results in the SAC circuit, was also simulated.  A standard primary crusher product size  distribution,  with  an  F 80 of  115  mm,  was  requested.    The  complete  size  distribution  used  for  the design is presented in Figure 12.

## 3.1.1. Correction Factors and Calculations

The SAG mill powers were calculated using the Morrell power calculation spreadsheet and correspond to the power at the motor input.

The average crusher power requirements, calculated using the Bond crusher work index, were reported at the motor input.  Bond's equation reports the crusher power at the motor output, and thus a correction factor  of  0.95  was  applied.    Note  that  the  calculated  crusher  power  corresponds  to  average  power

requirements based on the third theory of comminution, but the crusher motors must be designed by the supplier to handle peak power

The total gross power was obtained by adding the power requirements for the SAG milling and pebble crushing (when applicable).  The total specific power requirement was calculated by dividing the gross power requirement by the total feed rate.

## 3.2. Scoping Simulation Results

The  simulations  were  performed  with  a  SAG  mill  charge  level  of  25%,  which  is  the  average  in  the JKSimMet model database, and is considered optimal for throughput.  The simulations were performed with  a  maximum  of  25%  recycle  rate  at  the  SAG  mill.    The  results  of  the  scoping  simulations  are presented in Table 9 and Table 10.

In SIM-01, it was found that a 20.0' x 9.0' (nominal diameter x EGL) SAG mill with internal dimensions of 5.89 x 2.74 m and operated with a 10% ball charge would be required to achieve 122.3 t/h (2,700 tpd) for the single-stage SAG configuration.  A speed of 75% of the critical speed was used, which corresponds to 13.1 RPM.  A closing screen size of 8 mm was used, and resulted in a product size P80 of about 1.6 mm. The grind size was slightly coarser than the target of 1.4 mm because it is expected that the grindability test results from the 80 th percentile, used in the scoping simulations, will generate a coarser P80 than the average grinding test results.  The SAG mill power requirement was 10.9 kWh/t.  Cone angles of 15º were assumed for the SAG mill, but final design should be checked with the supplier.  The SAG mill should be fitted with a total installed power of 2,300 HP (1.72 MW), which would allow an increase in ball charge up to 15% and in mill speed up to 80% of the critical speed (13.9 RPM).

The addition of a pebble crusher, simulated in SIM-02, resulted in an overall power requirement reduction of about 1.7 kWh/t and thus a shorter SAG mill.  A 20.0' x 7.5' (EGL) SAG mill, with internal dimensions of 5.89 x 2.29 m was selected to handle 122.3 t/h for the SAC configuration.  Cone angles of 15º were also assumed  for  the  SAG  mill.    The  SAG  mill  should  be  fitted  with  a  total  installed  power  of  1,900  HP (1.42 MW), which  will  allow  an  increase  in  ball  charge  up  to  15%  and  in  mill  speed  up  to  80%  of  the critical speed (13.9 RPM).  Given the low recycle rate of 27 t/h, a single HP100 cone crusher should be adequate for pebble crushing.

The total specific energy required to process 122.3 t/h was 10.8 kWh/t, on average, and varied from 10.3 to 11.3 kWh/t, for the SS-SAG configuration.  The product size P80 averaged 1,426 microns, and ranged from 1,184 to 1,840 microns.

The addition of a pebble crusher reduced the average total specific energy requirement to 9.2 kWh/t, and ranged from 8.7 to 9.6 kWh/t.  The average product size for the SAC configuration was 1,459 microns, and varied from 1,219 to 1,868 microns.  The characteristics of the recommended AG mills are presented in Table 11.

Note  that  the  product  size  P 80 from  AG  mill  operation  is  highly  ore-dependent,  although  also  clearly affected by the classification system.  The P80 figures simulated in JKSimMet should be used as indicative only,  and  fine  tuning  of  the  AG  mill  discharge  system  and  classification  screen  aperture  may  be necessary once in operation.

## 1 INTRODUCTION

Drop-weight test data for six samples from Niocorp were received  from SGS Minerals Services on February 24-26, 2015, by CSS  for data analysis.  The samples were  identified as  Comp 4-VM 12-12, Comp 5-LPM 11-13, Sample #1, Sample #2, Sample #3 and Sample #12.  The data were analysed to determine the JKSimMet comminution parameters.  Analysis and reporting  were completed on February 27, 2015.

## 2 THE JK DROP-WEIGHT TEST

## 2.1 INTRODUCTION

The JKTech drop-weight test provides ore specific parameters for use in the JKSimMet Mineral Processing Simulator software.  In JKSimMet, these parameters are combined with equipment details and operating conditions to analyse and/or predict SAG/autogenous mill performance.  The same test procedure also provides ore type characterisation for the JKSimMet crusher model.  These ore specific parameters have been calculated from the test results and are supplied to Niocorp Developments Ltd. in this report as part of the standard procedure.

## 2.2 DROP-WEIGHT TEST PROCEDURE

Details of the drop-weight test procedure can be found in Appendix A.

## 2.3 INTERPRETATION OF DW TEST RESULTS

## 2.3.1 Resistance to Impact Breakage

One of the problems with the functional form used to represent the t10 v Ecs relationship is that the parameters A and b are not independent and thus cannot be used directly for comparisons between ore types.  Two alternative parameters give a better comparison.  These are the product A*b and the t10 achieved by the application of 1.0 kWh/t of Specific Comminution Energy (Ecs).  For both of these parameters, a smaller number means a greater resistance to impact breakage.

## 2.3.2 Resistance to Abrasion Breakage

Resistance to abrasion is indicated by the ta parameter.  As with parameter A*b, a smaller value of ta indicates more resistance, this time to abrasion breakage.

## 2.3.3 Effect of Particle Size on Resistance to Impact Breakage

Variation of impact resistance with particle size is important for crusher power draw calculations and SAG/autogenous mill media competency considerations.  Some ores exhibit a significant decrease in impact resistance with increasing particle size while others show no variation with size.  The opposite trend of increasing impact resistance with increasing particle size is extremely rare.

The trend most frequently observed is for there to be decreasing slope with decreasing energy (Ecs values).  However, it is both the slope and the absolute values of the low energy t10 values that are of interest for SAG/autogenous milling because these data give an indication of the ability of media particles to survive.  If the trend of the t10 values with increasing particle size is significantly upwards, it can be inferred by extrapolation that particles in the 100 - 200 mm size range (normal media size) will not be strong enough to survive.  The same argument applies if the absolute values of t10 at low energy are sufficiently high.

## 2.3.4 Density Results

As part of the standard JKTech ore property assessment procedures, the relative density of 30 randomly selected particles in the size range 26.5 mm to 31.5 mm are determined by weighing each particle, suspended initially in air and then in water.

It should be noted that this method measures the density of the particle rather than the density of the solid phase, since any internal porosity will be included in the volume measurement.  A more accurate measurement of the solid phase density is possible using a Helium Pycnometer.  However, it is the particle density rather than the phase density that is of concern in the assessment of SAG milling properties.

Even at the coarse particle sizes tested, it is normal to find a range of relative densities as the mineralogy of the particles varies.  However, of great concern in SAG/autogenous milling is the possibility of a component in the ore that is both high density and resistant to breakage.  Such material will concentrate in the load in a SAG/autogenous mill and result in higher than expected power draw.

## APPENDICES

## APPENDIX A.  BACKGROUND TO THE DROP WEIGHT TEST

## A 1 INTRODUCTION

This section provides a brief description of the drop-weight test procedure.

To characterise ore breakage at different energy levels, the JKTech method uses two complimentary techniques:

- 1. To characterise breakage at moderate to high energy levels (i.e. impact breakage), a drop-weight device is used.
- 2. To characterise breakage at low energy inputs (i.e. the abrasion component of breakage), a tumbling test is used.

## A 2 IMPACT BREAKAGE TESTING

The JK drop-weight device comprises a steel drop-weight that can be raised by a winch to a known height.  A pneumatic switch releases the drop-weight, which then falls under gravity and impacts on a rock particle that is positioned on a steel anvil. The device is enclosed in Perspex shielding and incorporates a variety of features to ensure operator safety.  By varying the height from which the drop-weight is released and the mass of the drop-weight, a very wide range of energy inputs can be generated.  A schematic drawing of the device is given in App Figure 1.

After release, the drop-weight descends under the influence of gravity and impacts the target particle.

App Figure 1 - The JK Drop Weight Tester

<!-- image -->

The particle is broken and the drop-weight is brought to rest at a distance above the anvil approximately equal to the largest product particle.  The difference in distance between the initial starting point and the final resting place of the drop-weight is used to calculate the energy that is expended in breaking the particle.  Thus

where:

Ei =  energy used for breakage

M  =  drop-weight mass g  =  gravitational constant

h  =  initial height of the drop-weight above the anvil xM =  final height of the drop-weight above the anvil.

Providing the drop-weight does not rebound after impact, the application of equation (1) is valid.  Where rebound occurs an additional term is required to account for the energy re-transmitted to the drop-weight.  Rebound has been seen to occur only at elevated input energies.  This energy will be assessed during the test work program. It is likely, however, that its magnitude will be relatively small and can be ignored with only a minimal loss in accuracy.

The assumption is made that all the energy provided is utilised in the breakage of the particle.  Thus

<!-- formula-not-decoded -->

where:

Eis =  specific input energy

Ecs =  specific comminution energy m    =  mean particle mass

To test an ore type, the original 100 kg sample is sized into selected fourth-root-oftwo size fractions.  Ten (10) to thirty (30) particles are required in each size fraction for each energy level, depending on particle mass.  Typically fifteen (15) size/energy combinations are selected.  The input energy levels for a particular test are designed to suit ore hardness but a standard set of energies are used whenever possible.

The breakage products of all particles for each size/energy combination are collected and sized.  The size distribution produced is normalised with respect to the original particle size.  For a wide range of energy inputs, particle sizes and ore types, the relative size distributions remain similar in shape and can be fully characterised by a single point on the distribution.  The JKTech convention is to use the percentage passing one-tenth of the original particle size.  This is referred to as the "t10" value.

In the manner described above, a set of t10 and Ecs values are produced for the 15 energy/size combinations.

## A 3 ABRASION BREAKAGE TESTING

It is possible to characterise low energy (abrasion) breakage with a miniature dropweight and repeated impacts.  However, Leung (1987) demonstrated that a tumbling test of selected single size fractions could produce a similar result with less experimental effort.

The standard abrasion test tumbles 3 kg of -55+38 mm particles for 10 minutes at 70% critical speed in a 305 mm by 305 mm laboratory mill fitted with 4 x 6 mm lifter bars.  The resulting product is then sized and the t10 value for the product is determined.

## A 4.1 SAG/autogenous Mill Model

In the SAG/autogenous mill, both breakage mechanisms discussed in Section 2 are assumed to occur.  The parameters used in the model are given in Table 1.

As discussed in Section A 3, the abrasion test results in a t10 figure.  The abrasion parameter used in the model, ta, is defined as

For example, if t10 = % passing 4.57 mm = 4.0%, then

## A 4.4 Combined Breakage

These two sets of parameters representing the two breakage modes are used in combination by the model to generate an ore specific appearance function.  The scaling factor of 10 is applied in the calculation of ta so that the relative proportions of

high and low energy breakage represented in the combined appearance function are correct.

The assumption is made that all brittle rock types break with the same general pattern and this pattern is built into the model.  This assumption does not mean that the amount of energy required to achieve a particular t10 is the same for all brittle rocks.  It simply means that if a single particle is broken to a particular t10 value, then the complete size distribution of the broken fragments is known.

This assumption is not perfect but is quite adequate for the purposes of the SAG/autogenous model.

To use the results of testing, the ore type parameters A and b (from drop-weight testing) and ta (from abrasion testing), are entered into the SAG/autogenous mill model in JKSimMet, together with machine dependent parameters of mill size, grate size, ball load, etc.  The simulation predicts product size and mill load using appropriate breakage rates.  The simulator can then also be used to predict mill performance with variations in screen and classifier configurations or even with recycle crushing.

Details of the SAG/autogenous mill model are given in Leung (1987) and Leung, Morrison, and Whiten (1987).  The calculations on which the power prediction for SAG/autogenous mills is based are described in Morrell (1996).

## A 4.5 Crusher Model

For the crusher model, only the high energy or impact breakage test results are used. These are presented in a somewhat different manner from the SAG/autogenous mill model.

The assumption that all brittle rocks break with the same breakage pattern is not made and the pattern for the ore under test is used.  The parameters used by the crusher model are tabulated in the results section of this report.  The appearance function defines the shape of the breakage distribution curve at various degrees of "broken-ness", as defined by t10.  The specific comminution energy table defines the amount of energy required to achieve varying levels of "broken-ness".  The form of the specific comminution energy table reflects the fact that the energy required to achieve a certain degree of breakage is sometimes found to be dependent on the initial particle size.

Details of the crusher model including power prediction are described in Andersen and Napier-Munn (1988).

## A 4.6 Limitations

Experience to date demonstrates that the drop-weight test is appropriate for brittle ores over a wide range of hardness.  However, it is not useful for ores which undergo plastic deformation rather than brittle fracture, such as those of high clay content.

The testing procedure is limited by the maximum particle size tested.  If the ore is fractured or weaker at larger particle sizes, then JKSimMet simulations will be conservative.

For autogenous mills it is essential to have competent material in the range 150 mm to 100 mm in the feed to form the media.  If autogenous milling is seriously contemplated, testing of media competency at larger particle sizes should be conducted.  This can be achieved by drop-weight testing, media competency testing or full pilot plant testing.

The samples were  identified as Comp 1-VM10, Comp 2-PM10, Comp 3-P10, Comp 4VM12-13, Comp 5-LPM 11-13, Comp 6-PM13, Sample #4, Sample #5, Sample #6, Sample #7, Sample #8, Sample #9, Sample #10, Sample #11 &amp; Sample #13. ## 2 THE SMC TEST®

## 2.1 INTRODUCTION

The standard JK Drop-Weight test provides ore specific parameters for use in the JKSimMet Mineral Processing Simulator software.  In JKSimMet, these parameters are combined with equipment details and operating conditions to analyse and/or predict SAG/autogenous mill performance.  The same test procedure also provides ore type characterisation for the JKSimMet crusher model.

The SMC test was developed by Steve Morrell of SMC Testing Pty Ltd (SMCT) to provide a cost effective means of obtaining these parameters from drill core or in situations where limited quantities of material are available.  The ore specific parameters have been calculated from the test results and are supplied to NioCorp Developments in this report as part of the standard procedure

## 2.2 GENERAL DESCRIPTION AND TEST BACKGROUND

The SMC Test ® was originally designed for the breakage characterisation of drill core and it generates a relationship between input energy (kWh/t) and the percent of broken product passing a specified sieve size.  The results are used to determine the so-called JK Drop-Weight index (DWi), which is a measure of the strength of the rock when broken under impact conditions and has the units kWh/m .  The DWi is directly 3 related to the JK rock breakage parameters A and b and hence can be used to estimate the values of these parameters as well as being correlated with the JK abrasion parameter - ta.  For crusher modelling the t10-Ecs matrix can also be derived. This is done by using the size-by-size A*b values that are used in the SMC Test® data analysis (see below) to estimate the t10-Ecs values for each of the relevant size fractions in the crusher model matrix.

For power-based calculations, (see APPENDIX B), the SMC Test ® provides the comminution parameters Mia, Mih and Mic. Mia is the work index for the grinding of coarser particles (&gt; 750 µm) in tumbling mills such as autogenous (AG), semiautogenous (SAG), rod and ball mills.  Mih is the work index for the grinding in High Pressure Grinding Rolls (HPGR) and Mic for size reduction in conventional crushers.

The SMC Test ® is a precision test, which uses particles that are either cut from drill core using a diamond saw to achieve close size replication or else selected from crushed material so that particle mass variation is controlled within a prescribed range. The particles are then broken at a number of prescribed impact energies. The high degree of control imposed on both the size of particles and the breakage energies used, means that the test is largely free of the repeatability problems associated with tumbling-mill based tests.  Such tests usually suffer from variations in feed size (which is not closely controlled) and  energy input, often assumed to be constant when in reality it can be highly variable (Levin, 1989).

The relationship between the DWi and the JK rock breakage parameters makes use of the size-by-size nature of rock strength that is often apparent from the results of full JK Drop-Weight tests.  The effect is illustrated in Figure 1, which plots the normalized values of A*b against particle size.  This figure also shows how the gradient of these plots varies across the full range of rock types tested.  In the case of a conventional JK Drop-Weight test, these values are effectively averaged and a

mean value of A and b is reported. The SMC Test ® uses a single size and makes use of relationships such as that shown in Figure 1 to predict the A and b of the particle size that has the same value as the mean for a JK full Drop-Weight test.

Figure 1 - Relationship between Particle Size and A*b

<!-- image -->

## 2.3 THE TEST PROCEDURE

In the SMC Test ® , five sets of 20 particles are broken, each set at a different specific energy level, using a JK Drop-Weight tester.  The breakage products are screened at a sieve size selected to provide a direct measurement of the t10 value.

The test calls for a prescribed target average volume for the particles, with the target being chosen to be equivalent to the mean volume of particles in one of the standard JK Drop-Weight test size fractions.

The rest height of the drop-head (gap) is recorded after breakage of each particle to allow for a correction to the drop energy.  After breaking all 20 particles in a set, the broken product is sieved at an aperture size, one tenth of the original particle size. Thus, the percent passing mass gives a direct reading of the t10 value for breakage at that energy level.

There are two alternative methods of preparing the particle sets for breakage testing: the particle selection method and the cut core method.  The particle selection method is the most commonly used as it is generally less time consuming.  The cut core method requires less material, so tends to be used as a fallback method, only when necessary to cope with restricted sample availability.

## 2.3.1 Particle Selection Method

For the particle selection method, the test is carried out on material in one of three alternative size fractions: -31.5+26.5, -22.4+19 or -16+13.2 mm.  The largest size fraction is preferred but requires more material.  The middle size fraction tends to be

most commonly used, whilst the finest size fraction tends only to be used if there is an issue with starting material size distribution or quantity.

In the particle selection method, particles are chosen so that their individual masses lie within ±30% of the target mass and the mean mass for each set of 20 lies within ±10% of the target mass.  A typical set of particles is shown in Figure 2.

Figure 2 - A Typical Set of Particles for Breakage (Particle Selection Method)

<!-- image -->

Before commencing breakage tests on the particles, the ore density is determined by first weighing a representative sample of particles in air and then in water.

## 2.3.2 Cut Core Method

The cut core method uses cut pieces of quartered (slivered) drill core.  Whole core or half core can be used, but when received in this form it needs to be first quartered as a preliminary step in the procedure.  Once quartered, any broken or tapered ends of the quartered lengths are cut, to square them off.  Before the lengths of quartered core are cut to produce the pieces for the JK Drop-Weight testing, each one is weighed in air and then in water, to obtain a density measurement and a measure of its mass per unit length.

The size fraction targeted when the cut core method is used depends on the original core diameter.  The target size fraction is selected to ensure that pieces of the correct volume will have 'chunky' rather than 'slabby' proportions.

Having measured the density of the core, the target volume can be translated into a target mass and with the average mass per unit length also known, an average cutting interval can be determined for the core.

Sufficient pieces of the quartered core are cut to generate 100 particles.  These are then divided into the five sets of 20 and broken in the JK Drop-Weight tester at the five different energy levels.  Within each set, the three possible orientations of the particles are equally represented (as far as possible, given that there are 20 particles).  The orientations prescribed for testing are shown in Figure 3.

Figure 3 - Orientations of Pieces for Breakage (Cut Core Method)

<!-- image -->

The cut core method cannot be used for cores with diameters exceeding 70 mm, where the particle masses would be too large to achieve the highest prescribed energy level.

## APPENDICES

## APPENDIX A. BACKGROUND TO THE SMC TEST ®

## A 1 HOW THE SMC TEST ®  RESULTS ARE USED

The SMC Test® generates a relationship between specific input energy (kWh/t) and the percent of broken product passing a specified sieve size. The results are used to determine the JK Drop-Weight index (DWi), which is a measure of the strength of the rock when broken under impact conditions. The DWi is directly related to the JK rock breakage parameters A and b and hence can be used to estimate the values of these parameters.

Provision of a relatively low cost method of estimating the A and b parameters opens the possibility of incorporating these data into mine and mill planning operations. However a number of full JK Drop-Weight tests is still recommended for any particular orebody, to ensure that an accurate correlation between the DWi and the A and b parameters is available. The number of full JK Drop-Weight tests required for a given orebody will depend on its variability and should at least cover the major recognised ore types.

The A and b parameters are used in AG/SAG mill models, such as those in JKSimMet, for predicting how the rock will break inside the mill. From this description the models can predict what the throughput, power draw and product size distribution will be (Napier-Munn et al (1996)). Modelling also enables a detailed flowsheet to be built up of the comminution circuit response to changes in ore type. It also allows optimisation strategies to be developed to overcome any deleterious changes in circuit performance predicted from differences in ore type when such changes are indicated by the SMC Test®. These strategies can include both changes to how mills are operated (eg ball load, speed etc) and changes to feed size distribution through modification of blasting practices and primary crusher operation (mine-to-mill).

The mine to mill models require information on rock mass competence such as provided by the point load index. The DWi is correlated with the point load index and hence can also be used in blast fragmentation modelling where direct measurements of point load index are not available.

The DWi is related to the resistance of a rock to breakage under impact. SMCT has developed a series of equations that relate the DWi to the specific energy (kWh/t) requirements of complete AG and SAG mill circuits. These equations take into consideration factors such as ball charge, feed size, aspect ratio, whether the mill is operated with or without a pebble crusher and whether it is closed with a fine classifier such as a cyclone. The ability of these equations to predict AG/SAG mill circuit specific energy is illustrated in App Figure 1. The data shown cover 19 different operations and include Cu, Au, Ni and Pb/Zn ores.

App Figure 1 - Mill Power Prediction Based on DWi

<!-- image -->

It should be noted that the parameter ta, which is the parameter representing the low energy abrasion component of breakage, is not yielded by the SMC Test®.  This parameter is derived from a tumbling test that is carried out as part of the full JK Drop-Weight test.  The fact that it is also required as an input to the JKSimMet SAG/AG models provides a further reason for ensuring that some full JK DropWeight tests are also performed to represent at least the main rock types of an orebody.

## A 2 IMPACT COMMINUTION THEORY

When a rock fragment is broken, the degree of breakage can be characterised by the 't10' parameter.  The t10 value is the percentage of the original rock mass that passes a screen aperture one tenth of the original rock fragment size.  This parameter allows the degree of breakage to be compared across different starting sizes.

The specific comminution energy (Ecs) has the units kWh/t and is the energy applied during impact breakage.  As the impact energy is varied, so does the t10 value vary in response. Higher impact energies produce higher values of t10, which of course means products with finer size distributions.

The equation describing the relationship between the t10 and Ecs is given below.

<!-- formula-not-decoded -->

As can be seen from this equation, there are two rock breakage parameters A and b that relate the t10 (size distribution index) to the applied specific energy (Ecs).  These parameters are ore specific and are normally determined from a full JK Drop-Weight test.

A typical plot of t10 vs Ecs from a JK Drop-Weight test is shown in App Figure 2.  The relationship is characterised by the two-parameter equation above, where t10 is the dependent variable.

App Figure 2 - Typical t10 v Ecs Plot

<!-- image -->

The t10 can be thought of as a 'fineness index' with larger values of t10 indicating a finer product size distribution. The value of parameter A is the limiting value of t10. This limit indicates that at higher energies, little additional size reduction occurs as the Ecs is increased beyond a certain value.  A*b is the slope of the curve at 'zero' input energy and is generally regarded as an indication of the strength of the rock, lower values indicating a higher strength.

The A and b parameters can also be used with equation 1 to generate a table of Ecs values, given a range of t10 values. Such a table is used in crusher modelling to predict the power requirement of the crusher given a feed and a product size specification.

The DWi can be used to estimate the JK rock breakage parameters A and b by utilizing the fact that there is usually a pronounced (and ore specific) trend to decreasing rock strength with increasing particle size.  This trend is illustrated in App Figure 3  which shows a plot of A*b versus particle size for a number of different rock types.

App Figure 3 - Size Dependence of A*b for a Range of Ore Types

<!-- image -->

In the case of a conventional JK Drop-Weight test these values are effectively averaged and a mean value of A and b is reported. The SMC Test® uses a single size and makes use of relationships such as that shown in App Figure 3 to predict the A and b of the particle size that has the same value as the mean for a full JK Drop-Weight test.

An example of this is illustrated in App Figure 4 - Predicted v Observed A*b where the observed values of the product A*b are plotted against those predicted using the DWi. Each of the data points in App Figure 4 is a result from a different ore type within an orebody.

App Figure 4 - Predicted v Observed A*b

## APPENDIX B. USE OF THE Mia, Mib, Mih, Mic IN PREDICTING COMMINUTION CIRCUIT SPECIFIC ENERGY

## B 1 INTRODUCTION

-  As the SMC Test® produces the JK parameter values A and b as well as estimates the JK parameter ta and crusher model energy matrices, the SMC Test® can be used to conduct AG/SAG mill and crusher circuit simulations through the use of JKSimMet.  Independent of this it can be used in powerbased calculations, which in conjunction with the Bond ball work index test, enable the prediction of specific energy of comminution circuits where such circuits include combinations of any of the following equipment:



-  AG and SAG mills
-  Ball mills
-  Rod mills
-  Crushers
-  High Pressure Grinding Rolls (HPGR)

## B 2 EQUATIONS

## B 2.1 General

The approach divides comminution equipment into three categories:

Tumbling mills, eg AG, SAG, rod and ball mills

Conventional reciprocating crushers, eg jaw, gyratory and cone

HPGRs

Tumbling mills are described using 2 indices: Mia and Mib

Crushers have one index: Mic

HPGRs have one index: Mih

For tumbling mills the 2 indices relate to "coarse" and "fine" ore properties plus an efficiency factor which represents the influence of a pebble crusher in AG/SAG mill circuits.  "Coarse" in this case is defined as spanning the size range from a P80 of 750 microns up to the P80 of the product of the last stage of crushing or HPGR size reduction prior to grinding. "Fine" covers the size range from a P80 of 750 microns

down to P80 sizes typically reached by conventional ball milling, ie about 45 microns. The choice of 750 microns as the division between "coarse" and "fine" particle sizes was determined during the development of the technique and was found to give the best overall results across the range of plants in SMCC's data base.  Implicit in the approach is that distributions are parallel and linear in log-log space.

The work index covering grinding in tumbling mills of coarse sizes is labelled Mia. The work index covering grinding of fine particles is labelled Mib (Morrell, 2008).  Mia values are provided as a standard output from a SMC Test® (Morrell, 2004a) whilst Mib values can be determined using the data generated by a conventional Bond ball mill work index test (Mib is NOT the Bond ball work index). Mic and Mih values are also provided as a standard output from a SMC Test® (Morrell, 2009).

The general size reduction equation is as follows (Morrell, 2004b):

## B 2.2.3 Specific Energy Correction for Size Distribution (Ws)

Implicit in the approach described in this paper is that the feed and product size distributions are parallel and linear in log-log space.  Where they are not, allowances (corrections) need to be made.  By and large, such corrections are most likely to be necessary (or are large enough to be warranted) when evaluating circuits in which closed circuit secondary/tertiary crushing is followed by ball milling.  This is because such crushing circuits tend to produce a product size distribution which is relatively steep when compared to the ball mill circuit cyclone overflow.  This is illustrated in Figure A1, which shows measured distributions from an open and closed crusher circuit as well as a ball mill cyclone overflow.  The closed circuit crusher distribution can be seen to be relatively steep compared with the open circuit crusher distribution and ball mill cyclone overflow.  Also the open circuit distribution more closely follows the gradient of the cyclone overflow.  If a ball mill circuit were to be fed 2 distributions, each with same P80 but with the open and closed circuit gradients in Figure A1, the closed circuit distribution would require more energy to grind to the final P80.  How much more energy is required is difficult to determine.  However, for the purposes of this approach it has been assumed that the additional specific energy for ball milling is the same as the difference in specific energy between open and closed crushing to reach the nominated ball mill feed size.  This assumes that a crusher would provide this energy.  However, in this situation the ball mill has to supply this energy and it has a different (higher) work index than the crusher (ie the ball mill is less energy efficient than a crusher and has to input more energy to do the same amount of size reduction).  Hence from equation 7, to crush to the ball mill circuit feed size (x2) in open circuit requires specific energy equivalent to:

*

<!-- formula-not-decoded -->

For closed circuit crushing the specific energy is:

*

<!-- formula-not-decoded -->

The difference between the two (eq 10 - eq 11) has to be provided by the milling circuit with an allowance for the fact that the ball mill, with its lower energy efficiency, has to provide it and not the crusher.  This is what is referred to in equation 3 as Ws and for the above example is therefore represented by:

*

<!-- formula-not-decoded -->

Note that in equation 12 Mic has been replaced with Mia, the coarse particle tumbling mill grinding work index.

In AG/SAG based circuits the need for Ws appears to be unnecessary as Figure A2 illustrates.  Primary crusher feeds often have the shape shown in Figure A2 and this has a very similar gradient to typical ball mill cyclone overflows.  A similar situation appears to apply with HPGR product size distributions, as illustrated in Figure A3.

Interestingly SMCC's data show that for HPGRs, closed circuit operation appears to require a lower specific energy to reach the same P80 as in open circuit, even though the distributions for open and closed circuit look to have almost identical gradients. Closer examination of the distributions in fact shows that in closed circuit the final product tends to have slightly less very fine material, which may account for the different energy requirements between the two modes of operation.  It is also possible that recycled material in closed circuit is inherently weaker than new feed, as it has already passed through the HPGR previously and may have sustained micro-cracking.  A reduction in the Bond ball mill work index as measured by testing HPGR products compared it to the Bond ball mill work index of HPGR feed has been noticed in many cases in the laboratory (see next section) and hence there is no reason to expect the same phenomenon would not affect the recycled HPGR screen oversize.

It follows from the above arguments that in HPGR circuits, which are typically fed with material from closed circuit secondary crushers, a similar feed size distribution correction should also be applied. However, as the secondary crushing circuit uses such a relatively small amount of energy compared to the rest of the circuit (as it crushes to a relatively coarse size) the magnitude of size distribution correction is very small indeed - much smaller than the error associated with the technique - and hence may be omitted in calculations.

## B 2.2.4 Weakening of HPGR Products

As mentioned in the previous section, laboratory experiments have been reported by various researchers in which the Bond ball work index of HPGR products is less than that of the feed.  The amount of this reduction appears to vary with both material type and the pressing force used. Observed reductions in the Bond ball work index have

%

typically been in the range 0-10%.  In the approach described in this paper no allowance has been made for such weakening.  However, if HPGR products are available which can be used to conduct Bond ball work index tests on then Mib values obtained from such tests can be used in equation 5.  Alternatively the Mib values from Bond ball mill work index tests on HPGR feed material can be reduced by an amount that the user thinks is appropriate.  Until more data become available from full scale HPGR/ball mill circuits it is suggested that, in the absence of Bond ball mill work index data on HPGR products, the Mib results from HPGR feed material are reduced by no more than 5% to allow for the effects of micro-cracking.

## B 3 VALIDATION

## B 3.1 Tumbling Mill Circuits

The approach described in the previous section was applied to over 120 industrial data sets. The results are shown in App Figure 8.  In all cases, the specific energy relates to the tumbling mills contributing to size reduction from the product of the final stage of crushing to the final grind.  Data are presented in terms of equivalent specific energy at the pinion.  In determining what these values were on each of the plants in the data base it was assumed that power at the pinion was 93.5% of the measured gross (motor input) power, this figure being typical of what is normally accepted as being reasonable to represent losses across the motor and gearbox. For gearless drives (so-called wrap-around motors) a figure of 97% was used.

App Figure 8  - Observed vs Predicted Tumbling Mill Specific Energy

<!-- image -->

## B 3.2 Conventional Crushers

Validation of equation 1 used 12 different crushing circuits (25 data sets), including secondary, tertiary and pebble crushers in AG/SAG circuits.  Observed vs predicted specific energies are given in App Figure 9.  The observed specific energies were calculated from the crusher throughput and the net power draw of the crusher as defined by:

Net Power =

Motor Input Power - No Load Power

(13)

No-load power tends to be relatively high in conventional crushers and hence net power is significantly lower than the motor input power.  From examination of the 25 crusher data sets the motor input power was found to be on average 20% higher than the net power.

App Figure 9  - Observed vs Predicted Conventional Crusher Specific Energy

<!-- image -->

## B 3.3 HPGRs

Validation of equation 1 for HPGRs used data from 19 different circuits (36 data sets) including laboratory, pilot and industrial scale equipment. Observed vs predicted specific energies are given in App Figure 10.  The data relate to HPGRs operating with specific grinding forces typically in the range 2.5-3.5 N/mm .  The observed 2 specific energies relate to power delivered by the roll drive shafts.  Motor input power for full scale machines is expected to be 8-10% higher.

## Executive Summary

A  single composite  sample  from  the  Elk Creek  project was  submitted for bench-scale HPGR characterization.    The  sample  was  first  submitted  for  a  series  of  batch  HPGR  tests  which  investigated various operating parameters followed by a locked-cycle test, to evaluate the  HPGR performance in a closed circuit.  The results from the HPGR locked-cycle test, which was performed at 2% moisture and initial nitrogen and hydraulic pressures of 38 and 56 bars, respectively, are summarized in Table 1.  The test was closed with a 10 mesh (1.7 mm) screen.

Table 1: HPGR Locked-cycle Test Summary

| Sample ID   |   Closing  Screen Size  (mm) |   Pressure  Circul.  of Oper.  (bar) |   Load  (%) |   Net Spec.  Energy Requ.  (kWh/t) | P80  (µm)   |   % Passing  100 Mesh |   Specific  Grinding Force  (N/mm 2 ) |   Spec.  Throughput  (ts/hm ) (mf) 3 |
|-------------|------------------------------|--------------------------------------|-------------|------------------------------------|-------------|-----------------------|---------------------------------------|--------------------------------------|
| HPGR Comp   |                          1.7 |                                   63 |       157.5 |                               3.65 | 1,269       |                  28.6 |                                  3.14 |                                  311 |

The net specific power requirement of 3.65 kWh/t was amongst the highest value in the SGS database, but  is  likely  due  to  the  relatively  fine  closing  screen  size  used  in  the  locked-cycle  test  (1.7  mm).    The specific grinding force of 3.14 N/mm  fell near the median of the SGS database, while the sample was 2 categorized  as  very  soft  in  terms  of  the  specific  throughput  rate  (311  ts/hm 3 ).    The  HPGR  testwork showed that this sample is amenable for HPGR grinding.

Higher  pressure  should  be  considered  to  lower  the  current  high  circulating  load  (158%)  produced  by screening at 1.7 mm.

It  is  recommended to perform preliminary HPGR sizing in order to compare the HPGR scenario to the single stage SAG mill simulations presented in SGS report 14379-008A (issued October 31, 2016).  The specific power requirement from the bench-scale HPGR test and the single-stage SAG mill simulations cannot  be  directly  compared  at  the  moment  as  the  feed  F80's  are  significantly  different.    To  compare HPGR power requirement to the SAG milling option, additional power required to 1) crush the ore from the gyratory crusher product to a feed suitable for the HPGR (top size depends on the HPGR size unit), and 2) account for the extra conveyors, will need to be included.

## Introduction

Mr.  Arun  Vathavooran  from Tetra Tech,  on  behalf  of  NioCorp  Developments  Ltd  (NioCorp),  requested that SGS Minerals Services (SGS) perform a High Pressure Grinding Rolls (HPGR) grindability study on a single sample from the Elk Creek project, located in Nebraska, USA.

This report summarizes the sample preparation and presents the grindability test results.

## Testwork Summary

## 1. Sample Preparation

Twelve pails were received at the SGS Lakefield site on November 14, 2016.  The shipment was given the SGS sample receipt number 0180-NOV16.  The sample weighed about 350 kg and was prepared as depicted in Figure 1, for the HPGR testing program.

Figure 1: Sample Preparation Diagram

<!-- image -->

## 2. HPGR Investigation

An HPGR batch investigation and an HPGR locked-cycle test were performed on a single sample labelled as 'HPGR Comp'.  The batch tests investigated the effects of pressure of operation and moisture content on  HPGR performance, whereas the  locked-cycle  test  established  closed-circuit  power  requirement  at steady state using the optimal operating parameters determined during the batch investigation.  The test results  are  discussed  in  the  following  sub-sections  and  the  complete  test  details  are  appended (Appendix A).

## 2.1. Feed Characteristics

A head sample was withdrawn for Specific Gravity (S.G.), bulk density, Particle Size Analysis (PSA), and 'as-received' moisture determinations.  The S.G. was measured using a gas pycnometer, while the bulk density was measured by vibrating a weighted sample for five minutes in a 1-L graduated cylinder, and recording the volume.  The HPGR feed characteristics are summarized in Table 2.  In addition to the F50 and F80 values, the percent passing 10 mesh (1.7 mm) and 100 mesh (150 microns) were also selected as key performance indicators.

Table 2: HPGR Feed Characteristics

## 2.2. LABWAL Characteristics and Test Procedure

The HPGR tests were run in the LABWAL unit, which is equipped with solid roll tires that are protected against wear by tungsten-carbide studs.  The principal characteristics of the unit are presented below.

Diameter of rolls

0.25 m

Width of rolls

0.10 m

Speed of rolls

0.57 rotation/second

The  unit  pressure  and  power  draw  were  measured  every  second  by  a  Bailey  DCS  system  and  were trended over the test period.  The HPGR was choke-fed.  The following data were recorded and reported:

-  Zero gap
-  Moisture content
-  Throughput rate
-  Specific throughput rate
-  Flake thickness (if present)
-  Flake density (if present)
-  Ore specific gravity (S.G.)
-  Ore bulk density
-  Preset nitrogen pressure
-  Initial hydraulic pressure
-  Operating hydraulic pressure
-  Gross, no-load and net power
-  Specific energy input
-  Feed and product particle size analyses

In the batch test procedure, a 10-kg test charge was processed through the HPGR to clean the rolls and apply an autogenous layer on the tungsten-carbide studs.  Seven tests were then carried out using 30-kg charges  at  different  pressure  settings  and  different  moisture  contents.    The  moisture  content  was adjusted each time by adding the proportion of water required to the sample and mixing it in a cement mixer.

For each test, the initial nitrogen and hydraulic pressures were recorded, as well as the feed sample wet weight.  The sample was choke-fed to the HPGR and the test duration was recorded with a stopwatch. The power draw and pressures of operation were recorded through the Bailey system.  The maximum movement of the rolls during operation was also recorded as part of the test.

The  HPGR  discharge  was  sampled  (three  cuts)  following  stabilization  (about  10  seconds),  and  the product flake thickness was measured with a ruler and recorded.  The product was submitted for moisture content and PSA determinations.

For the  locked-cycle  procedure, the  30-kg test charges  were set at the optimal moisture prior to each cycle.  Once processed through the HPGR, the product was discharged on a 10 mesh screen and the oversize was combined with the fresh feed for the next cycle.  This procedure was then repeated until the amount of oversize produced was stabilized for at least 3 cycles.  For each cycle, the initial nitrogen and hydraulic pressures were recorded, as well as the feed sample weight.

The HPGR circuit product, which corresponds to the screen undersize, was sampled and submitted for moisture content and PSA determinations for the last three cycles.  The flake thickness was measured with a ruler and was also recorded.  A sample of the flake was collected and submitted for bulk density determination, using the waxing method.  The wax protects the sample from breaking up when immersed in  water and prevents the water from filling the voids in the flake.  The flake specimens were weighed before and after coating with wax, prior to S.G. determination, using the water displacement technique. The  weight  and  volume  of  the  wax  were  known,  so  the  actual  bulk  density  of  the  flake  could  be calculated.

Seven batch tests were performed using different pressure settings and moisture contents, followed by a locked-cycle test to establish closed-circuit performance. ## 2.3.1. Particle Size Analyses

The feed and product PSA's are presented in Figure 2.  The solid lines represent the batch tests, while the dotted lines represent the locked-cycle test.

Figure 2: HPGR Feed and Product Particle Size Distributions

<!-- image -->

## 2.3.2. Specific Grinding Force

The specific grinding force corresponds to the hydraulic force between the rolls per unit of area and is expressed in N/mm .  For a given HPGR unit, it is directly related to the hydraulic pressure, as presented 2 in  Figure  3.    Higher  forces  normally  result  in  higher  power  draw  and  increased  size  reduction  up  to  a certain point.

Figure 3: Specific Grinding Force versus Hydraulic Pressure

<!-- image -->

## 2.3.3. Specific Throughput Rate

The specific throughput rate corresponds to the throughput of  the HPGR unit  per unit  of roll area and speed.  It is normalized to a 1 m x 1 m HPGR (Diameter x Width) operated at 1 m/s.  This normalized throughput is ore-dependent and varies with operating conditions, but is essentially independent of the rolls'  geometry  and  speed,  and  can  therefore  be  used  for  scale-up  to  industrial  size.    The  relationship between  the  specific  grinding  force  and  the  specific  throughput  is  presented  in  Figure 4.    Specific throughput decreased with higher pressure and with moisture, which is typical.

Figure 4: Specific Throughput Rate versus Specific Grinding Force

<!-- image -->

## 2.3.4. Net Power Draw and Net Specific Power

The  net  power  draw  is  defined  as  the  energy  of  comminution,  i.e.  the  gross  power  requirement  as measured by the Bailey system less the power required to drive the rolls empty (no-load power).  The additional power applied is that which actually achieves comminution.  The effect of the specific grinding force of the LABWAL net power is presented in Figure 5.  The net specific power requirement, in kWh/t, corresponds  to  the  net  power  divided  by  the  actual  throughput  rate.    It  is  plotted  against  the  specific grinding force in Figure 6.  Power requirement increased with higher grinding force.

Figure 5: Effect of Specific Grinding Force on the LABWAL Net Power

<!-- image -->

Figure 6: Net Specific Power Input as a Function of Specific Grinding Force

<!-- image -->

The net power requirement for the locked-cycle test was significantly higher (3.65 kWh/t) than for similar conditions in batch mode (1.68 kWh/t), which is the effect of the additional power required to achieve a 100% passing 10 mesh (1.7 mm) product.  The moisture had no significant impact on the net power draw, but did for the net specific energy (lower throughput rate with higher moisture content).

## 2.3.5. Product Size

The LABWAL product sizes, as percent passing 10 and 100 mesh, are presented based on the specific grinding force and the specific energy input in Figure 7 and Figure 8.  Higher grinding forces and specific energy inputs increased fineness and did not reach a plateau for the range investigated.

Figure 7: Effect of Specific Grinding Force on HPGR Product PSA

<!-- image -->

Figure 8: Effect of Net Specific Energy Input on HPGR Product

<!-- image -->

## 2.3.6. Overall HPGR Test Results

The locked-cycle test results are compared to the SGS database in Figure 9.  At a specific grinding force of  3.14  N/mm , the sample used a pressure corresponding to the 60 2 th percentile  of  the  SGS  database (meaning that 60% of all the locked-cycle tests used a lower pressure).  The HPGR Comp sample fell in the  soft  range  of  the  SGS  database  in  terms  of  the  specific  throughput  (m ),  falling  around  the  15 f th percentile.  The high specific throughput rate achieved by the HPGR Comp is partially due to the feed S.G.  of  3.13  kg/L.    However,  it  was  categorized  as  very  hard  with  respect  to  net  specific  energy requirement (kWh/t), falling in the 97 th percentile  of the database.  This is probably partially due to the relatively fine closing screen size used in the locked-cycle test (1.7 mm), while most of the data points from the database were completed at a much coarser screen size of 3.35 mm.

Figure 9: HPGR Locked-cycle Test Database

<!-- image -->

## Executive Summary

This study examined various mineral processing routes to pre-concentrate niobium from the Elk Creek deposit located in Nebraska, including gravity, magnetic separation, roasting, and flotation approaches. Head assays (whole rock analysis, niobium, tantalum and zircon) for the two main samples tested are presented in Table 1. In addition to the head assays presented in Table 1, the 'Nb Comp' contained 63 g/t of Scandium. Full head analysis of both samples has been presented in the body of the report. Testwork was also conducted on an ore sample provided by Hazen Research, and assay reject material was used in the operation of a mini-flotation pilot plant.
