## Mineralogy of Test Samples

Testwork was conducted on two different samples from the deposit and labeled Nb Comp and the 2 nd Nb Drill  Core. The  two  samples  were  found  to  have  similar  mineralogy,  although  minor  differences  are recorded:

- o Carbonates  (51%  and  62%),  Fe-oxides  (10%  and  5%),  quartz/feldspars  (7%  and  11%),  biotite (3% and 4%), Fe-(Ti)-oxides (2%), barite (15-10%), sulphides (2-1%), and trace amounts of other minerals. Note that both magnetite and hematite were identified with XRD analysis.

At  a  grind  of  100%  passing  212 μ m,  the  D 50 (50%  passing  value  from  the  cumulative  grain  size distribution) shows that the niobium minerals are &lt;20 μ m in size and that pyrochlore carries most of the niobium (78%-82%), followed by niobium-rutile (11%-12%) and ilmenorutile (10%-6%). Free and liberated pyrochlore  accounts  for  23%  and  37%  in  the  Nb  Comp  and  2 nd Nb  Drill  Core  Head,  respectively. Pyrochlore liberation is significant at 48% and 57% in the -25 μ m fraction of the Nb Comp and 2 nd Nb Drill Core  Head,  respectively,  indicating  a  need  for  fine  grinding.    Greater  than  30%  exposure  of  niobium minerals is 39% and 48% in the Nb Comp and 2 nd Nb Drill Core Head, respectively, indicating that there is not a large portion of available surface for flotation of the niobium minerals.

The two samples yield similar theoretical grade and recovery values at a grind size of 100% passing 212 μ m.  Thus, grades of 7%-17% for recoveries of 24%-51%, respectively, are projected for the Nb Comp, and grades of 6%-16% for recoveries of 36%-60% for the 2 nd Nb Drill Core Head.

## Heavy Liquid and Magnetic Separation Testing

Results from heavy liquid separation (HLS) testing suggest that gravity separation would likely not be an efficient method of upgrading the Elk Creek ore, due to lack of niobium mineral liberation at sizes suitable for  such  processing  methods.  Likewise,  magnetic  separation  (both  low-intensity  (LIMS)  and  wet  highintensity (WHIMS)) was not successful in effectively upgrading the Nb Comp feed material, likely due to a lack of niobium mineral liberation at 100% passing 150 mesh, and the deportment of niobium to magnetic and paramagnetic minerals.

## Flotation Testing

After  testing  many  different  niobium  mineral  collectors  and  various  conceptual  flotation  flowsheets, benzohydroxamic acid (Florrea 7510 collector) was found to yield the best flotation performance when used in  conjunction  with  sodium  hexametaphosphate  (Calgon)  as  a  dispersant  and  carbonate  mineral depressant.  The  final  flotation  flowsheet  included  grinding  using  an  IsaMill  to  100%  passing  38 µm followed by a simple rougher flotation circuit, which recovered a large portion of niobium and titanium, while  effectively  rejecting  approximately  80-85%  of  the  mass,  containing  a  large  portion  of  carbonate minerals.

The final flotation  flowsheet is  illustrated  in  Figure  1.  To  obtain  71.3%  niobium  recovery  in  19%  of  the mass, a total of eight rougher flotation stages were required with reagent addition prior to each rougher stage.  Limiting  the  circuit  to  only  seven  rougher  stages,  a  combined  rougher  concentrate  with  68.1% niobium recovery in 16.5% of the mass was obtained. The total collector addition rates for seven and eight rougher flotation stages were 950 g/t and 1,050 g/t, respectively.

<!-- image -->

Concentrate

Use  of  the  Elk  Creek  ground  water  in  the  flotation  circuit  showed  no  adverse  effects  on  flotation performance. Pulp temperature was 30-35 C, in the range of grinding discharge temperatures. Flotation o pulp pH was not adjusted, but was recorded to be between 7.7-8.5, depending on the water used (Elk Creek ground water versus SGS Lakefield tap water). Fluctuation of pH in the range stated above did not appear to have a significant effect on flotation results.

## Recommendations for Future Testwork

It has been demonstrated that the collector and dispersant/depressant dosage are of utmost importance.

Prior to running a full scale pilot plant, it would be highly beneficial to run a statistically designed set of batch flotation tests with the objective of optimizing collector dosage, mass pull, niobium recovery, and the ratio of collector to depressant. This set of experiments would provide detailed information and allow for  rough  predictions  of  flotation  mass  pull  and  niobium  recovery  for  given  reagent  dosages  through mathematical modelling. Not only will this information help to achieve the best possible results from the

full scale pilot plant, it will prove invaluable to NioCorp Developments Ltd. and consultants through plant design and economic analysis.

In  addition,  a  trade-off  study  on  the  effect  of  IsaMill  versus  conventional  grinding  on  flotation  is recommended. This study should be executed with both grinding types targeting 100% passing 38 µm; subsequent flotation should follow the final recommended flotation flowsheet and reagent scheme. The results  will  help  to  minimize  grinding  costs  and/or  optimize  flotation  performance  in  the  process  plant design for the Elk Creek deposit.

Overall, the current recommended mineral processing flowsheet is quite simple, and as such, valuable information could be obtained and cost reduction may be realized through basic optimization testwork and trade-off  studies  on  a  representative  sample  and/or  variability  samples,  ideally  conducted  prior  to  the commissioning of a full scale pilot plant.

A  separate  study  should  investigate  the  flotation  response  of  geometallurgical  test  units  to  gauge metallurgical variability across the mineralization.

## Introduction

Neil McCallum and Darren Smith of Dahrouge met with members of SGS on February 11, 2014 at the Lakefield  site  to  review  SGS  mineralogical  findings  on  samples  from  the  Elk  Creek  deposit  located  in Nebraska. Effective February 20, 2015, NioCorp has announced the Elk Creek deposit to be an NI43-101 compliant resource reporting an Indicated Resource of 80.5 million tonnes grading 0.71% Nb2O5, 2.68% TiO2 and 72 ppm Sc and an Inferred Resource of 99.6 million tonnes grading 0.56% Nb2O5, 2.31% TiO2 and 63 ppm Sc (at a 0.3% Nb2O5 cutoff grade). Mineralogical characterization indicates that the niobium occurs  in  a  variety  of  minerals,  but  most  notably  a  Fe-Ti-Nb-oxide  phase  and  pyrochlore.  Liberation characteristics reveal that grain sizes are fine and that metallurgical flowsheet development was likely to be challenging.

A scope of work for a preliminary metallurgical test program was discussed. The objective of this program was to develop a conceptual flowsheet to treat a sample, representative of the Elk Creek deposit. The study  was  to  examine  various  processing  routes  to  concentrate  niobium  including  gravity,  magnetic separation, and flotation approaches. In addition, basic leach testing on whole ore would be completed to provide an indication of the success of niobium extraction.

The sample was received at SGS in Lakefield in April of 2014.  Sample preparation and metallurgical testwork,  as  outlined  in  the  original  proposal,  began  shortly  thereafter.  In  October  of  2014,  based  on discussions  with  Darren  Smith,  a  change  of  scope  was  executed  with  the  objective  to  perform complementary  testing  on  the  drill  core  samples,  and  leach  residue  with  the  same  objective  as  was defined  in  the  earlier  proposal:  70%  niobium  recovery  in  15%  mass  pull,  minimizing  collector  7510 dosage to 1,500 g/t or less, and identify a better and more selective collector.  This complimentary work continued into early 2015. The results from the original proposal and the change of scope from the end of October, 2014 are included in this report.

## Testwork Summary

## 1. Sample Receipt and Description

## 1.1. Sample Receipt and Preparation

In  April  of  2014,  one  skid  of  samples  was  received  at  the  SGS  Lakefield  site  and  assigned  the  SGS receipt  number  0022-APR14.  A  total  of  210  kg  of  the  sample  was  received  in  the  form  of  drill  core intervals placed in two drums. The core sample was identified as Nb Comp .

The material in the two drums was weighed, recorded, and combined to form a composite. The composite was stage-crushed to ½'. A 15 kg sub-sample was removed from the ½' material for Bond Rod mill Work Index  (RWI)  testing.  A  5  kg  sub-sample  of  -¾'+½'  was  split  out  for  Abrasion  Index  (AI)  testing. Approximately 120 kg of -½' material was split out and further stage-crushed to 100% passing 6 mesh. The minus 6 mesh material was homogenized, and an 8 kg sub-sample was removed for Bond Ball mill Work Index (BWI) testing. The remainder of the minus 6 mesh material was then split into 10 kg and 2 kg charges. A total of ten 10 kg charges and five 2 kg charges were prepared for the composite. One of the 2 kg charges was selected (randomly) for head characterization. A 150 g head assay sample was split out  from  the  2  kg  charge  and  submitted  for  niobium,  tantalum,  zirconium,  whole  rock  analysis  (WRA), carbon speciation (C(t), C(g), CO , TOC), sulphur speciation (S(t), S , SO , S°), ICP-OES multi element 3 = 4 scan, ICP-MS rare earth scan, and ISE (fluorine). A 200 g mineralogical sample was taken and submitted for QEMSCAN analysis in PMA (Particle Mineral Analysis) mode.  Furthermore, a 300 g sub-sample was submitted for head particle size analysis. All test charges as well as the remainders of -½' and minus 6 mesh materials, with a weight of ~73 kg and ~1.1 kg, respectively, were stored for future testing.

In July of 2014, a second sample shipment was received at the SGS Lakefield site. One drum containing approximately  250  kg  of  core  material  was  identified  as 2 nd Nb  Drill  Core .  This  material  was  stagecrushed to 100% passing 6 mesh. The minus 6 mesh material was homogenized and split into 10 kg and 2 kg charges, one of which was taken randomly for head characterization. A 150 g head assay sample was  split  out  and  submitted  for  niobium,  WRA  assays,  and  ICP-OES  multi  element  scan.  A  200  g mineralogical  sample  was  also  taken  and  submitted  for  QEMSCAN  analysis  in  PMA  (Particle  Mineral Analysis) mode.  All test charges, as well as the remainders of -½' and minus 6 mesh materials were stored for future testing.

## 1.3.4. IsaMill

The 2 nd Nb Drill Core material was initially submitted to batch regrinding in an IsaMill to generate material at a K98 of ~ 20 microns.  The testing was performed in a closed loop, and Malvern size analyses were performed periodically to determine the grind size.  When the target was reached, the ground product was submitted for further testing.

It  was  then  requested  to perform an IsaMill signature plot test on the sample to determine the energy requirement to grind to various sizes.  Further batches of the sample were then reground in the IsaMill to the  required  sizes,  using  the  results  of  the  signature  plot.    The  mill  description,  along  with  the  testing procedure  and  results,  are  given  in  the  following  sub-sections.    The  IsaMill  test  details  are  appended (Appendix A).

Prior to being submitted to IsaMill testing, minus 10 mesh charges of the sample were stage-ground in a rod mill  to  generate  an  IsaMill  feed  with  a  K 98 of ~ 150 microns, which was a suitable size to feed the IsaMill and to efficiently grind the sample to the target size while only using one media type in the IsaMill.

## 1.3.4.1. IsaMill Description and Testing Procedure

The IsaMill, developed by Xstrata Technology, is a high intensity, compact, continuous ultra-fine grinding technology, with demonstrated direct (1:1) scale-up.  A steep particle size distribution is produced in open circuit  operation,  without  the  use  of  troublesome,  fine  separating  screens.    Figure  5  presents  the operating principle of the IsaMill.  The inside configuration of the mill is designed such that there is an

internal classification that keeps the grinding media inside the mill, while the pulp is discharged at the mill outlet.  The bench-scale unit at SGS is a 4 L IsaMill, equivalent to the LMK 4 Netzsch mill.

Figure 5: Grinding and Internal Classification Mechanisms of an IsaMill 1

<!-- image -->

The  relationship  between  product  size  and  energy  input  remains  constant  during  scale-up  of  IsaMill technology.  As the diameter of a particle is halved, the surface area of its progeny is doubled.  Within reasonable reduction ratios, the log of size plotted against the log of energy produces a straight line.  This line can be extrapolated within the limits of media efficiency and viscosity.  This plot is referred to as a signature plot, and is unique to the ore, pulp conditions, and media selected.

The power draw is measured every minute, which allows trending of these values over the test period. The test investigates the energy required to grind a sample to a pre-determined size.  For the test, the following data were recorded and reported:

-  Feed % solids
-  Feed and product pulp densities and viscosities
-  Throughput rate
-  Number of passes required
-  Specific energy input
-  Specific energy input versus P 80 curve
-  Feed and product particle size analyses

The viscosity of the sample is measured during each pass using a Marsh funnel.  If the material becomes too viscous, the efficiency of the IsaMill decreases.  If the sample takes longer than 38 seconds to flow through the Marsh funnel, the pulp density of the sample must be decreased for the next pass by adding water.  Each data point on the curve corresponds to one 'pass' in the mill, in which the sample is entirely processed at a given kWh/t input.  The product from each pass is collected at steady-state and analyzed with the Malvern, prior to re-passing in the mill to generate further data points.  This is performed as many times as required to generate the signature curve.

Development of the signature plot is used to design large-scale IsaMills.  Most large-scale installations have been designed from a signature plot developed in a 4 L laboratory continuous mill.  The 4 L test must reflect the media and pulp conditions planned for full-scale operation, or full-scale design can be based on the most efficient signature plot developed during the testwork.

The experimental set up is presented in Figure 6.  It consists of an agitated feed tank, connected through a  pump  to  the  IsaMill,  which  discharges  into  a  second  agitated  tank.    For  each  pass,  the  circuit  is operated  at  a  given  flow  rate  and  density  in  order  to  achieve  a  target-specific  energy  input.    The  mill discharge  is  sampled  at  steady-state  and  the  product  is  submitted  for  particle  size  analysis  through  a Malvern sizer.  After the first pass, the product tank becomes the feed tank, and so on.

Figure 6: IsaMill Experimental Set-up

<!-- image -->

## 1.3.4.2. No-load Power

The IsaMill no-load power (i.e. the power required to run the mill empty) was measured before the test. The  mill  was  operated  without  slurry  and  grinding  media  for  about  30  minutes.    Before  the  no-load measurements were recorded, the mill was allowed to warm-up for 15 minutes.  The measurements were taken over a time of 15 minutes, and the results averaged.

The net power draw, which is used to scale-up the mill, is computed by subtracting the no-load power from the actual gross power measured during a test.  The measured no-load power was 0.71 kW.

## 1.3.4.3. Signature Plot Results

The IsaMill signature plot test was conducted on August 12, 2014.  The IsaMill was operated with the following parameters:

-  Mill speed of 1,500 rpm
-  2.5 L of 2 mm Keramax MTX grinding media

## 2. Mineralogical Characterization of Feed Sample

The Nb Comp and 2 nd Nb Drill Core were each submitted for quantitative analysis using QEMSCAN once received on site in Lakefield.

## 2.1. Summary of Observations

-  Both samples were stage-ground to K80 of 106 μ m. The analysis was conducted on three size fractions (+106 μ m, -106/+25 μ m, and -25 μ m).
-  The  Nb  Comp  and  the  2 nd Nb  Drill  Core  Head  consist  of  similar  mineralogy  although  minor differences are recorded.
- o Carbonates 51% and 62%, respectively, Fe Oxides (10% and 5%), quartz/feldspars (7% and 11%), biotite (3 and 4%), Fe-(Ti)-oxides (2%), barite (15-10%), sulphides (2-1%), and trace amounts of other minerals. Note that both magnetite and hematite were identified with XRD analysis.

-  The D50 (50% passing value from the cumulative grain size distribution) shows that the niobium minerals are &lt;20 μ m in size.
-  Pyrochlore  carries  most  of  the  Nb  (78%-82%),  followed  by  Nb-rutile  (11%-12%),  ilmenorutile (10%-6%).
-  Free and liberated pyrochlore accounts for 23% and 37% in the Nb Comp and 2 nd Nb Drill Core Head, respectively.  Pyrochlore liberation is significant at 48% and 57% in the -25 μ m fraction of the Nb Comp and 2 nd Nb Drill Core Head, respectively.
- o This indicates the need for fine grinding to liberate the niobium minerals.
-  Exposure of niobium minerals greater than 30% exposure is 39% and 48% in the Nb Comp and 2 nd Nb Drill Core Head.
- o This  indicates  that  there  is  not  a  lot  of  available  surface  for  flotation  of  the  niobium minerals.
-  The two samples yield similar theoretical grade and recovery values.  Thus, grades of 17%-7% for recoveries of 24%-51%, respectively, are projected for the Nb Comp, and grades of 16%-6% for recoveries of 36%-60% for the 2nd Nb Drill Core Head.

## 2.2. Mineral Abundance

The  mineral  abundances  of  the  calculated  head  for  the  samples  are  graphically  shown  in  Figure  8. Mineral abundance is given in wt%.

The Nb Comp and the 2 nd Nb Drill Core Head consists of similar mineralogy although minor differences are recorded. Carbonates 51% and 62%, respectively, Fe Oxides (10% and 5%), quartz/feldspars (7% and 11%), biotite (3 and 4%), Fe-(Ti)-oxides (2%), barite (15-10%), sulphides (2-1%), and trace amounts of other minerals.

The main difference in the niobium mineral abundance is the mass of ilmenorutile. However, given the fine grained nature of the sample and the variability in chemistry, the mass of Nb-rutile and ilmenorutile may vary significantly.

## 2.5. Liberation and Association of Pyrochlore and Nb-minerals

Liberation  and  association  data  for  pyrochlore  and  niobium  minerals (pyrochlore,  ilmenorutile,  and  Nbrutile)  and  image  grids  of  the  pyrochlore  association  are  presented  in  Figure  10.    Free  and  liberated pyrochlore (&gt;80% of surface area free) accounts for 23% and 37% in the Nb Comp and 2 nd Nb Drill Core Head,  respectively.    Liberation  of  the  niobium  minerals  is  lower  at  19%  and  24%,  respectively.  The niobium  minerals  occur  mainly  as  binary  and  ternary  (particles  containing  two  and  three  different minerals, respectively) middling particles with carbonates, silicates, Fe-(Ti)-oxides and barite.  It is noted that liberation of pyrochlore in the Nb Comp is 3%, 13%, and 48% for the +106 μ m, -106/+25 μ m, and -25 μ m, respectively, and nil, 18%, and 57%, respectively for the 2 nd Nb Drill Core Head.

Exposure of niobium minerals greater than 30% exposure is 39% and 48% in the Nb Comp and 2 nd Nb Drill Core Head, respectively (Figure 11).

## 2.6. Grade-Recovery Curves

Figure  13  illustrates  the  grade-recovery  curves  for  the  samples  based  on  the  liberation  of  niobium minerals  at  a  P 80 of  106  µm.    The  two  samples  yield  similar  theoretical  grades  and  recovery  values. Thus, grades of 17%-7% for recoveries of 24%-51% are projected for the Nb Comp, and grades of 16%6%  for  recoveries  of  36%-60%  for  the  2 nd Nb  Drill  Core  Head.  Note  these  values  are  based  on  the average niobium concentration in the pyrochlore, ilmenorutile, and Nb-rutile from the electron microprobe analyses and their respective liberation values. Thus, they may vary given the wide variation of niobium in the ilmenorutile and Nb-rutile. Note that based on the mineralogy developed grade-recovery curve, in an ideal separation in order to achieve niobium recovery close to 70%, concentrate grade will not exceed approximately 4.8% Nb. This grade of concentrate is not acceptable for pyrometallurgical conversion to ferroniobium without further processing.

Figure 13:  Mineralogy Developed Niobium Grade-Recovery Curves

## 3. Magnetic Separation Testing

## 3.1. Magnetic Separation on Head Sample

Due to the presence of magnetic (magnetite) and paramagnetic (hematite, ilmenite) minerals in the Elk Creek  ore,  magnetic  separation  testing  was  completed  on  a  6  kg  sample  of  Nb  Comp  material.  The sample  was  stage  ground  to  100%  passing  150  mesh,  and  then  subjected  to  low  intensity  magnetic separation (LIMS) to remove magnetic minerals and wet high intensity magnetic separation (WHIMS) to remove paramagnetic minerals. The LIMS test was performed on the whole 6 kg sample at approximately 1,000 Gauss cleaned once at the same intensity, while the WHIMS test was performed on a 500 g subsample split out from the LIMS Non-Mags. The sub-sample was successively re-passed through an Eriez WHIMS separator with a steel matrix at 4,000, 7,500, 12,500, and 20,000 Gauss. All products from both LIMS and WHIMS tests were submitted for Nb2O5 assay and WRA (whole rock analysis). The test results are summarized in Table 10 and Table 11. All magnetic separation data is also presented in Appendix B.

Figure  14  illustrates  the  recovery  of  various  elements  at  different  magnetic  intensities  in  WHIMS. Figure 15 illustrates the separation performance of the WHIMS tests with mass pull versus recovery and grade versus recovery relationships. No efficient separation of niobium was observed in the tests.  From Table 10, the LIMS Mags recovered ~16% of the Nb2O5 which was directly proportional to the mass pull of the Mags at ~14%.  Nb2O5 recovery to the WHIMS Mags was also proportional to mass pull.

Overall, magnetic separation (both LIMS and WHIMS) was not successful in effectively upgrading the Nb Comp material, likely due to a lack of niobium mineral liberation at 100% passing 150 mesh, and the deportment of niobium to magnetic and paramagnetic minerals.

## 4. Heavy Liquid Separation Testing

Heavy liquid separation (HLS) testing was performed on Nb Comp material from the Elk Creek deposit to identify  the  potential  of  gravity  separation  as  a  unit  process  in  the  flowsheet.  Approximately  2.5  kg  of sample was initially stage-ground to 100% passing 212 µm and then separated into four different size fractions of -212/+150 µm, -150/+75 µm,-75/+38 µm, and -38 µm. Each size fraction was submitted for HLS at specific gravities (SG) of 3.30, 3.10, 2.90, and 2.80 g/cm . The float and sink products were then 3 submitted for Nb O5 2 analysis and WRA.

Table 12 summarizes the HLS results on each of the individual size fractions, Table 13 summarizes the HLS results for all combined size fractions in terms of sink products and Table 14 summarizes the HLS results for all combined size fractions in terms of float products.  Figure 16 illustrates the distribution of the cumulative  sink  products  at  different  SGs.  Figure  17  illustrates  the  distribution  of  the  cumulative  sink products at different SGs for each individual size fraction.

The results indicate that niobium recovery is closely related to mass recovery and limited upgrading was observed at any size fraction without significant niobium losses. At an SG cut point of 3.10, 72% Nb O 2 5 was recovered to the sink product in 51% of the mass in the -212/+150 µm fraction, 76.4% Nb2O5 was recovered in 52% of the mass in the -150/+75 µm fraction, 71.3% Nb2 O5 was recovered in 45% mass in the -75/+38 µm fraction, and 98% Nb O5 was recovered in 96.3% mass in the -38 µm fraction. 2

## 5. Flowsheet Development

## 5.1. Flotation Feed Sample Preparation

Feed for flotation was prepared by stage grinding minus 6 mesh feed material to the required grind size. Stage-grinding  of  the  material  was  conducted  in  a  10  kg  laboratory  rod  mill  using  stainless  steel  rod charges, beginning with 10 kg dry equivalent charges at 65% solids pulp density. The charge was first screened  to  remove  any  undersize  material  at  a  specified  cut  size.  The  oversize  material  was  then charged to the mill and ground for approximately 10 minutes, targeting a passing fraction yield of 30-40%

weight after grinding.  Material  was  removed  from the  mill  and  passed  through  the  appropriate  screen. Oversize  material  was  returned  to  the  mill  for  another  10  minutes  while  the  undersized  material  was filtered. Grinding was repeated in approximately 10 minute intervals. Water addition was adjusted based on the weight of oversize returning to the mill in order to maintain 65% solids. Once the oversize material was less  than  4  kg,  the  stage-grinding  procedure  was  continued  in  the  4  kg  laboratory  rod  mill;  once below 2 kg, oversize material stage-grinding was carried out in the 2 kg laboratory rod mill. Stage-grinding was  carried  out  until  the  entirety  of  the  10  kg  sample  passed  the  selected  screen  size.  The  ground material was filtered and spilt into equal 2 kg or 4 kg charges for flotation.

Grind size was adjusted throughout Phase 1 based on mineralogy and flotation test results. A laboratory scale IsaMill was used to more efficiently grind flotation feed to 100% passing 38 microns for later batch flotation tests. For IsaMill grinding, approximately 30 kg batches of minus 6 mesh materials was ground at 65% solids. A particle size distribution of the recycle streams was obtained in regular time intervals using a  Malvern  Mastersizer  during  grinding  until  the  material  reached  the  target  grind  size,  at  which  point grinding  was  stopped  and  material  was  filtered  and  made  into  equal,  representative  4  kg  flotation charges.

## 5.2. Flotation Batch Tests

A  total  of  136  flotation  tests  were  conducted.  All  flotation  test  conditions  and  full  mass  balances  are presented in Appendix D. For reporting purposes, batch flotation testwork will be discussed in terms of the  final flotation flowsheet  which  was  developed  through  initial  scoping  work,  which  constitutes approximately the first 49 tests of the test program and then optimization tests, which cover the remaining tests  (up  to  test  F136).  For  the  most  part,  the  latter  half  of  this  test  program  deals  with  making improvements  to,  and  optimizing  the  reagent  scheme/flowsheet  developed  in  the  first  49  tests.  A comprehensive  list  of  all  reagents  used  in  the  entirety  of  the  test  program  can  be  found  in  Table  15 through Table 19.

## 5.2.1. Final Flotation Flowsheet

The final flotation flowsheet included a rougher flotation circuit, which recovered a large portion of niobium and  titanium,  while  effectively  rejecting  approximately  80-85%  of  the  mass  which  contained  a  large portion of  carbonate minerals. The objective of this flowsheet was to produce a low-mass concentrate with sufficient niobium recovery to minimize reagent consumption in downstream processing.

The final flotation flowsheet, along with reagent addition rates to each stage can be found in Figure 18. Feed was ground to 100% passing 38 µm (by IsaMill), and conditioned for 2 minutes at 50% solids with Calgon (or sodium hexametaphosphate), a depressant/dispersant, and lead nitrate as a niobium mineral activator.  The  slurry  was  then  conditioned  for  5  minutes  with  collector  Florrea  7510.  Since  no  definite conclusion regarding the benefit of lead nitrate addition has been made, this reagent has been left in the flowsheet, as it was used in the final batch tests.

Figure 18: Final Flotation Flowsheet

<!-- image -->

To  obtain  71.3%  niobium  recovery  in  19%  of  the  mass,  a  total  of  eight  rougher  flotation  stages  were required  with  reagent  addition  prior  to  each  rougher  stage.  Limiting  the  circuit  to  only  seven  rougher

stages,  a  combined  rougher  concentrate  with  68.1%  niobium  recovery  in  16.5%  of  the  mass  was obtained. The total collector addition rates for seven and eight rougher flotation stages were 950 g/t and 1,050 g/t, respectively. The above results were obtained using Elk Creek site groundwater in flotation. Pulp temperature was maintained at 30-35 C. Pulp pH ranged from 7.3-7.7; no pH adjustment was made. o

## 5.2.2. Initial Scoping Batch Flotation Tests

In  this  initial  scoping  study,  two  approaches  to  pyrochlore  flotation  were  assessed.  The  first  approach involved  the  direct  flotation  of  niobium  oxide  minerals  using  various  collectors.  The  most  common collector used in niobium mineral flotation is a cationic amine collector, often tallow diamine acetate. This reagent  is  used  to  selectively  float  pyrochlore  at  increasingly  acidic  pH.  The  lower  the  pH  in  the  final cleaning  stages,  the  higher  the  selectivity  of  the  amine  collector  for  niobium  minerals  over  silicate minerals.  However,  in  the  presence  of  a  great  deal  of  acid  consuming  carbonate  minerals  (such  as calcite, ankerite, and dolomite) it becomes difficult to control and maintain acidic pulp conditions. Thus, the second approach is to first float carbonate minerals using a fatty acid collector while niobium minerals are depressed with causticized corn starch. The tailings from the carbonate flotation circuit act as feed to the niobium circuit, where pyrochlore is floated under acidic conditions using an amine collector.

There are many other collectors that can be used to float niobium minerals, although their use is less common. Hydroxamates, succinimates, imadazoline, and diphosphonic acid have all been documented as selective collectors for niobium, iron, and titanium. Hydroxamates in particular are known to be strong chelating reagents which are selective for iron, titanium, niobium, and rare earths. Hydroxamates are also less sensitive to the presence of very fine material (slimes).

Based on the initial mineralogy report which identified niobium deportation to both pyrochlore and titanium oxide minerals, as well as highly complex pyrochlore which would likely necessitate fine grinding, different types of benzohydroxamic acid collector were tested first in conjuncution with Calgon for dispersion and carbonate mineral depression. These benzohydroxamic acids included:

- 1. Pure benzohydroxamic acid purchased from Alfa Aesar.
- 2. Benzohydroxamic  acid  product  known  as  BHD  from  an  unknown  Chinese  supplier,  which  is comprised of approximately 30% benzohydroxamic acid.

In further tests using benzohydroxamic acid, pulp temperature was adjusted to between 40 C and 50 C in o o order to improve collector dissolution, as well as facilitate collector adsorption on mineral surfaces. The results from some of these initial tests are presented in Figure 19.

Figure 19: Niobium Recovery as a Function of Mass Pull Using Different Benzohydroxamic Acid Collectors

<!-- image -->

F11, which used pure benzohydroxamic acid as a collector produced a first cleaner concentrate with a mass pull of 25.7% and 75.8% niobium recovery.

The 1  cleaner concentrate from F13 contained 22.9% mass with 68.4% recovery. Results from these st tests  can  be  found  in  Table  20  and  Table  21.    The  1 st cleaner  and  1 st cleaner  scavenger  combined concentrate from F13 was leached using hydrochloric acid at 50 C for four hours before being passed o through  wet  high  intensity  magnetic  separation  at  various  intensities.  The  intention  of  this  test  was  to improve iron oxide (and other paramagnetic mineral) liberation prior to magnetic separation through the leaching  of  carbonate  minerals. From these tests it was observed that:

-  Recovery  improved  with  a  decrease  in  grind  size  from  100%  passing  105  microns  to  100% passing 38 microns.
-  Chinese collector BHD, when added at the same dosage are pure benzohydroxamic acid and the same grind size produced less attractive  results;  this  is  attributed  to  only  30%  of  the  collector being active benzohydroxamic acid, necessitating higher dosages to produce similar results.
-  Niobium recovery was highest at a grind size of 100% passing 38 microns.

A  number  of  different  flotation  flowsheets  and  reagents,  including  reverse  carbonate  mineral  flotation, followed by pyrochlore flotation with an amine collector, reverse barite and titanium flotation, and direct niobium flotation  with  an  amine  collector  were  all  tested,  but  none  of  these  options  showed  promising results.  For  the  most  part,  mass  rejection  was  limited  and  niobium  recovery  was  low,  with  significant niobium losses to gangue concentrate products. A summary of the tests conducted with results (mass recovery, Nb2O5 assay of the final concentrate and overall niobium recovery) can be found in Table 22. Full test conditions and mass balances are located in Appendix D.

Based on the results for the first 15 tests presented in Table 22, benzohydroxamic acid was identified as the most promising collector for upgrading the Elk Creek ore.  A commercially available benzohydroxamic acid collector from Florrea, known as 7510 was procured for further testwork, as pure benzohydroxamic acid  is  extremely  costly  and  the  Chinese  reagent  BHD  was  difficult  to  source.  It  was  determined  that

Florrea 7510 was approximately 50% strength compared to pure benzohydroxamic acid, and therefore it's dosage was doubled to produce the same results as were obtained with the pure reagent.

Florrea 7150 was tested under similar conditions to F11 with collector dosage increased based on the assumption of 50% strength. Results from F16 are presented in Table 23. Compared to test F7, which used pure benzohydroxamic acid and produced a combined rougher concentrate with 41.97% mass pull and 84.1% niobium recovery, F16 produced a combined rougher concentrate with 42.2% mass pull and 82.3% niobium recovery. Both tests used a 2%  solution of collector 7510, Calgon (sodium hexametaphosphate) for pulp dispersion/carbonate mineral depression, and frother F549 (Cytec).

Figure 20: Comparison of Mass-Recovery Curves for Various Tests Using Either Pure Benzohydroxamic Acid or Florrea 7510

<!-- image -->

From Figure 19, it is clear that test results are quite consistent, indicating that the depressant AQ-4 has no added value compared to Calgon. Further, while it was hypothesized that grinding to 100% passing 20 microns would result in improvements to niobium mineral liberation and thus improve mass rejection, tests  F25  through  F28  do  not  support  this  assumption.  This  is  possibly  due  to  minimal  incremental increase in pyrochlore liberation between a grind size of 38 microns and 20 microns, and/or due to the negative impact (i.e. need for increased collector addition rates to maintain recovery) of the increased slimes generated when grinding to a finer size. Likewise, test F25 demonstrated that temperature may not play as significant of a role in terms of collector dissolution and uptake.

Results from tests F36 through F44 have been summarized in Table 25. In this set of tests, while awaiting a shipment of Florrea 7150, the Chinese reagent BHD was employed in order to drive testwork forward. For these tests collector dosage was scaled based on the relative strength of BHD compared to Florrea 7510.  Parameters  investigated  included  collector  dosage  reduction,  increased  number  of  cleaner scavenger stages, pH adjustment to more alkaline conditions, increased pulp density, and testing of F500 (a lignin sulphonate) as an alternative carbonate mineral depressant. Tests F43 and F44 were the first tests  to  be  conducted  on  the  2 nd Nb  Drill  Core  sample  received  by  SGS,  which  had  a  head  grade  of 0.66% Nb2O5, compared to the first Nb Drill Core which was 0.86% Nb O . 2 5

The primary observations from these tests were as follows:

-  Increased cleaner scavenger stages with lower collector addition in each stage increased recovery by approximately 5% with negligible increase in mass pull (F36 and F37).
-  There appeared to be little room for lowering collector dosage without negative impact on concentrate mass  pull  and  recovery  (tests  F37  and  F38).  Test  F38,  while  yielding  lower  recovery  than  F37, demonstrated that lower collector dosage added in more scavenger stages is beneficial for improving overall recovery. This test included 3 cleaner scavenger stages, as opposed to only one scavenger stage in F36. The resulting recovery was approximately 8% higher, as was mass pull.
-  Comparing  F39  and  F40,  which  were  performed  under  similar  conditions  but  at  50 C  and  80 C, o o respectively, elevated temperature resulted in increased mass pull with a corresponding increase in niobium recovery. Considering the incremental cost of operating at 80 C compared to 50 C, and the o o minimal improvement to test results, further testwork was continued at 50 C. o
-  In F39, nearly perfect linear relations were observed between niobium and titanium recovery. Similar relationships were observed between P2 O5, CaO, and MgO.
-  Operating at a pH of 10.5 as opposed to natural pulp pH of 8 showed no increased in mass rejection or recovery (F42).
-  Higher pulp density resulted in both higher mass pull and recovery but lower concentrate grade, likely due to an increase in entrained material.
-  F500 was not effective in depressing carbonate minerals or increasing recovery.

## 5.2.3. Optimization Batch Flotation Tests

## 5.2.3.1. Batch Flotation Tests on 2 nd Nb Drill Core Material

The  focus  of  the  majority  of  tests  in  the  latter  half  of  the  test  program  was  on  optimizing  the benxohydroxamic acid (Florrea 7510) Calgon reagent scheme to maximize recovery and minimize mass pull,  ultimately reducing acid consumption in hydrometallurgy. The results discussed in this section are divided between tests performed on the 2 nd Nb Drill Core material and assay reject material, which was used at the feed to a mini pilot plant (reported elsewhere). Comprehensive details of the mini pilot plant are outlined in a separate report.

Results from tests F49 to F68, completed on the 2 nd Nb Drill Core material, have been summarized in Table 27. Niobium distribution has been plotted against concentrate mass pull for tests F49 to F58 in Figure 21. From this plot, it is  evident  that  F49  and F50  demonstrate  the  highest  degree of  selectivity towards  niobium  for  recoveries  &gt;60%,  both  following  similar  mass-recovery  curves.  As  previously mentioned, these tests were conducted under identical conditions on 20 micron material (F50) and 38 micron material (F49). F50, with the finer initial grind size, showed slightly higher recovery in the rougher and  first  cleaner  flotation  stages  compared  to  the  coarser  grind  material.  Mass  pull  to  the  rougher concentrate of F50 was more than 15% higher. However, at a target mass pull closer to 10%, which was achieved through a cleaning stage, recovery was just above 60% for both grind sizes.

Figure 21: Comparison of Mass-Recovery Curves for Tests F49 - F58

<!-- image -->

Test  F55  follows  a  nearly  identical  mass  recovery  curve  to  F50,  with  niobium  recovery  just  exceeding 60% with  10%  mass  pull.  Mass  pull  and  niobium  recovery  for  tests  F61  to  F66  have  been  plotted  in Figure 22 in reference to test F55.

Figure 22: Mass-Recovery Curves for Tests F61 - F66 Plotted in Relation to Test F55

Test F62 demonstrated the highest degree of niobium selectivity. The test was conducted using Calgon and  A3-3  (sodium  silicate,  disodium  phosphate  and  sodium  metabisulphate)  as  dispersants/gangue depressants, Florrea 7510, and frother F549. Mass pull to the rougher concentrate was 19.2% with 79.7% niobium  recovery.  After  six  cleaner  scavenger  stages,  a  final  combined  cleaner  concentrate  was produced with 67% niobium recovery in 10.4% of the mass. It was observed that the mini pilot plant material had poorer flotation performance than the Nb Drill Core samples. Of the tests performed on the mini pilot plant material, more promising results were observed on the mini pilot plant feed material when ground in the laboratory IsaMill. Tests F73 and F74, which were conducted on mini pilot plant feed ground in the IsaMill, both produced concentrates with between 60% and 64% niobium recovery in approximately 11% of the mass. These results can be compared to F86, which produced the best results on the mini pilot plant grinding product. Mass pull to this concentrate was 9.1% with 52.5% niobium recovery. Test F86 also employed lower collector addition rates, with a total 7510 addition of 2.4 kg/t. Comparing results of F86 to F84, which used a total of 12.65 kg/t and produced a  concentrate  with  9.3%  mass  pull  and  49.7%  niobium  recovery,  it  became  evident  that  collector  was being added in excess and a great deal of room existed for reduction in collector dosage.  Figure 23 illustrates  mass  pull  and  recovery  for  tests  F66  to  F88,  performed  on  mini  pilot  plant  grinding  circuit material.

Figure 23: Mass-Recovery Curves for Tests F66 - F88 (Excluding F71, F72) on Mini Pilot Plant Material

<!-- image -->

Tests were performed to assess the effectiveness of A3-3 addition, pulp temperature, regrinding, variable air  addition  and  agitation  rates,  imidazoline  and  other  hydroxamate  collectors,  and  various  initial  grind sizes. From tests F60 through F87, the following observations were made:

-  A grind size of 100% passing 38 microns yielded optimum results; little to no improvement was observed with regrinding to 100% passing 20 microns.
-  Depressant/dispersant 'A3-3' addition may help to a very small extent in terms of mass rejection, but overall did not appear to offer significant added benefit.
-  Imadazoline  and  various  other  hydroxamate  collectors  were  tested.  None  of  these  reagents outperformed Florrea 7150 as a selective niobium mineral collector in this particular ore system.

-  Pulp  temperature  appeared  to  have  some  importance,  but  there  was  no  benefit  observed  in elevating  the  temperature  above  approximately  55 C.  Testing  at  75 C  (F82)  only  showed  an o o increase in recovery of gangue mineral without increasing niobium mineral recovery.

Optimization testwork continued, while additional collector screening was carried out simultaneously. F89 through F92 were conducted on the mini pilot plant grinding circuit product after regrinding the material to 100% passing 38 microns in the laboratory IsaMill. Test F93 to F102 were carried out on the 2 nd Nb Drill Core. These test results are summarized in Table 29.

## 5.2.4. Optimization of Reagent Addition Rates

Before the test program shifted focus to optimization, consumption of the collector (Florrea 7510) was relatively  high  due  to  the  addition  of  collector  in  several  stages  of  rougher  and  cleaner  flotation.  An economic  assessment  performed  by  NioCorp  Developments  Ltd.  and  their  associates  revealed  that project economics required collector addition rates to be minimized, ideally to 1 kg/tonne or lower.

The majority of tests from F89 to F102 (Figure 24) focused on reduction of collector addition rates, testing niobium mineral activators with the potential to assist in collector reduction, and screening for other less expensive collectors and/or collector blends.

<!-- image -->

Figure 24: Mass-Recovery Curves for Tests F89 - F92 on Mini Pilot Plant Material (left) with Test F93 as Reference / Mass-Recovery Curves for Tests F93 - F102 on 2 nd Nb Drill Core (left)

<!-- image -->

## 5.2.4.1. Reagent consumption and cleaner circuit performance

Preliminary optimization tests (i.e. F93) with the aim of collector reduction indicated that it was possible to reduce dosage, however reduction to as low as 1 kg/t would be difficult with the inclusion of the cleaner circuit,  which  required  several  scavenger  stages  with  collector  addition  to  each  in  order  to  maintain recovery.  As  a  result,  the  efficiency  of  the  cleaner  circuit  was  placed  under  scrutiny.  Typically,  mass rejection in the cleaner circuit was ~20%, with niobium losses to the cleaner tails just below 20% (F73).

It  was  also  observed  that  a  strong  relationship  existed  between  collector  and  Calgon  dosage.  It  was hypothesized that collector dosage could be further reduced if the effective ratio of collector to Calgon was maintained, and if the cleaner circuit was eliminated from the flowsheet.

## 5.2.4.2. Rougher flotation performance

To  assess  the  potential  of  eliminating  the  cleaner  circuit  from  the  flowsheet,  the  rougher  flotation performance of all tests was assessed to determine the best possible flotation conditions to achieve a rougher  concentrate  with  as  low  as  15%  mass  pull  and  close  to  70%  niobium  recovery.  A  rougher flotation performance index was calculated for each test; this number was calculated by dividing niobium recovery to the rougher concentrate by mass pull. Figure 25 shows the rougher flotation mass niobium recovery curves for all  flotation  tests,  with  'best  tests'  characterized  as  those  with  the  highest  rougher performance index values.

Figure 25: Rougher Flotation Performance for All Flotation Tests

<!-- image -->

Operating conditions for tests with the highest rougher performance index values were then assessed, with particular focus on the ratio of collector 7510 dosage to Calgon dosage. The tests with the highest rougher performance index values were found to be F71 and F61, which had 7510:Calgon addition rates of  7.4  and  7.7,  respectively.  Further,  both  of  these tests  were  performed on 10 kg charges in a 10 kg batch  flotation  cell.  It  was  observed  that  due  to  the  larger  surface  area  of  this  10  kg  flotation  cell compared  to  the  4  kg  flotation  cell  used  in  the  majority  of  the  test  work,  the  operator  was  inherently unable  to  pull  the  froth  as  quickly.  It  was  speculated  that  this  less  aggressive  froth  removal  allowed sufficient  time  for  entrained  particles  to  fall  out  of  the  froth,  ultimately  increasing  rougher  flotation selectivity.

As a result of this analysis, the remainder of the batch flotation tests included rougher flotation circuit only and addition of  Florrea 7510  was  limited  to  approximately  to  1  kg/t.  A  summary  of  results  for  rougher flotation tests performed on 2 nd Nb Drill Core material is presented in Table 30.

## 5.2.5. Batch Flotation Tests on the Leach Residue

Two flotation tests were carried out on hydrochloric leach residue (F115 and F117) with the objective of further  upgrading  the  concentrate  following  improved  niobium  mineral  liberation  after  the  dissolution  of carbonate and phosphate minerals. Attempts were made to remove pyrite, silicate, barite, and Fe-oxides through reverse flotation,  however  in  all  cases  niobium  losses  were  significant  (directly  proportional  to mass pull as is evident in Figure 30). It was concluded that increased liberation after leaching was not sufficient  to  allow  for  further  upgrading  of  the  concentrate.  Further  batch  flotation  work  on  the  leach residue was abandoned.

## 6. Discussion of Flotation Results

## 6.1. Pulp Temperature

It  was  observed  that  although  the  collector,  Florrea  7510  must  be  maintained  at  65-70 C  in  order  to o prevent  precipitation,  flotation  results  were  not  drastically  affected  by  pulp  temperature.  In  rougher flotation at low collector dosages (i.e. in the range of 1 kg/t), there was no significant change in results when pulp temperature was dropped from 50 C to 30 C. This is likely attributed to the rapid uptake of o o collector once introduced to the pulp and the sufficient solubility of the active component, benzohydroxamic acid, at 30 C. o

In  earlier  tests,  at  much  higher  collector  dosages,  temperature  had  a  far  more  pronounced  effect. Figure  33  shows  a  significant  decrease  in  recovery  when  the  temperature  was  dropped  from  50 C  to o 25 C (plot on the left of Figure 33). Tests F55, F59, and F60 had 7510 addition rates of approximately o 10 kg/t, and included a cleaner circuit. The 7510:Calgon ratio was approximately 7.3-7.8.

Tests  F103  and  F112  (Figure  33)  produced  similar  results  in  terms  of  mass  pull  and  recovery,  but included only a rougher flotation circuit, with a total 7510 dosage of ~1 kg/t. The 7510:Calgon for these two tests was 6.3.

Figure 33: Mass-Recovery Curve at Various Pulp Temperatures at High Collector Dosages (left) and Lower Collector Dosages (right)

<!-- image -->

<!-- image -->

For these two sets of tests, which employed a similar ratio of collector to Calgon, it is likely that the more distinct effect of temperature while at high reagent addition rates can be attributed to collector solubility. It may be  that  when  both  Calgon  dosage  and  7510  dosages  are  high,  a  greater  amount  of  collector  is required to overcome the depressing effects of Calgon. However, 7510 is only partially soluble at such a high concentration, its solubility increasing with an increase in temperature. As flotation pulp temperature exceeds  25 C,  more  of  the  collector  is  readily  dissolved  and  becomes  available  for  adsorption  onto o minerals of interest, resulting in increased niobium recovery. This however, is merely speculation. Further testwork is required to fully understand the chemistry and mechanisms of this reagent system.

When  Calgon  dosage  is  reduced,  as  is  the  case  in  F103  and  F112,  a  lesser  amount  of  collector  is required to achieve good results. At lower concentrations, it is possible that the collector is more readily dissolved  at  lower  temperatures  and  therefore  an  increase  in  temperature  has  little  effect  on  niobium recovery.

## 6.2. Pyrite flotation

In the beginning of the test program, pyrite flotation was performed as an initial sulphur removal step prior to niobium flotation. However, the pyrite concentrate rarely contained more than 0.5% mass pull with a sulphur assay of approximately 16% S and 12% sulphur recovery (F71). Due to the inefficiency of this circuit, pyrite flotation was eliminated from the flowsheet.

## 6.3.1. F7 and F11 Concentrates

Two flotation  products,  rougher  concentrate  from  test  F7  and  3 rd cleaner  concentrate  from  F11,  were initially analysed using QEMSCAN. Both tests used benzohydroxamic acid as a niobium mineral collector. The F7 first rougher concentrate had a mass pull of 14.9%, with 49.5% niobium recovery. QEMSCAN revealed that:

-  35% of pyrcohlore was free and liberated in &lt;10 microns
-  12.1 % of pyrochlore was free and liberated in material coarser than 10 microns

-  17.8% pyrochlore was complex
-  11.5% of pyrochlore associated with other oxides
-  8.2% of pyrochlore was associated with carbonates

The F11 3 rd cleaner concentrate had a mass pull of 6.2% with 29.6% niobium recovery. QEMSCAN revealed that:

-  33% or pyrochlore was free and liberated in &lt;10 microns
-  18.8%% of pyrochlore was free and liberated in all material coarser than 10 microns
-  18.6% of pyrochlore was complex
-  14.9% or pyrochlore was associated with other oxides
-  3.5% of pyrochlore was associated with carbonates

From  these  results,  it  was  determined  that  in  order  to  obtain  a  high  grade  pyrochlore  concentrate (approximately  &gt;45%  Nb2O5), at  least 50%  of  the  niobium  would  have  to  be  rejected  from  these concentrates.  Furthermore,  it  is  very  difficult  to  achieve  good  results  and  selectivity  in  conventional flotation when grinding the feed material to less than 10 or 15 µm. Thus, in order to obtain reasonable recovery, the final niobium concentrate must be relatively low in grade.

## 6.3.3. F72 Combined Cleaner Concentrate and Combined Tailings

Test F72 was performed on a 10 kg charge of 2 nd Nb Drill Core material at an initial grind size of 100% passing  37  µm.  The  test  included  eight  rougher/scavenger  stages  followed  by  a  1 st cleaner  and  six 1  cleaner scavenger stages. The combined 1 st st cleaner and 1 st cleaner scavenger concentrates, and the combined rougher and cleaner tailings were analyzed by QEMSCAN.

The results clearly indicate the niobium collector was fairly selective and efficient in recovering pyrochlore, ilmenite, and Nb-rutile. Furthermore, a large portion of dolomite, and ankerite/siderite was rejected to the tailings. The main weakness of this particular collector is its weak selectivity over titanium and iron oxide minerals.

## 6.4. Stage Addition of Reagents

Through all flotation tests, the necessity of stage addition of the collector has been observed. In almost all cases, the first concentrate collected, whether a cleaner or rougher concentrate, was lower in niobium assay than subsequent scavenger concentrates. This is generally uncommon in flotation. In the case of this complex ore, it appears the first flotation stage, while contributing to overall niobium recovery, is far less selective than subsequent steps. This is likely attributed to the entrainment of fines (both pyrochlore and gangue) which are removed in the first flotation stage, allowing for true, selective flotation to take place in later stages. It may also be that these slimes consume a great deal of collector in this first step, which would account for the need to continually add collector through the scavenger stages.

## 7. Roasting of Flotation Concentrate

Select  samples  of  flotation  concentrate  were  subjected  to  a  reductive  roast  with  the  objective  of converting  hematite  to  magnetite  to  be  removed  by  low  intensity  magnetic  separation,  resulting  in  a higher grade, lower mass feed for hydrometallurgy. Three reductive roasts were conducted, the first two on flotation  concentrate  before  pre-leaching  (C1  and  C2).  The  third  reductive  roast  was  run  on  a  preleach concentrate (C3).

For each test, 150 g of sample was measured into a quartz tube which was inserted into the furnace and rotated at a rate of 2 rpm. Argon gas was allowed to flow through the furnace at a rate of 500 mL/min as the temperature was brought to target. Test C1 was run at a target temperature of 500 C, C2 at 650 C, o o

and C3 at 650 C. Once at target temperature, the argon gas was switched off and carbon monoxide was o allowed to flow through the furnace at 500 mL/min for 2.5 hours. After 2.5 hours at temperature, carbon monoxide  was  switched  off,  argon  gas  was  switched  on  and  the  furnace  was  allowed  to  cool  to  an internal temperature less than 200 C. All valves to the furnace were then closed and the sample left in the o furnace  to  cool  for  an  additional  ~48  hours,  after  which  point  the  glass  tube  was  removed  from  the furnace and then sample was removed from the glass tube. The roast calcine was ground using mortar and pestle and any changes in physical appearance of the sample were noted.

After roasting was completed, each of the samples was submitted to Davis Tube testing to assess the potential for LIMS to separate any hematite which had been converted to magnetite. Davis tube results have been presented in Table 35, Table 36, and Table 37.

Flotation concentrate from flotation test F49, both before and after roasting (i.e., on the C1 feed and C1 calcine, and C3 feed and calcine) was submitted for Semi-Quantitative XRD. XRD results are presented in Table 38 and Table 39. The following was observed in the roasting tests:

The roasting tests on the flotation concentrate both before and after pre-leaching did not result in efficient conversion of magnetite to hematite. Due to this, LIMS was not an effective means of rejecting mass prior to  downstream  processing.  At  lower  roasting  temperatures  (~500 C),  a  portion  of  the  hematite  was o converted to magnetite and ~18% of iron was removed in low intensity magnetic separation in 10% of the mass. However, niobium losses to the magnetic fraction were 16%, negating the benefit of mass rejection by LIMS. The lack of conversion of hematite to magnetite at higher roasting temperatures (~650 C) is not o well  understood at this  time.  Should  more efficient  conversion be  achieved  through roasting,  magnetic separation  would  likely  become  a  more  effective  means  of  mass  rejection.  Thus,  further  testwork  is required  before  it  can  be  determined  if  it  is  possible  to  reject  mass  through  roasting  coupled  with magnetic separation.

## Conclusions and Recommendations

## Conclusions

Due to the extremely fine grain size of niobium bearing minerals in the Elk Creek deposit, particularly pyrochlore, mineral beneficiation using a typical niobium mineral processing flowsheet was shown to be challenging.  Mineralogical  limitations  of  the  ore  prevented  the  production  of  a  standard,  high  grade pyrochlore concentrate and measures were taken to produce a high recovery, low grade niobium mineral concentrate  with  the  aim  of  maximizing  mass  rejection  and  niobium  recovery  to  reduce  reagent consumption and equipment size in downstream processing.

Examination of physical separation techniques, including gravity and magnetic separation, revealed that neither method was effective in rejecting sufficient mass without associated niobium losses due to the finely disseminated, highly complex nature of the ore.

In  flotation,  benzohydroxamic  acid  (commercially  available  as  Florrea  7510)  was  determined  to  be  the most suitable collector for selective recovery of niobium minerals. When used in conjunction with sodium hexametaphosphate (commercially available in North America as Calgon), a combined rougher flotation concentrate with niobium recovery of 65% or higher was produced in approximately 15% of the mass.

Based on bench scale flotation test work and extensive review of both rougher and cleaner flotation, the following can be noted:

-  Grinding to 100% passing 38 microns was required to achieve near target niobium recovery with sufficient mass rejection. Further grinding to 100% passing 20 µ m did not improve flotation results, possibly due to only marginal increase in niobium mineral liberation. Thus, it is recommended that future flotation testwork be conducted with on material ground to 100% passing 38 µm.
-  Improved flotation performance was noted on mini-pilot plant feed material ground in an IsaMill versus conventional grinding, likely due to the finer size distribution produced by the IsaMill, even at the similar 100% passing targets.
-  Elimination of the cleaner circuit allowed for higher niobium recovery and reduction of collector addition rates to ~1 kg/t (or potentially less).
-  Successful rougher flotation performance depended on the relative dosage of collector (Florrea 7510) to depressant (Calgon), thus it is important to optimize the Florrea 7510:Calgon ratio.
-  Stage  addition  of  reagents  through  multiple  rougher  flotation  stages  is  necessary  to  maintain niobium recovery and minimize mass pull to the flotation concentrate.
-  Tests  showed  that  pulp  temperature  in  flotation  was  an  important  variable  at  high  collector dosages  (~10  kg/t).  However,  at  lower  dosages  little  difference  was  observed  when  pulp temperature was dropped from 50 C to 30 C. Thus it is recommended that the flotation circuit be o o operated at typical mill discharge temperatures around 30-35 C to minimize costs and operating o challenges associated with pulp heating.

-  Pulp pH should be kept in the range of 8-9 (natural slurry pH); increasing pH to 9-10 did not result in improved results and therefore pH was not adjusted for the majority of tests. Reduction of pulp pH to below 7 had adverse effects on flotation and is not recommended.
-  Initial  tests  demonstrated  that  lead  nitrate  had  a  positive  effect  on  niobium  recovery  at  lower collector dosages but this was not confirmed in later tests. It is still uncertain if lead nitrate can indeed improve results significantly.

Reductive  roasts  on  the  flotation  concentrate  and  pre-leach  residue  were  not  highly  successful  in producing  a  large  amount  of  magnetite  to  be  removed  by  LIMS.  At  a  roasting  temperature  of  500 C, o partial  reduction  was  observed  but  not  to  the  extent  that  all  of  the  iron  was  transferred  to  magnetite. Further,  niobium  losses  to  the  magnetic  concentrate  were  high  (~15%)  even  with  partial  conversion, making  the  roast  detrimental  to  overall  metallurgical  recovery.    Further  roasting  testwork  is  not recommended at this time.

## Recommendations

The following is recommended for further testwork on Elk Creek ore:

-  Optimization study to assess the limits of the following parameters in flotation:
- o Collector addition rate and collector mixtures
- o Assessment  of  the  effect  of  different  metallic  compounds  (similar  to  lead  nitrate)  on niobium flotation behaviour and collector dosage
- o Depressant addition rate and assessment of different dispersants

It has been demonstrated that of these parameters, the collector and dispersant/depressant dosage are of  utmost  importance.  Prior  to  running  a  full  scale  pilot  plant,  it  would  be  highly  beneficial  to  run  a statistically designed set of batch flotation tests with the objective of optimizing collector dosage, mass pull,  niobium  recovery  and  the  ratio  of  collector  to  depressant.  This  set  of  experiments  would  provide detailed information and allow for rough predictions of flotation mass pull and niobium recovery for given reagent dosages through mathematical modelling.

-  Trade-off study on the effect of IsaMill and/or vertical grinding mills versus conventional grinding on flotation
- o This study should be executed with both grinding types targeting 100% passing 38 µm; subsequent flotation should follow the final recommended flotation flowsheet and reagent scheme

The  grinding  study  will  be  of  great  value  to  NioCorp  Developments  Ltd.  in  minimizing  grinding  costs and/or optimizing flotation performance in the process plant design for Elk Creek. This information will also be of great value prior to full-scale pilot plant testing.

-  Variability testing:
- o A  number  of  variability  samples  should  be  collected  and  tested  with  the  developed flowsheet.  The  exact  number  of  variability  samples  should  be  determined  by  NioCorp Developments  Ltd.  and  associates  to  capture  major  ore  variation  in  the  deposit.  This testwork  will  determine  how  robust  the  flowsheet  is  in  treating  the  entirety  of  the  Elk Creek deposit.

-  Geometallurgical testing:
- o This analysis will be extremely valuable for NioCorp Developments Ltd. to determine the effect of feed mineralogy on flotation and grinding in terms of reagent consumption and plant  energy  requirements.  The  developed  model  can  be  used  to  identify  different orebody zones which may respond differently to processing in real operation.

Overall, the current recommended mineral processing flowsheet is quite simple and as such, a great deal of information could be obtained and cost reduction may be realized through basic optimization testwork and trade-off studies, ideally conducted prior to the commissioning of a full scale pilot plant.
